text:
Charging families for each bag of rubbish they produce seems like a good idea for the environment and economy, but it might not be. In many developed countries, rubbish collection is a common service. Rubbish bags or bins are collected regularly and taken to a landfill. Economists find this service strange because it is usually free. Households pay for it through local taxes, but a family that fills four bins pays the same as an elderly couple that fills one. However, rubbish disposal is not free. More rubbish means more collectors and trucks are needed, and local authorities pay more in landfill fees. This is a basic economic problem: if rubbish disposal is free, people will produce too much rubbish. The solution seems to be to make households pay for the rubbish they throw away. This would encourage them to throw out less and recycle more, assuming there are places to recycle. 

However, American economists Don Fullerton and Thomas Kinnaman found that this approach has complicated and sometimes disappointing results. They studied several American towns and cities that started charging households for rubbish. The most common system is to sell stickers or tags for rubbish bags or cans. Only bags with these labels are collected. In a study of Charlottesville, Virginia, where residents were charged 80 cents per tagged bag, the authors found that the benefits did not cover the costs of the scheme. The number of bags fell by 37%, but this was mainly because people crammed more rubbish into each bag, a practice known as the 'Seattle stomp'. The weight of rubbish collected fell by only 14%, and in other Virginian cities without a pricing scheme, it fell by 3.5% anyway. Some people also resorted to illegal dumping to avoid paying. 

One positive outcome was a 15% increase in recycling, but this might not be due to the fee, as many people were already recycling. In a later study, Fullerton and Kinnaman found that pricing reduces rubbish weight, but not by much. A 10% increase in sticker prices only cuts rubbish by 0.3%. To significantly reduce rubbish, people would need to buy less of everything, and a small tax on rubbish is unlikely to make a big difference. Other factors, like income and education, might be just as important. In richer towns, people throw out more rubbish and have less time to recycle. 

Should we stop charging for rubbish? Not necessarily. Free disposal is too cheap, but simple policies can have complex effects. Detailed economic models are needed to understand them, and sometimes the results are not what we expect.

Theodore Zeldin explores how our work life might change. Do you feel respected and appreciated at work? Today, just being successful in your career isn't enough. Many professions feel undervalued, and even famous people can feel bitter. Loving your job used to be special, but now you need to consider how your work affects you personally, including your mind, character, and relationships. This is important because no matter how skilled you are, if your work makes you boring or unable to talk to others outside your field, or if you're too busy to gain wisdom or use your imagination, then status or money won't make up for your shortcomings as a person.

I am exploring how work can focus on fulfilling personal aspirations, rather than just shaping us for industrial needs. Work should not only create wealth but also offer a meaningful lifestyle, help discover hidden talents, and provide diverse human interactions. However, this doesn't mean eliminating unemployment is the only goal. As people become more educated, they want jobs that are enriching, interesting, and useful. A career should be like a work of art, with a fulfilled person at its center.

Even middle-class jobs aren't as appealing as they used to be. Doctors are often more stressed than their patients, accountants worry about ethics, architects rarely use their creativity, and administrators are stuck in bureaucracy. Middle managers are losing confidence in their roles. Meanwhile, companies and public institutions are getting smaller. Efforts like decentralizing decisions, improving skills, and rewarding performance haven't gained employee commitment. In Britain, only 8% of employees strongly feel their values match their organization's values.

I am investigating various jobs to see how they shape or sometimes harm people. I've studied how different cultures expand human potential and how courage can be developed. I've looked at happiness, love, friendship, and respect, and now I'm focusing on finding more satisfying ways to work. Many experts work on extending the life and income of companies, but we also need to evaluate ourselves as people and decide who we want to spend our lives with. How many of us feel truly alive at work? How many are like part-time slaves, stuck in jobs because we see no other choice?

Take hotel workers, for example. They make up 10% of the workforce in the hospitality industry. Many intelligent and lively people work in hotels with low prestige, low pay, and long hours because hotels haven't been rethought since the days of the Ritz. A hotel is more than a place to sleep; it's like a mini United Nations where people from around the world meet but often don't interact. Many hotel staff are foreigners eager to learn new languages and cultures, but they have limited interaction with guests. Hotels could be cultural centers, connecting guests with the city and each other. Hoteliers could use the skills of the students they employ, rather than just giving them basic tasks. If they focused on their staff's ambitions, they could offer more services. But accountants often say companies should focus on one main activity to maximize profits. It's time to rethink this from a human perspective, not just a financial one.

For me, work is about relationships. Now that people want more than just obedience and see work as a way to express independence, they should have the chance to design their jobs and choose their colleagues and customers, within practical and profitable limits. This means they need to communicate beyond professional jargon and connect with different minds. Everyone knows communication is important, but true conversation is different. It's a deeper interaction that creates respect and helps understand others, often changing us in the process. It's more than just relaxing; it's a way to establish equality. Every meaningful conversation changes the world a little bit.

**Broadcasting: The Social Shaping of a Technology**

The word 'broadcasting' originally meant spreading seeds by hand over a large area. This idea is not only about farming but also about modern growth and development. It suggests spreading resources widely to produce a good result, like a harvest. Broadcasting assumes there is a central source of information that can be shared with many people.

The question is why a new technology that could send words and pictures electronically was set up in a way that fits this farming metaphor. Television, like the telegraph and telephone, is a two-way communication tool. Yet, from the start, it was seen as a one-way, centralised 'mass' medium. This setup matched the social and economic structures of modern societies. Other ways of organising television were tried but did not last.

Two interesting alternatives to traditional broadcasting deserve mention. In the early 1930s in Britain, radio enthusiasts experimented with two-way television, similar to a telephone. Magazines like Radio News explained how to build TV transmitters and receivers. However, in 1938, the British Radio Manufacturers Association set standards that pushed these hobbyists out. This ended the chance for television to develop as a grassroots, equal form of communication in Britain.

Broadcasting was linked to strong economic interests and the structure of modern societies. In the USA in the early 1930s, television was mainly used for public shows and was seen as a competitor to the film industry. In Britain and Germany, most people watched TV in public places. Although the idea of two-way, amateur television was not successful, public viewing of TV was common in the 1930s and could have challenged the idea of TV as a home-based medium. But this did not happen. Manufacturers saw the potential for selling TVs to homes once prices dropped. As people in Western countries gained better living standards from the 1920s, the dream of having entertainment at home became possible for many.

Broadcasting is closely linked to social modernisation. As societies became more centralised and traditional communities broke up, people became more mobile and isolated. Centralised broadcasting helped governments reach all citizens with important information and created a sense of national community. This made broadcasting the dominant form of radio and TV.

Broadcasting also played a role in democracy by providing equal access to information needed for informed participation in society. However, as television changes, the term 'broadcasting' might become outdated. It may only refer to a specific way of organising audio-visual technology during a certain period of social modernisation.

**Clutter**  
Sometimes, it feels like no matter how many things you own, you never feel safe. It's normal to want a home that meets your needs, but sometimes the desire to get more things goes too far. Modern advertising is made to make us feel insecure. It often tells us that if we don't have a certain product, we are not good enough. To see how much ads affect you, try not to read any billboards next time you walk down the street. These expensive ads influence us in strong ways without us even noticing. We see them everywhere—on TV, radio, newspapers, magazines, posters, T-shirts, the internet—all telling us to buy more.

**Caves**  
Research centers and universities around the world have spent years studying caves, focusing on how they form, their water systems, and their biology. Caves are a small but mysterious part of nature, which makes us curious and eager to learn more about them. Because they are natural wonders, caves have been studied for a long time, especially in places where they have affected how people live. However, exploring many caves requires physical skill, so cave research is often done by both scientists and amateurs who enjoy visiting caves for fun.

**Weather Watch**  
Many people who paid attention to the weather without any tools laid the groundwork for meteorology, which has become a very technical science since the 17th century. Today, satellites and electronic tools send us weather information quickly, and computers solve complex math problems faster than humans can. Meteorology uses many long words that can be hard to understand for non-experts. It might seem like there's no room for simple weather knowledge, but that's not true. Human experience is still important for turning computer data into weather forecasts. Observations from people can still provide unique information that helps professionals understand the atmosphere better.

**MUSIC AND THEATRE**

Until recently, I believed opera was mainly about theatre. Now, I think differently. After working at a national opera house, I learned that opera is primarily about music, with theatre coming second. This makes sense, but I come from the theatre world, where the spoken word and the actor are most important. In theatre, there is no one directing the action once the play starts, and the performers and audience usually speak the same language.

At musical performances, like concerts or operas, many people, including myself, may not have a deep understanding of music. Some might feel embarrassed about what they don't know, but most are amazed by the performers' skills. A brilliant singer or a perfect string section is easy to admire. Even a good musician shows the results of years of hard work. Watching top-class music is like watching an athletics match. We know athletes are doing something similar to running for a bus, but they do it much better.

Theatre audiences have different expectations. They often don't understand an actor's skill and aren't particularly impressed by something that seems close to what they could do themselves. They don't usually applaud when an actor finishes a long speech, although they often ask, "How do you learn all those lines?" This doesn't mean theatre audiences are more generous or less demanding than music audiences. In fact, many people attend both. However, in theatre, audiences and performers meet on more equal terms, no matter how challenging the play or event.

The question is, should music learn from theatre about this relationship? I think yes, because a different approach can change the concert-goer's experience. Live music is naturally theatrical, full of emotion and drama, and it connects with the listener's imagination. However, the way music is presented often feels too formal, with strict dress codes and too much respect for conductors and soloists, creating a hierarchy between players and listeners. On the other hand, when audiences interrupt performances by clapping between movements, it can disrupt the flow of the music, even if it's meant as appreciation.

Is there a solution? Yes, a lot is being done to attract new audiences to concerts and operas and to make 'serious' music more accessible. I remember a special event, Jonathan Dove's community opera "In Search of Angels," which moved from a cathedral to the town. It was a high-quality musical experience, and it was life-changing for many in the audience, who were not just watching but also participating.

What I hope for in music is more of the risk and boldness that theatre can show. Sometimes this comes from using unusual or challenging locations, which can surprise both performers and audiences. It might be uncomfortable, with poor acoustics or cold temperatures, but theatre audiences have learned to be adventurous. I know most plays are performed in a traditional way, similar to concerts. However, I believe something should change in music conventions. I am just an enthusiast who loves theatre and music, and I want both to succeed and for more people to enjoy them as much as I do.

**Sand**  
While I admire how sand can be turned into useful things like glass and concrete, I don't really like it in its natural form. To me, sand is mostly an annoying obstacle between a car park by the sea and the water. It blows into your face, gets into your sandwiches, and hides important things like car keys and coins. When you're wet, it sticks to you like glue and is hard to remove, even with a strong water hose. But here's the strange part: as soon as you step onto a beach towel, get into a car, or walk on a clean carpet, it falls off you. For days, you keep finding piles of sand on the floor every time you take off your shoes, and more sand flies around when you take off your socks. Sand stays with you longer than many illnesses. No, I don't like sand at all.

**Lock and Key**  
People have always wanted a safe home for privacy and security since they first started building houses. The simple wooden beam behind the door has been replaced by electronic locks that use a plastic card with many combinations. But the desire to keep out the 'bad guys' is still there. Locks and keys are partly about feeling safe. Recently, some companies have tried using computerized locks, where smart cards control electronic locks. But people don't like them much. You might accept them at work, but at home, everyone wants the comfort of turning a real key in a lock. So, when one locksmith company created a new electronic system, they made sure to include a real metal key in it.

**Modern Art**  
I was nervous about visiting the new Tate Modern gallery because, like many people, I don't really understand modern art. I know I like some of it, especially furry things, neon light sculptures, and big photographs. Maybe if I knew more about it, I'd have more opinions. But you're not supposed to analyze it like a school essay. The idea is to let art speak to you. This is a great idea, but it never worked for me. However, this new gallery tries to help visitors understand the reasons behind the artworks. The first thing I noticed were the labels, real labels that explained the context of a work and what it was trying to say. Instead of just staring at the pictures without understanding, these bits of information helped me get it.

**Every Picture Tells a Story**

When novels are turned into films, the story often needs to be shortened and simplified. This can be frustrating for the writer, but it can also be enlightening. While working on a script, I realized that much of the dialogue and description in a novel can be left out, yet the main idea still comes through. This doesn't mean the original text was unnecessary. It's about how each medium—books and films—engages the audience differently and uses repetition in its own way. In novels, repetition helps readers remember character traits and who is speaking. In plays, dialogue often mimics real speech, sometimes using extra words just to keep the conversation going, even if it doesn't add much meaning.

**Watching Movies**

Watching movies can be an immersive experience, making you feel part of the film's world. For the duration of the movie, you escape from reality. However, once the movie ends and the lights come on, you're back in the real world. In the past, movies were seen as just entertainment, not art. Many people, including our parents and teachers, thought movies were not serious art, even though they enjoyed watching them.

**The Film Studios**

The Leiper Film Company studios were a mix of different buildings, making it hard to find your way around. There were a few permanent landmarks, like the Script Department, but many rooms looked the same and were hard to distinguish. There were three main entrances, but none had a clear sign or information desk to help visitors. However, strangers were rare because the studio didn't encourage them. Employees knew their way around and worked together to create films that offered audiences a break from everyday life.

**Film-makers**

Many people dream of making movies. Bookstores are full of guides on scriptwriting and film production, and universities offer courses on filmmaking. Competitions even offer cameras like the one Robert Rodriguez used to make his film El Mariachi, which cost $7,000 and made him a well-known director. Rodriguez achieved his dream early, making his breakthrough film by age 23. In the past, filmmakers took longer to succeed. They started in smaller roles, like editors or writers, and learned by making low-budget films. Directors like John Huston and Fred Zinnemann only became successful later in life. Today, without the support of big studios, new filmmakers often have to be independent and resourceful.

In those days, council houses covered the western side of the city. They were rows of crowded, dull homes made of orange half-brick or pale white stucco. In the summer, chemicals from the May and Baker factory, two miles away, filled the air with a strong smell of sulfur. It was common to see a paperboy wrinkling his nose in disgust as he delivered papers in the morning. I have forgotten most of my early life, but I remember sitting near an upstairs window, watching the houses fade into the distance. 

Later, I have memories of faces I can't name, my mother ironing towels in a house that might not have been ours, and snow falling over the turrets of a mansion at Earlham. My mother often appears in these memories. She was a small, precise, and usually angry woman. I never understood why she was angry, so I couldn't do anything to make her happy. Even as a child, when I went with her to shops in Bunnett Square or into the city, I noticed her unusual personality. She was the most solitary person I knew, feeling alone even in a room full of people. She was also very strict about behaving properly, which was rare in West Earlham. This sometimes led to intense cleaning or handwashing and instructions to 'behave properly.' I didn't understand this moral code then, and I still don't fully understand it now. It meant not walking into neighbors' gardens or damaging their rose bushes, sitting quietly in the dining room with hands folded, listening to radio programs my mother liked, and following many other rules.

Despite her solitude, my mother had friends. There was Mrs. Buddery, who loved the Royal Family, Mrs. Winall, who rarely spoke, and Mrs. Laband, who was livelier but not fully accepted by the others. Later, I realized they were not great company. They often talked about their health, the weather, and ungrateful children, a group I felt I belonged to. Looking back, it felt like a heavy weight of the West Earlham houses, my mother and her friends, and the need to 'behave properly' was on my shoulders. I felt I had to grow up quickly to free myself from it, but it wasn't easy.

Growing up in West Earlham followed a routine. Until you were five, you stayed at home, often getting in your parents' way. I remember boring days when I was about four, playing on a rug while my mother sat in an armchair. After your fifth birthday, you went to Avenue Road infants school, half a mile towards the city. Some lucky children had mothers with old bikes and child seats. My mother let me go with other children for this journey. 

If I remember anything from those early years, it's the summer holidays. During these times, I saw glimpses of the world outside West Earlham. There was an old man next to Mrs. Buddery who told stories about his time in the Merchant Navy. Once, there was a charity event at a house on Christchurch Road, where a kind woman gave out lemonade and talked about the League of Pity, a junior charity. My mother dismissed it, saying they just wanted money. She often talked about people having selfish motives, especially politicians, whom she deeply distrusted. She thought of the House of Commons as a place where rich people took money from the public. I might be exaggerating, but my mother didn't have much kindness. 

To be fair, my mother cared about my education. Sometimes on Sundays, she took me in my 'good clothes' on the 85 bus to the Norwich Castle Museum. We would walk through rooms of paintings by the Norwich School of Artists. My mother didn't mind this activity and even started to have opinions about the art. I remember her once joking about a painting of a Roman soldier, saying, 'Well, I wouldn't like to meet him on a dark night!' This was one of the few times I remember her trying to make a joke.

**Philadelphia Avenue**

I walked down the odd-numbered side of Philadelphia Avenue. The evening was getting darker, and the air was thick with a light, prickly rain. This made my walk feel secretive and sheltered. I knew this side of the street well since I was a child. Our neighbors were the Matzes and the Pritchards, and there was Han Kieffer's grocery store. My first friends, all girls, lived in the Kring's and the Pottses' houses. Even if I didn't know everyone by name, each house was familiar to me, like the small channels in the sidewalk that carried rainwater from the roofs to the street. As the street went downhill, the houses seemed to get smaller, and the front yards became tiny. Over the years, things changed: wooden porch railings and pillars were replaced with wrought iron in a style that seemed Southern or Spanish. In Shillington, some houses I remembered as homes became stores, and some stores, like Pep Conrad's and Han Kieffer's, became homes again. I wondered how people lived in those spaces that used to be shops, with the smells of old merchandise still there.

**Bachelor Fads**

Rick Gilbert, a furniture designer, lives in a flat that used to be a curtain warehouse. It has typical loft features like exposed brickwork and large doors. Gilbert didn't want an open-plan space because it was hard to separate work from home life. So, he used a large sheet of corrugated plastic to divide the space. This created a hallway and led the eye to the kitchen in the middle of the flat. He wanted the kitchen to be a neutral area for both cooking for friends and making coffee for clients. To balance the modern look of the plastic and steel, he used light wood for the floors. His flat has futuristic furniture but also sentimental pieces from his parents or markets.

**Bruce Chatwin**

Bruce Chatwin's life was full of secrets and mysteries, but he was a brilliant writer. His first book, "In Patagonia," published in 1977, changed travel writing. It was imaginative, like a thriller, and had the charm of romantic fiction. Chatwin often mixed fact with fiction to make stories more interesting. He believed that through travel, one could discover histories that seemed to exist just to fascinate future explorers.

**Swimming**

During a summer rainstorm in 1996, I swam in the pool behind my house. The rain made the water bubble and burst, and the storm's noise drowned out the birds. It was then that I thought about swimming across Britain. I wanted to follow the rain to the sea and escape the routine of swimming back and forth in a pool. In today's world, everything is labeled and explained, but activities like walking, cycling, and swimming let us experience the wild and mysterious parts of the world. A swimming journey would allow me to explore these mysterious places, like dark woods or high mountains.

Text: 'CRYING Charles Darwin thought that humans cry for no clear evolutionary reason. He was probably wrong. More recent scientists have shown its social importance. Psychiatrist John Bowlby said crying helps create a bond between mother and child. Many think that tears, especially in children, show helplessness. But why adults cry is harder to understand. The sound of crying is less important than the visual signal it gives. In early human groups, crying might have helped build trust and social connections. Tears can also have other reasons. We might cry to show sympathy for people facing great injustice. Also, tears can come without us wanting them, which can be embarrassing, like when we hear inspiring music or speeches. We might cry during a sentimental movie, but this happens more often when we are with others than when we are alone. The social role of crying seems clear, but research is still ongoing.'

**The Heat is On**

We all know about global warming, but how much warmer will the Earth get, and how will it affect us? Many people have an idea of what global warming is, but its exact effects are uncertain. A warmer climate will likely change the weather everywhere. Since the atmosphere is connected to everything on Earth, changes in climate will impact plants, animals, water, and soil. Humans rely on these natural resources to grow food, build cities, and support billions of people. Any changes to these resources are important.

The challenge is understanding how the world will change and what causes these changes. Over the last 100 years, human activities have increased the levels of certain gases in the atmosphere, which are linked to global temperatures. These gases are likely affecting the climate, but we don't fully understand the global heat balance, making future predictions uncertain. We do know that greenhouse gas levels have changed with global temperatures over the past 40,000 years, suggesting a strong connection.

Evidence shows that Earth's surface has warmed by about 0.6°C over the past century. Most scientists believe this warming is not natural and is partly due to human pollution. Researchers use computer models called general circulation models (GCMs) to predict future climate conditions. These models use physics and chemistry to analyze temperature, pressure, solar radiation, and other factors. However, they are simplifications and have limitations. They are also slow and costly to run. We don't fully understand all climate processes, but we know the system is complex.

Despite these challenges, most agree that climate change will happen faster than before. GCMs help us understand what the future might look like. They predict that by 2100, the average global temperature will rise by 1°C to 3.5°C, sea levels will rise by 15-95 cm, and precipitation patterns will change. Extreme weather, like heatwaves, floods, and droughts, may become more common.

These changes could affect ecosystems, like forests and grasslands, and the benefits they provide. Resources like food, water, and human settlements are sensitive to climate changes. Some effects might be irreversible and harmful, but not all. Some impacts could be positive. For example, in Australia, warmer temperatures have increased wheat yields since 1952 due to fewer frosts.

However, many predicted effects of climate warming are negative. Small climate changes can affect water availability, especially in dry regions or areas with existing shortages. The Mediterranean Basin is one example, where rainfall patterns have changed, concentrating more rain in autumn and winter.

Another concern is changes to glaciers, which will affect ice, vegetation, wildlife, and human structures. The Arctic ice might melt completely, making transport and exploration easier but increasing iceberg risks. The most visible effect of global warming could be rising sea levels due to ocean expansion and melting ice. With half the world's population living in coastal areas, rising sea levels could cause severe flooding and displacement. Cities like London, New York, and Tokyo could face major disruptions. Many people could lose their homes, creating environmental refugees. Small island nations might disappear entirely, causing devastating impacts on their people and cultures, and challenging other countries to accommodate displaced populations.

Text: 'Mission to Mars Wanted: a middle-aged, married couple for a 501-day trip to Mars and back. Applicants must be strong both physically and emotionally. This will be the profile of the first astronauts to go to Mars if multi-millionaire Dennis Tito's plans to launch a capsule on 5 January 2018 are successful. The capsule will take the crew to about 160 km above Mars. The spacecraft will use Mars's gravity to return to Earth without using more fuel, as saving fuel is very important. The 2018 date is set because the next time Mars and Earth are in the right position for a launch is not until 2031. It's a big challenge, but the race is on to create systems with completely new technologies. If these can be developed quickly enough, the spacecraft might succeed. But even if it never leaves Earth, the efforts to reach these ambitious goals will still be valuable, as they will help future missions.'

**Aesthetics**

Sometimes, the very existence of art can make it hard to understand aesthetic theory. This is because art is often seen as just physical objects like buildings, books, paintings, or statues, separate from human experience. However, the true essence of art is what it does to our experiences. This misunderstanding can make it difficult to truly understand art.

Moreover, when art becomes famous and admired over time, it can create fixed ideas that block new insights. Once an art piece becomes a classic, it often gets disconnected from the human experiences and conditions that created it and the effects it has on people today. This separation makes it hard to see the broader meaning of art, which is what aesthetic theory tries to explain. Art is often placed in a separate world, away from other human activities and achievements.

A key task for someone writing about the philosophy of art is to reconnect art with everyday life experiences. Just like mountains are part of the earth, art should be seen as part of human experience. Geographers and geologists show how mountains are connected to the earth, and art theorists should do the same for art.

To truly understand art, we need to step away from the art itself for a while and look at the everyday experiences that we don't usually see as artistic. We need to take a different path to understand art. Just like you can enjoy flowers without knowing about plants, understanding flowers means learning about soil, air, water, and sunlight. Similarly, to understand art, we should start with the raw experiences that catch our attention and bring us joy.

Many people enjoy things like movies, jazz, comic strips, and news stories without realizing they are forms of art. When art is only seen in museums and galleries, people look for enjoyable experiences in their daily lives. Even those who criticize the idea of art being only in museums often still separate art from everyday life. The best times for appreciating art are when it is closely connected to everyday activities.

**Observing Lions**

People often imagine lions hunting as a perfect team. In the evening light, a group of quiet lions suddenly appears and surrounds their prey, like skilled hunters. Lions seem to be very social animals, working together for a common goal, which is to catch their next meal. However, after many years of watching lions in the wild, we have a different view. When we began our research in 1978, we wanted to find out why lions hunt together, raise their cubs, and scare away rivals with loud roars. If an animal's success is measured by how many of its offspring survive, then working together might not always be beneficial. If an animal is too generous, others might benefit more than it does. So, why do lions cooperate? We thought we could answer this question in two to three years. But lions are very good at doing nothing. Like the noble gases krypton, argon, and neon, lions are often inactive. It has taken many research methods to learn about their behavior. Since wild lions can live up to 18 years, we are only now starting to understand the answers to our questions.

**Pop Music Review**

The release of Bedrock's third album was a big moment for the band. "New Life" started a new trend in rock music in the country for the rest of the decade. The old style of serious and plain rock music was replaced by a lighter, more melodic style. The album mixed social observations and strong emotions with sounds like fairground organs and brass bands. It was full of humor and irony, and the singers didn't hide their accents. Bedrock showed they were good at collecting different styles and writing versatile songs. They sang about typical English topics like sunbathing and Sunday afternoons. But the album's real strength was in its deeper, more emotional songs like "So Low," which was about weather, and "To the Brink," a serious ballad. "New Life" was consistently high quality, with 16 tracks and no filler, which is rare in the era of long CDs.

**Extract from an Autobiography**

As a child, I was fascinated by stories of "The Sibyl," wise women who had a lot of influence in ancient times. I first heard about them in a story my mother told me. An old woman from Cumae offered nine books to Tarquin, the King of Rome, for 300 gold pieces. He refused, so she burned three books and offered the remaining six for the same price. When he refused again, she burned three more books. He finally bought the last three for the full price. I understood that there was a lesson in this story about salesmanship and life. I was often a lonely child and would ask to play with others but was sometimes refused. My mother advised me to do something interesting so that other kids would want to join me. It worked, and I never forgot that lesson. When I had the chance to write a travel book, I looked for something I was interested in, something relevant to my life. I'm not a big traveler, so I sent my editor a long list of places I didn't want to visit. I'm mostly interested in ruins because I like to travel through time in my mind.

**What Becomes of Your Manuscript?**

When you submit your manuscript, it usually ends up in a pile waiting to be sorted. This pile is called the "slush pile." The person sorting it is often a junior editor or an experienced freelancer who works part-time. They don't have much influence, but they want to find something original. The junior editor hopes to make a name for themselves, and the freelancer wants to keep their job. If they think your novel is good, they will pass it to a senior editor. Eventually, it will be discussed at a meeting. The editor who supports your novel must explain why it should be accepted, based on its quality and potential sales. They also consider if you, as an author, have long-term potential, which you should mention in your letter. Another important factor is how promotable you are, as a new novel needs all the help it can get. Publishers often like to meet a potential author before making an offer.

**Advertising on Trial**

If you worked in an advertising agency in the early 1990s, it might have been a very tough time for you. The economy was in a recession, which was worse than expected. This recession affected many industrialized countries, including Britain. In 1991, Britain's GDP went down, interest rates were very high, people spent less money, over half a million people lost their jobs, and many homes were repossessed. Every business felt the impact, especially the vehicle and building industries, which saw a 30% drop.

Advertising professionals were not the only ones losing jobs, but those who kept their jobs felt a lot of pressure. They were expected to help improve company profits and were closely watched by their colleagues and bosses. They also had to do more work with smaller budgets, being told that "less must be more."

Despite these challenges, the importance of marketing was growing. Companies started to focus more on making products and services that customers actually wanted, rather than just what was easy for them to produce. This shift meant that marketing activities received more attention from management, and some brands began to be marketed more effectively. This increased the status of marketing professionals but also added to their responsibilities. Marketing was seen as a solution to many problems, even though it wasn't always the answer.

About half of most marketing budgets were spent on advertising, so advertising professionals felt the pressure. The 1980s were a great time for advertising, but the early 1990s were tough. The recession made companies review and often cut their advertising budgets. They also started questioning the value of advertising, wanting to know exactly what they were getting for their money.

Advertising was under scrutiny, and companies wanted better strategies, targeting, creativity, media placement, and thinking from their advertising agencies. They wanted the best people working hard to produce outstanding work.

Advertising professionals faced the same problem as their clients: doing more with less. The recession made it hard to produce effective advertising. There were also other challenges, like demographic changes, the power of retailers, changing consumer needs, the rise of sponsorship, stricter legal restrictions, and the challenge of advertising abroad.

These issues forced advertising professionals to reconsider how effective their work was. They needed to make sure more of their advertising was successful. However, finding help to improve was difficult. Companies and agencies were too busy dealing with these challenges to share their strategies, and those who succeeded wanted to keep their secrets. Conferences and seminars offered some help, but books on advertising often didn't provide practical advice. They sometimes made advertising seem more perfect than it really was, which didn't help those responsible for making it work.

**The Lure of the Kitchen**

When I was at university, I decided I wanted to be a chef. This was not a common choice among my friends. Cooking was not a popular job that many of us wanted. Being a chef seems difficult: the work is long, stressful, and not well-paid. But these things didn't stop me. I was unhappy at university. The studies were hard, and the social life felt closed and self-important. Being a chef seemed like the perfect way to escape from this. It offered a seriousness and honesty that I felt was missing in my college life. But my wish to cook was not just because I was a student. It also showed my love for beauty and art. I first saw this when I ate at a famous restaurant in London. It was amazing. I still remember my starter. After that meal, I wanted to thank the chef who made it. I felt happy and light for days. After this, I really wanted to learn the secrets of this wonderful art. I changed my student life to prepare for my future in cooking. My history degree felt empty, taking me away from my real goal. I learned about cooking by reading cookbooks, visiting markets and delicatessens, and making fancy meals.

**The Swimming Instructor**

The school's swimming teacher was a former drill sergeant, small and muscular, with tattoos on his arms. When I asked him to teach me how to dive, he told me to sit on the pool's edge, put my hands above my head, and roll forward, pushing off with my feet. I practiced this move until the lesson was over. The next time, he had me stand up and dive off the edge. The instructor was very strict, and every time I came up from the water, he looked at me with disapproval: 'Don't look down, look up!' 'Keep your legs straight.' 'Point your toes, I said!' The next week, I went up onto the high diving board. It was a fixed board, and its front edge bent slightly downward. It seemed very high as I stood there, trying to gather my courage. Slowly, the echoing voices disappeared, and I felt like I was in silence. I moved my arms as I had been taught, tried to look up, not down, and jumped into the air. For a brief moment, I felt like I was flying. When I hit the water, I fell awkwardly, and my legs were everywhere. The instructor looked at me with contempt and shook his head. But even he could not take away my happiness. That's what they mean by 'free as a bird', I thought.

**The Traveller**

For those of us who value a comfortable bed, running water, and the chance to live at least until tomorrow, the idea of the traveller is both confusing and interesting. These are people who are drawn to the unknown, who choose to risk their lives by climbing dangerous mountains covered in ice and snow; who sail alone in small boats through huge waves; who will eat insects if there is nothing better to eat, and who can live for months in the unknown. It is easy to see these people as strange - and they are - like hermits, freefall divers, or writers. They exist, but their unusual world is far from our everyday life and can be ignored, we tell ourselves. We can be thankful for our world of microwave ovens and phones, happy that the only risks we face are predictable ones, like crossing a busy street.

**Sailing**

Jonathan Raban is afraid of the sea, saying it is not his natural place, which is probably why he spends so much time on it. He does not claim to be a top sailor, though he is clearly a skilled one. His main reason for sailing is that, as a writer, he likes to write about his sailing experiences. Sailing gives him exciting stories to write about. Raban's small boat has an electronic device that tells sailors their exact position anywhere on Earth. While he likes this tool, Raban has a simple view of other sailing aids. He thinks the invention of the compass was a mistake, causing a 'big change in the relationship between man and sea'. Raban believes that since the compass was invented, about a thousand years ago, it has become the main focus for sailors, so they no longer study the waves and feel the sea. The ocean, once full of life, is now just a space. Since the sailor's job is just to stay on course, he can be replaced by an autopilot for long periods. This may be why Raban had time to look so closely at the waves.

**Holiday Reading**

Summer gives us two great joys: leaving home and reading books. These joys are closely connected. Books help us feel more at home in the world. We can relate our experiences to those in books written long ago or in faraway places because there are fewer types of people than there are people. In books, we find our own thoughts, embarrassments, and dramas. Authors can describe situations we thought we were alone in feeling, or express our thoughts with clarity and accuracy that we can't. What was shy and confused in us is clearly expressed in their words, which is even more impressive if the book was written by someone from a different place or time. We feel thankful to these authors for reminding us of who we are. Through reading and travel, we escape the dullness of routine. Our eyes are most open during our first days in a new place, or when reading a great book, which shows us interesting things we ignored before. Our mind becomes like a radar, noticing things we didn't see before, like the colors of the sky, the changes in a face, a friend's hypocrisy, or a hidden sadness about a situation we didn't know we could feel sad about.

**Author's Note**

These travel reflections were published as articles in the Observer newspaper over seven years. I have restored some small cuts made by the editor to fit the page, but I have added very little. I corrected some mistakes, but only if they were details I should have gotten right. I could have made more improvements, but that process would never end. For example, in the second article about China, it seemed likely at the time that the Hong Kong dollar would stay strong, but a year later it fell. If I rewrote the piece to predict this, it would seem like I knew the future, which I didn't. Like any traveler, I was there at that moment, not knowing what would happen next, and trying to understand what had already happened. This is the real story of mass air travel: the world opening up to people who only need a ticket to explore it. But I believe that not all travelers are blind. Even a postcard can have a purpose.

**Ecotourism**

If there were awards for tourism phrases that have been overused, 'ecotourism' would win. The term appeared in the early 1980s, when people became more aware of the environment, and tour operators realized that travelers wanted to believe their trips wouldn't harm the places they visited. It quickly became a popular marketing term. Now, the ecotourism label includes anything from a two-week stay with remote tribes to a one-hour motorboat trip through an Australian gorge. Any tour involving cultural interaction, natural beauty, wildlife, or a bit of adventure is likely to be called ecotourism. The original idea was to help people make informed choices, but the lack of rules and a clear definition left many travelers confused about what ecotourism really means.

**Transylvanian Journey**

I lost the notebook from my Transylvanian journey for 50 years, but found it again by luck. It helped me remember that time and write about it, but it wasn't as helpful as it could have been. In Transylvania, I had an easier time than expected, moving from one welcoming house to another, often staying for weeks. When I stopped moving, I stopped writing because I thought there was nothing to record. I was slow to start writing again when I moved on, and sometimes I only wrote short notes instead of a full story. I worried that some details might be out of order when I started writing this book, so I added some warnings and guesses. But then I realized this book wasn't a guidebook, so I let the story tell itself without too many worries.

**Fashion**

Fashion is often thought of as a modern idea, mainly growing because of capitalism in the 1800s and 1900s. However, many fashion historians argue that fashion, in terms of style and design, has a long history. They often start with the rise of markets and trade in the 1500s and 1600s. As societies have become more complex, populations have grown, and new technologies for making different types of clothing and accessories have been discovered, the meanings of clothing have also become more complex. Today, it is hard to say exactly what any piece of clothing or accessory means. For example, a man's suit, which seems to be a symbol of uniformity, can have very different meanings in different situations and to different people.

**Writer**

Newspaper stories about publishers fighting over new manuscripts have given a false idea of what life is like for most novelists. For those of us not at the top of the best-seller lists, there are two ways to make a living. The smartest among us write in the evenings and have other full-time jobs that are secure even if the book doesn't become a hit or a movie. Others, like me, do various literary jobs, such as teaching, running workshops, and writing articles like this one. I've heard of a writing job at a chocolate factory, but I've never gotten anything like that. Somehow, by juggling part-time jobs, using credit cards, and often with the help of the people mentioned in Acknowledgements, the novel gets written.

**Sudden Fame**

The small venues we were performing at around the country were starting to sell out, and extra security was needed to manage the growing number of screaming girls. We had to use secret entrances to the places we played to avoid being mobbed by fans. On the few nights we weren't working, it was hard to leave the house without being chased by followers. In just a few days, we became celebrities. Our fans watched our every move, and our management and others took care of all our needs. Even though I was always shy, this was replaced by a strange over-confidence that only naturally shy people in similar situations can understand. In short, I was emotionally overwhelmed.

**Music - The Challenge Ahead**

Technology keeps changing our lives at work, home, and during free time. Susan Hallam talks about how this affects music in Britain. In the late 20th century, there were more ways to listen to music, like radio, TV, records, tapes, CDs, and videos. But, live music performances and full-time jobs for musicians have decreased. More people can now access music, which meets many human needs. Music is part of every big national event and offers many activities for individuals. A society without music is hard to imagine. The question is not if there will be music in the 21st century, but what kind of music it will be and if people will still want to learn musical instruments.

I believe people will still want to learn instruments. The music industry is a big source of income in Britain, and musical skills will remain important for jobs, especially in media. Besides job opportunities, playing an instrument can help develop skills early on. Research in the USA shows that listening to or making music can improve spatial reasoning, a part of intelligence. Although these results need more proof, studies in Europe show that group music lessons can improve social relationships in school and help children focus, especially those with behavioral issues. Further research is looking into whether playing an instrument can help develop skills that can be used in other areas. For example, regular practice can help with good study habits and concentration, and playing in concerts can teach punctuality and organization. Because of these benefits, there will likely be a demand for music lessons in the short term.

What about the long term? Will there be changes, and what will they be? I think two things might happen. First, people will listen to more types of music, and new styles will mix different genres. Second, technology will be used more to create and perform music, making it easier for people to compose without needing technical skills. However, this might reduce the need for live performances and musicians who only perform live. At the same time, more people of all ages might want to make music themselves, often in community settings that reflect local musical traditions.

To prepare for this future, the music profession needs to change. Instrumental teaching should allow more people to learn different instruments throughout their lives. This will affect the music curriculum and how progress is measured, requiring changes to stay relevant for more people. The curriculum will need to include a wider range of musical skills. Training musicians will be key. They must inspire and teach learners of all ages, work with large and diverse groups, and have communication, social, entrepreneurial, and management skills for community work. This is a big change from traditional methods and will require accountability. Positively, this is a chance for music educators to show the quality of music teaching available.

Finally, we need to raise the importance of music. Music is crucial in our lives but often overlooked. Everyone in the music profession should work together to change this.

**The Actor's Craft**

Actors sometimes face criticism and disrespect. This often happens when they talk about their work in interviews, which can lead to clichés or gossip. They could learn from dancer Pavlova, who said, "If I could tell you, I wouldn't dance it," when asked about her dancing. Paul Scofield, a famous actor, once wrote that acting only has life when it's being performed. Discussing it makes it seem empty and theoretical. Each play is a new start for an actor, who learns and grows with the characters and the writer's insights. After a play ends, the actor feels empty until the next role. This emptiness is often felt in discussions about acting.

**A Review of Hamlet**

Adrian Lester's performance as Hamlet is a mix of youth and maturity. His simple yet confident acting shows he is a top actor. Lester plays a tense young man with hidden anger, using sharp wit and humor that make him both strong and likable. His performance is skillful, even if it seems understated. Watch how his body moves, like it's waiting to come alive. Handy, who plays Horatio, gives a similar impression. This raises questions about acting and behavior: Is acting just copying real life, or is it something more? What gives life to these characters on stage?

**One Director's Approach to Rehearsal**

This director starts rehearsals with a method called "dropping in." The stage manager projects the script on a screen. Actors listen quietly to others and think about the words' effects. When it's their turn, they look at the screen, understand the first phrase, and find the reason to speak. For example, with the line "Queuing all night, the rain, do you remember?" they breathe, let the thought sink in, and visualize the scene. They find the impulse to speak, which the director calls "The pathway to the line." Impulses can come from outside or inside. Actors should look into each other's eyes and consider their character's situation. The director encourages actors to start with an open mind and trust that something will happen.

**The Perfect Theatre**

The perfect theatre should make you feel like your presence matters. Going to a live performance is special, and the staff should recognize that. It's discouraging if the staff treats it like just another job. The theatre should create a connection between the performer and the audience. Everyone should be able to see, hear, and feel involved in the performance. The size and shape of the auditorium are important. It should fit the human voice and body. If the auditorium is too big, it can overshadow the actors. Many theatres from the late 19th century got this right, creating spaces that embrace the stage. Theatres with a sense of history, like worn steps in a church, feel rich with past human presence. You can't please everyone with a play, and you can't predict what the audience will want. When you go to the theatre, you want to see something unexpected and new, or else you might as well stay home.

**Paul Simon**

In the 1950s, rock and roll was mainly popular among young people, but it also had a big impact on middle-class and older people. It helped create a path for the next group of rock stars, who listened to it and felt that this new, exciting music would be important in their lives. For Paul Simon and other young people in the US, the best way to hear this new music was through Alan Freed's radio show, Moondog Rock'n'Roll Party. Freed's show was a must-listen for many future rock stars. Like young John Lennon, who listened to Radio Luxembourg in Liverpool, Paul Simon was captivated by the music on Freed's show. He was ready to move from just listening to music to creating his own.

**Snow**

There was no clear path, but I thought I would be safe if I walked carefully. The wind was strong, pushing me down as I slipped on the ice. Suddenly, the snow beneath me collapsed. I fell into a hole about four feet deep. The snow had formed a thin layer over a gap between two rocks, and I had broken through it. I pulled myself out, feeling shaken and worried, thinking about what I would have done if the hole had been much deeper. I sat against a pine tree sticking out of the snow to think about my situation. In an hour, I had only traveled about half a mile. It was clear that I needed to change my plan.

**Qualitative Research**

There are many books now that try to help researchers with qualitative research. While a lot has been written about collecting data, these books often do not explain how to analyze the data. Many people find the process of analyzing data mysterious. So, we asked different social scientists who have done qualitative research to talk about how they analyze their data. The goal was to share insights and understanding of the data analysis process, not to create a guidebook. This means making hidden methods more clear. Although this seems simple, it is actually quite difficult. We allowed our contributors to present their work in different styles, including personal stories and more formal writing.

**Screen Learning**

A few days ago, I saw my six-year-old eating noodles in a strange way. He was pulling them up with his teeth and trying to look fierce. "I'm a little dinosaur," he said. He was acting out a scene from a TV show he had watched. I asked him what he remembered about dinosaurs, and he didn't remember much. Many people are eager to use the internet and computers for learning, but is learning from a screen really effective? One writer shared his experience with an interactive program he tried with his son. The father read the words carefully, but the son was more interested in playing with the pictures. The father thought that if his son had spent ten minutes with a book, he might have learned something. Television, as shown by my son and his noodles, is a medium that gives impressions and suggestions. Research shows that learning happens best in an environment where there is conversation with teachers or parents. It needs guidance. Using new technology to teach children is fine, but formal education is still very important.

**Hollywood**

By 1918, most of the world's film-making had moved to Hollywood. Local people didn't like it at first, seeing their area of Los Angeles changed by these newcomers. But eventually, they accepted it because of the success it brought. Success in Hollywood is measured by how much money a film makes. Hollywood knows a good film when it sees one: it might make someone a star, but it must make money. In less than a hundred years, Hollywood has grown from a small village to a town as famous as New York, Rome, or Paris. Physically, it has changed a lot: a hundred years ago, you would walk through orange groves to get to the village store. Yet, in some ways, it is still like a village - small-minded, with limited views - just a part of Los Angeles. For those who live and work there, the main topic of conversation is films: how much money they have made, who is dating whom, who has been betrayed, and who is working on which project. Successful people often try to leave: they work there but live somewhere else. Still, it is the place where almost everyone in show-business eventually goes.

**Photography**

Photography was created by 19th-century artists as a new form of art. These artists wanted a lasting and accurate record of what they saw around them, and they found it. The new combination of light, lens, shutter, and a flat surface with light-sensitive chemicals created images that were more lasting, more realistic, and more detailed than what painters could make in weeks or months. This worried other artists, and after their initial excitement, art critics argued that photography was not real art. They said that because photography relied on machines, it couldn't be considered a product of human creativity. Despite the critics, photographers knew they had discovered a new art form, a new way to express themselves. They used their tools like other artists used brushes and pencils - to show their view of the world, nature, and the people in it.

**Book Illustration**

During the time when book illustrations were in black and white, it was common for every children's book to have some illustrations. This also included many novels for older readers, although this decreased as fewer copies were printed. Children's publishing was still very active, but it was mostly done on a low budget, which led to a lot of average work. However, the best artists always did their best work. The black-and-white collection is a mix of ordinary and valuable pieces, a great place for research or browsing. Some of the best works are likely to be shown to the public again, either through reprints of individual books, new publications about the artists, or exhibitions of original books and drawings. There are signs that this is starting to happen, and the process of appreciating this artistic period is underway. Eventually, a smart publisher will see the opportunity to create a series of classic children's book illustrations from this time, either as exact reprints or new editions using the original artwork.

**Blogging: Sharing with the World**

Some time ago, a website warned about the dangers of public check-ins—telling everyone online where you are. The message was clear: you might think you're just saying, "Hey, I'm here," but you're also letting everyone know you're not at home, which might not be safe. This made people realize that sharing too much online can have negative effects. The internet gives us many chances to share our lives with a global audience, offering dreams of wealth and fame. So, we dive into the online world, sharing confessions, photos, and stories. But soon, we find out that this world is crowded and risky, and we can get lost in it.

Feeling worried? Maybe, but don't lose hope. There is a guide to this future, created by a brave group of early internet users. In the early days of the web, they explored these challenges. They lost jobs, made and lost friends, and dealt with the ups and downs of being famous—all before social media existed. These early users, the first bloggers, have already experienced what many of us are going through now. Before we forget their stories, it's worth learning from them. As the saying goes, those who don't learn from history are doomed to repeat it.

In January 1994, Justin Hall, a 19-year-old student, started posting on the "WWW," which was mostly used by students, scientists, and a few young people like him. The web was created at CERN, a physics lab in Switzerland, to help researchers share their work. But Hall saw it as a way to share his life. He created a detailed online autobiography with words, photos, and art. In January 1996, he started a daily blog, and many people were interested in his bold use of this new medium. Hall's rule was simple: if you crossed his path, you might end up on his site; no topic was off-limits. While he was an exhibitionist, his work had a certain beauty that some might even call art.

One day, visitors to Hall's site found it replaced with a video called "Dark Night." He shared that he had fallen deeply in love, but when he wrote about it online, he was told, "either the blog goes, or I do." He realized that sharing his life online made people not trust him. He stopped blogging, but the problem remains. Sharing online is fun, but if you think it will make people like you more, you'll be disappointed.

In 2002, Heather Armstrong, a web worker in Los Angeles, had a blog called Dooce. She sometimes wrote about her job at a software company. One day, a colleague sent her blog to all the vice presidents, including some she had made fun of, and she lost her job. Experts call this the "online distribution effect": the feeling that we can say things online that we wouldn't say in person. But our online and real lives are connected. Ignoring this can lead to big mistakes.

Armstrong's story ended well. Although she was upset and stopped blogging for a while, she got married and started blogging again, focusing on her family. Now, she is a successful "mommy blogger," and her writing supports her family. Once an example of online mistakes, she has become skilled at sharing her life carefully. Armstrong learned an important lesson: just because the web lets us say anything, doesn't mean we should.

**Enough Sleep?**

Many people today feel tired all the time. In busy and wealthy countries, more people are having trouble sleeping and feeling anxious. In the USA, research shows that 40 million people have serious sleep problems. In Britain, some popular books have characters who can't sleep or are set in sleep research labs. People are interested in sleep, its patterns, and sleep problems. A main concern is that people need more sleep. A top sleep researcher says, "People sleep less when they're busy. They wake up early to avoid traffic."

A sleep researcher did an experiment where he let people sleep up to 14 hours a night for a month. It took them three weeks to settle at about eight hours of sleep. This shows they needed more sleep than they were getting.

In Europe, a university in the English Midlands studies sleep. They look at how tiredness affects sailors, how airport noise affects sleep, and the dangers of driving when tired. They find volunteers through student newspapers, pay them, and ask them to change their sleep patterns. Dr. Louise Reyner reassures people who worry about electrodes on their heads. The lab is more interested in physical effects. They have a driving simulator to test tired drivers. Volunteers come in the afternoon after little or no sleep. They drive while answering questions. The road seems endless, the sun is bright, and the air is warm. Many deny they will fall asleep, but Dr. Reyner has videos showing them nodding off. Coffee can help; two cups can make a tired person a safe driver for a short time. Dr. Reyner suggests using alertness products like energy drinks and caffeinated gum, especially for shift workers.

What do we know for sure about sleep? Humans, like other mammals, sleep in a daily cycle. During sleep, they go through four stages, from light to deep sleep. Dreams usually happen in the lightest sleep, and the brain stops the body from moving to prevent injuries. Beyond this, there are theories. Some say sleep repairs the body, restores muscles, or rests the brain. But these might also happen when awake and relaxed, so no one is sure. Scientists are certain that women sleep about half an hour longer than men and that older people need less sleep, but they don't know why.

In the past, people may have slept differently. A history professor found that between 1500 and 1850 in Britain, people went to bed early, woke up after midnight, stayed awake for an hour, and then went back to sleep. This break was a time for thinking, remembering dreams, or even stealing. The poor benefited most from this quiet time. By the 17th century, with more artificial light, the rich started sleeping like we do now. The industrial revolution made most people work longer hours, changing sleep patterns.

Outside Europe and America, the old sleep pattern was common until recently. In some non-western places, there are no strict bedtimes. People sleep for a few hours, wake up, and then sleep again. Continuous sleep is not possible in some tribal societies due to noise, the need to watch fires, and protect against predators. It seems that people everywhere need more sleep.

I was wearing very expensive cowboy boots, each costing 800 dollars, while standing on rocks in the Arizona desert. I had the full cowboy outfit, but I didn't feel like a real cowboy. As I looked at the Arizona mountains in the morning sun, I realized I didn't belong there. I had flown in from Denver and thought I might look like a cowboy from the sky, but that feeling disappeared when I saw a real cowboy at the Phoenix airport. He was wearing a sweaty T-shirt, needed a shave, and was picking up a dirty bag. He noticed my new boots, raised an eyebrow, and left without a word.

I wished there was an outfit I could wear that made me feel like I belonged, even though I was no longer a racing driver. I loved being a racing driver and was addicted to it, but I can't do it anymore. I wondered what I should do next. I thought I had other options, but they didn't work out. I considered being a commentator for races, but there were already many former drivers doing that. I also tried starting a business selling classic cars, but it didn't succeed because nobody was buying.

Being an "ex" anything is tough. People don't want to hear about how I almost became a World Champion. Even if I had been a champion, people would only listen for a short time. I don't want sympathy because I had a good career and made money. But I miss driving those powerful racing cars and the excitement of racing. I miss the attention from fans and reporters. Now that I don't race, my phone hardly rings, and I have a lot of free time.

As I looked at the sky, I noticed there were no buzzards, but there were small birds in a cactus nearby. They seemed to be telling me to leave their nest alone. I realized I had a lot to learn, just like a fake cowboy in fancy boots.

**Vancouver**

In the past ten years, many people from around the world have moved to Vancouver, in western Canada. In the evenings, people like to walk around the city, and if you join them, you will probably hear many different languages. People choose Vancouver because of its mild weather, beautiful location between the ocean and mountains, clean and safe environment, and opportunities for education and jobs. Some people complain about how quickly new buildings are being built, but it's clear that new residents and the growing tourism industry have helped the city grow and improve. Vancouver used to be called 'Terminal City' because it was a gateway to other places. Even though the name is not used as much now, Vancouver is still very much a gateway city.

**Putting Pen to Paper**

Journalists, like me, are often not very good at writing letters. Some say it's because we don't like writing things we won't get paid for, but I don't think that's true. It's more likely because, in our work, we always try to make a big impact, so we lose the natural feeling of writing a letter. Real creative artists, who don't focus on the impact of their words (even if they rewrite a passage many times), don't have this problem. I think the true test of a real artist is their natural understanding of the effect of their words. When Shakespeare wrote his famous lines, he probably didn't think about how the mix of long words made them powerful, but it showed he was a great writer.

**Supermarket Opening**

In the past, opening a new supermarket in Britain was a big event. A soap opera star, a radio DJ, or a minor royal would often come to cut the ribbon. Now, new supermarkets open so often that celebrities are no longer needed. Why pay a famous person when anyone can do it for free? Last week, waiting pensioners didn't care who opened the new Superbuy store, as long as they were first in line. One customer heard that the first five men would get a bottle of aftershave, and the first five women would get flowers. This news spread quickly through the crowd, making those at the front feel proud and those who came later feel envious.

**Citizen Kane**

When the film *Citizen Kane* was finally released in 1941, it faced a lot of controversy. The release was delayed because the distributors were afraid of what William Randolph Hearst, who was thought to be the subject of the film, might do to them. Despite receiving mostly excellent reviews, the film was not a commercial hit. It was television that later made it popular again. *Citizen Kane* is perhaps the most influential film, inspiring many people to become filmmakers. This is surprising because it was Orson Welles's first film. Welles said its success came from not knowing what he could or couldn't do, so he just did what he wanted. He had a great team, including cameraman Gregg Toland, screenwriter Herman J. Mankiewicz, and special-effects expert Linwood Dunn. **The Vienna Assignment**

I was in Vienna to take photos. At that time, taking photos was not just my job; it was a big part of my life. I loved how light could change a scene and how one photo could capture the essence of a place or person. I always hoped to take the perfect photo, and as long as I had film in my camera, there was a chance. My routine was simple: finish one roll of film, load another, and keep looking for that perfect shot. This had been my way for a long time.

They put me up at the Europa Hotel in the heart of the old city. I had been to Vienna before with my wife during a busy summer, but this time, in cold January, it felt different. I knew I would enjoy it and take great photos. On the first day, I didn't take any photos. Instead, I rode the trams around the city, getting a feel for the place. The next morning, I was out at dawn. Fresh snow made Stephansplatz look untouched and empty. I wasn't sure how to capture the cathedral in one shot because its spire was tall like a giraffe's neck, but the base was large and heavy. I decided to focus on part of it, hoping to capture something magical. Photography has always had a magical quality, even for the pioneers in the 19th century. Watching a photo develop in a dark room feels mysterious, and that sense of mystery stays with you. That's why what happened at Stephansplatz that morning didn't really surprise me.

Some say that art historians, who focus on theory, ignore the pleasure of looking and the creativity of art. This idea is like thinking that knowing a recipe's ingredients and cooking method takes away from enjoying the dish. Our preferences are shaped by the values of the society we live in. While no one wants to downplay the importance of instinctive responses to art, the idea that intellectual thought undermines sensory enjoyment is an outdated view from a time when art was seen as separate from thought.

**Metals**

Stone Age people might have become interested in metals because they wanted to decorate themselves. Imagine sitting by a river, waiting to catch a fish, when one of our early ancestors found a shiny yellow stone and picked it up. It didn't feel like a regular stone, but it was beautiful. This is how gold might have become important to early people. Gold is soft and easy to shape, so it quickly became a popular material. Copper might have been found by accident too. Once people realized how useful copper tools were, they started looking for copper ores and ways to extract copper from them. This is how metalworking became an important skill for our ancestors.

The reasons they settled in certain places or formed families and communities are forgotten. Archaeology gives us some clues, but we can't test our ideas with experiments on past cultures.
