**Autobiographies**

There is an unspoken agreement between an autobiographer and the reader that the truth is being told. However, this agreement is often not fully kept. Writers might leave out things they find too embarrassing or unimportant. There are also more complex reasons for not telling the whole truth. An autobiographer might think that inventing stories can show the truth about themselves better than sticking to the facts. Or they might decide from the start not to follow the truth. They might call their book an autobiography to make readers believe it is true, even if it is fiction. This can be done without being cynical.

**Dashiell Hammett's Detective Stories**

Experts say detective stories became popular because they reflect the conflicts of late 19th and early 20th-century society. These stories are like allegories. The crime represents human desires like lust or greed, and solving it shows how society can work smoothly again. In Hammett's stories, society returns to its old ways, but it is shown as corrupt. The detective and the criminal are two sides of the same person. They understand each other and are comfortable with each other. The detective is both a crook and a competitor. His mission is sometimes affected by his connection to the criminal, and sometimes his desire to punish is stronger because of this connection.

Stephen Jay Gould is considered today's greatest scientific essayist. To talk about writing, I met him at the Grand Hotel, where he was staying while promoting his new book. Neither of us felt comfortable there. Gould said, "I couldn't write about a place like this. Trollope might, but he knew the culture. Knowing the culture is important for a writer. Science is like its own civilization. Only scientists can present it well. If you don't understand the community and its rules, you can't do it well." One of Gould's rules is to never underestimate the reader. "Don't make it too simple," he says. "You can simplify the language but not the argument. If readers feel they are being talked down to, your piece is ruined."

**Air-conditioning**

At Cannons Gym, a popular spot for City of London workers during lunch, the air feels very cold. This is because the gym has used too much air-conditioning to handle the unusually high temperatures this summer. At quiet times, the gym feels as cold as the Arctic. This is an example of how people often misuse air-conditioning today. It has become a key part of our work and leisure, showing how humans can control or change the climate. However, many buildings with air-conditioning could use other ways to stay cool. They could use natural light and fresh air, and have thicker walls that keep out heat during the day and release it at night. These ideas might seem simple, but they can be very effective and would greatly reduce the need for air-conditioning.

**Sundials**

It is not surprising that as we start a new millennium, people are interested in sundials again. Sundials are tools that tell time based on the sun's position. A hundred years ago, they were important for keeping clocks accurate. But as clocks and watches improved, sundials became just garden decorations—interesting but outdated in our modern world. Now, people are taking them seriously again. David Harber, who makes sundials, thinks their charm is in their connection to the planets. He says there is a magical moment when a sundial starts working. They are calm, romantic objects that remind us of our place in the universe.

**Paint Your Own China**

I used to think china-painting was only for serious, experienced artists. I once saw older women at an arts and crafts show painting teacups with perfect flowers. Their hands were steady, and the paint never smudged. It seemed like they had been practicing for years or had a special talent. So, I wondered who would be brave enough to take a china-painting class. Would beginners also have natural skill? In reality, the class was not intimidating at all. The students were there to have fun, and even the teacher did not want to paint flowers on teacups as quickly and perfectly as I remembered.

Uncle chose a package holiday for Keith and Dawne at a good price: a flight from Gatwick Airport and twelve nights in Venice at the Pensione Concordia. When they went to book the trip, the travel agent told them that the other people in their package were a school group learning Italian. But something went wrong. Either at the travel agency, the check-in desk, or in a computer, a mistake happened. Keith and Dawne ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss, in Room 212, in Switzerland. 

At Gatwick, they gave their tickets to a girl in a yellow-and-red uniform. She checked their details and said everything was fine. On the plane, they were surprised to hear people speaking with North of England accents. Keith thought maybe there was a cancellation or the Italian class was on another plane. They ordered drinks and relaxed. 

When they landed, a woman with glasses told everyone to stay together. There was no mention of an overnight stop in the brochure, but Keith thought it was just a stopover. It was almost midnight when they arrived at the hotel, and they were too tired to question it. The next morning, they realized they were staying there for the whole holiday and got worried. 

The receptionist told them about the lake and the steamer to Interlaken. Keith calmly explained there was a mistake and they were supposed to be in Venice. The receptionist didn’t know about any mistake. Dawne described the travel agent who booked their trip. 

A woman named Mrs. Franks, who they saw at Gatwick, came over. Dawne explained they were in the wrong hotel. Keith said they followed the wrong group. Mrs. Franks explained that many holidays have similar tickets and labels, and it was easy to mix them up. She laughed and said it was impossible to end up in a wildlife park by mistake. 

Keith insisted they were not meant to be in Switzerland. Mrs. Franks left them standing there. The receptionist was gone, and they heard typing. Dawne thought Mrs. Franks seemed kind, but Keith was lost in thought, remembering everything that happened. 

An elderly couple, Mr. and Mrs. Nottage, talked to them, saying they had a great night's sleep. Keith and Dawne left the reception area. They didn’t mention the irony of ending up on a holiday with elderly people when they wanted to escape the demands of the elderly. Uncle had even said so when they tried to convince him to join them.

**He Was a People Person**

American business leaders are now looking up to the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton as a great example of good management. Eluned Price reports.

In Britain, most people know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was and have a general idea of his achievements. However, in America, he has only recently become well-known. The Wall Street Journal once described Shackleton as "an Antarctic explorer whose feats went unnoticed for most of the 20th century," which might be an exaggeration. But now, Americans are very enthusiastic about him. Many biographies and stories about his famous voyage on the ship Endurance are being written and are expected to sell quickly. The American Museum of Natural History is planning a big exhibition, and Columbia Tristar is making a movie about Shackleton's life.

Some American managers have started to see Shackleton as a role model. They admire his actions and learn lessons about leadership and communication from his story. They even use the term "speaking Shackleton" to describe their approach. Shackleton, known for being determined and resourceful, has become a model for modern management consultants.

Jim MacGregor, a managing partner at Abernathy MacGregor Frank in New York, has been inspired by Shackleton for years. His company deals with communication during mergers, acquisitions, and corporate crises, like when a company's plant explodes or when many employees have to be let go. MacGregor believes Shackleton is a great example of leadership and communication. Shackleton was at his best when he and his team had a lot to lose, like their lives. One of his most important decisions was to turn back when he was only 97 miles from the South Pole in 1908. This decision showed his credibility because he prioritized the lives of his men.

In a crisis, MacGregor says, people want to know someone is in charge. Unlike many managers today who avoid responsibility, Shackleton was ready to take charge. His 1914 expedition became legendary. His ship, the Endurance, was trapped in ice for nine months and eventually crushed. Shackleton told his men they would reach safety if they trusted him and did their best. From their diaries, it's clear that Shackleton was always in control.

Shackleton planned for every situation, kept his men informed, and asked for their opinions. He was flexible and ready to start over if needed. MacGregor's company uses Shackleton's story to teach principles that clients can relate to without feeling criticized.

Shackleton believed an explorer needs optimism, physical endurance, and patience. MacGregor notes that in America, people often want quick solutions, but sometimes doing nothing is the hardest but best choice. For example, if you buy bonds and the interest rates change, waiting might be better than selling at a loss. Similarly, if a new product isn't successful, it's okay to stop selling it.

Shackleton led by example. On the return journey from the Endurance, he noticed the expedition photographer, Hurley, without gloves. Shackleton gave him his own gloves, insisting he wear them. He did the same with a biscuit during a previous expedition when they were starving, showing his selflessness.

Caroline Alexander, author of "Endurance," says that the public's interest in heroic stories is growing. Shackleton represents the ideals we long for today, standing out as a true hero.

In the forests of Madagascar, there is a primate called the aye-aye that lives like a woodpecker. Both the woodpecker and the aye-aye search for insect larvae inside wood. The woodpecker uses its beak to make holes and its long tongue to get the insects. The aye-aye uses its sharp teeth to gnaw into the wood and its long, thin third finger to reach and scoop out the insects.

Although scientists described the aye-aye's feeding habits over a hundred years ago, they have only recently learned how it finds insects inside the wood. Dr. Carl Erickson from Duke University studied the hunting skills of some aye-ayes named Nosferatu, Poe, Samantha, and her daughter Annabelle. He wanted to see if they found insects by looking for signs on the wood's surface, like holes where insects might have entered to lay eggs.

Dr. Erickson gave the aye-ayes logs with several small holes. Some holes led to spaces with mealworms, while others were empty. The aye-ayes went directly to the holes with food, showing they didn't need to see surface holes to find the insects. They also didn't rely on smell or sound, as they could find mealworms even when the smell was blocked or the insects were dead and silent.

Dr. Erickson found that aye-ayes could sense empty spaces inside the wood. When looking for food, an aye-aye taps the wood with its middle finger and listens with its large ears. Dr. Erickson thinks the aye-aye uses echo-location, listening for sounds that show a hollow space below. It might also hear insects moving when disturbed by the tapping.

The idea that the aye-aye replaces woodpeckers in Madagascar is interesting, but there are birds like the Sickle-billed and Nuthatch Vangas that also search for insects in wood. The aye-aye is not only like a woodpecker and an echo-locating bat, but it also acts like a squirrel. Its teeth grow continuously like a squirrel's, and it has been seen in the wild gnawing through nut shells and using its long finger to get the nut meat.

**Ordinary People, Ordinary Lives**

Most of us have photos of our grandparents, but do we really know what their lives were like when they were young? Diaries and family stories often give us only small, incomplete pieces of their past. And what will our grandchildren know about us? We often plan to write things down but never do. We might leave videos instead of photos, but they still only show part of the story.

Hannah Renier has a solution: she writes autobiographies for other people. She creates a hardback book of at least 20,000 words, with pictures if needed, telling the stories of ordinary people, not just the famous. The idea came to her when she talked to her family and realized how much of the past was being forgotten. "When I started, I didn't take it as seriously as I do now," she says. "People have interesting lives and want to share them, not just for their children or future generations, but for themselves too. They enjoy the process."

The promise of privacy helps people be honest. A 62-year-old man who made and lost a fortune said, "I was surprised at what I shared. Some things were painful, like my divorce." He did it for his family, hoping they might learn something, but hasn't let his children read it yet. "If they insist, I'll let them. But I'd rather they read it after I'm gone."

Ms. Renier notices that many people repeat patterns from their childhood. "It's amazing how much parents influence their children," she says. "People often marry someone their parents would approve of, or do the opposite to rebel." Many people still feel disappointed about things with their parents, even 60 years later. They try to impress a parent who wasn't impressed, and some want to say, "I can't stand my mother."

Ms. Renier is more of a recorder than an investigator. "It's not for the public, and I'm not there to be nosy. People sometimes share things and then doubt if it should be included. I put it in, and they can decide later. But usually, people want to be honest."

"It's not about showing off. It's about remembering the past. Things are changing fast, and we are losing touch with history. This gives us roots and a connection to our ancestors because families don't stay together as they used to. People want a little immortality."

Each book involves up to 30 hours of recorded interviews, which Ms. Renier uses to write the life story. Modern technology allows her to produce everything except the book's binding. The final product is high quality and costs nearly £3,000, with extra copies at £25 each. She gets about 10 inquiries a week, but the cost stops many people. "I thought it would be more affordable," she says. "But my clients are often wealthy, the kind who might have had portraits painted for their descendants."

**A. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology**  
The Museum of Classical Archaeology has one of the few collections of Greek and Roman sculpture casts in the world, with over six hundred pieces. Remember, none of the sculptures are real; they are all accurate copies made from the originals, mostly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The Museum is in a special gallery with great natural light. Plaster casts have many benefits: sculptures that were originally together but are now in different museums across Europe can be seen together here. You can see almost all the famous Greek and Roman sculptures in one afternoon.

**B. Cambridge Darkroom**  
Cambridge Darkroom is a photography center with community darkrooms and a gallery that shows different photography exhibitions. We often run courses and workshops for all ages and skill levels, including a popular Beginner's Course, a shorter Induction Course, and Master Classes with guest photographers. We have a membership program that allows members to use our darkrooms. We also help young photographers (aged 12 to 16) improve their skills with our Young Members scheme, led by our resident photographer. We sell photography books, magazines, and a full range of photographic materials.

**C. Sedgwick Museum of Geology**  
The Sedgwick Museum has a wonderful collection of fossil animals and plants, rocks, and minerals from all geological ages and from all over the world. It also has Britain's oldest complete geological collection, belonging to Dr. John Woodward (1665-1728), with nearly 10,000 rare and interesting specimens in their original early 18th-century cabinets. Adam Sedgwick, a Professor of Geology, greatly expanded the collections, creating an outstanding museum. The collection is organized by geological age, showing major changes in life on Earth over time. The new Whewell Gallery displays beautiful minerals and gems, with labels explaining their nature and modern use.

**D. The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs**  
The collection has over 400,000 air photographs, taken by university staff over the past 45 years. The University has its own aircraft at Cambridge Airport and takes photos throughout Great Britain. The photos are interesting as they show detailed records of the landscape, including natural environments and human activities from prehistoric times to today. There is a small display in the entrance hall, and the knowledgeable library staff can help with questions. The photos cannot be borrowed, but copies can be bought. These are made to order and usually take about a month.

**E. Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre**  
The Cambridge Brass Rubbing Centre is the second oldest and longest-running center of its kind in the world and is a unique tourist attraction. You can enjoy making wall hangings by rubbing one of over a hundred different brass plates from the tombs of medieval knights and ladies. The center has made resin copies, called facsimiles, to preserve the originals while allowing people to enjoy brass rubbing. Brass plates were an alternative to tomb statues and spread from Germany across medieval Europe and Scandinavia. Many beautiful brasses were destroyed during various revolutions, but most of the remaining ones are in Britain, and the widest range can be seen at the Cambridge Centre.

**From Here to Fatherhood**

**A. The Theatre Director**

I have had 35 years of being around small children because of my unusual personal life, and I have loved every moment. This morning, I fed the baby, and for me, that's what being a father is all about. I'm very lucky with my children. We all enjoy the same things: opera, theatre, books, and music. This creates a strong bond, especially now that they are mostly grown up, and I have become more of a friend than a father. I don't believe in physical punishment. I have slapped my children in anger, but I don't support it. I may not have been the most attentive father, but I have always tried to be available. I'm here if they need me, but I let them contact me. If you start chasing them to ask why they haven't been in touch, you make them feel guilty. My parents did that to me, and I would never do it to my children.

**B. The Advertising Executive**

I was young when my children were born, only about 25, and I found the responsibilities difficult. It made me feel older quickly, but it also kept me young, which I value. As they became teenagers, they introduced me to music, youth culture, and clothes. This has been very helpful for running the agency. I have never felt out of touch. When they were young, I was busy building my business, so I missed some things like their first concerts and sports days. I'm sad about that, but now I can take them on holidays to the south of France. They get along well with our friends and come to parties and advertising award ceremonies without feeling shy. I think it's an advantage that I do something they find glamorous and interesting.

**C. The Politician**

My first child was born just as I was about to be elected to the Greater London Council, and the others came soon after. My wife and I promised to make time for them, but as I became more politically active, time became a problem. I only accept weekend meetings and public events if there are facilities for the kids to come with me. This way, they know what I do when I'm not with them, and they don't feel like I'm disappearing. I've noticed more MPs bringing their kids to the House. Maybe we are all realizing the need to involve our children in our lives.

**D. The Writer**

My first marriage ended when Kate and Bonnie were young, so I had to think a lot about being a father. I made big efforts to stay in touch with them. My ex-wife and I even tried living next door to each other so they could come and go as they wanted, but I think it was confusing for them. Kate has said in interviews that I was always there for her, but I'm not sure I was a very good father. I was around a lot, but like many parents in the Seventies, I think I treated the kids as adults too soon. Kate recently said we were too liberal. I think I could have been more organized. I regret that now. I still worry about my older daughters as much as my youngest. In that way, your kids never leave you.

**E. The TV Presenter**

I was ready for kids. I was 30, met my wife, and we had a lovely house, so we thought, "Why keep spending money on new sofas when we could have a child instead?" Having my daughter Betty has made me understand who I am. You feel special when you have a child, and you are, but you also become just another parent. It's a great equalizer. Sometimes I feel annoyed, but one look at her and it goes away. A baby's smile is the best way to make you feel better. It can melt a grown man.

**THEATRE CHARLES SPENCER**

A. **Tamburlaine the Great**  
Marlowe's long play about a powerful warrior can feel endless, but in Terry Hands' version, it becomes one of the most exciting shows of the year. He has cut a lot from the original text, making it fast and full of action. Antony Sher is amazing in the main role, doing stunts like somersaulting from a balcony and sliding down a rope while speaking. He captures the audience's full attention with his intense desire for power and glory. A must-see.  
*Swan Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*

B. **Women Laughing**  
This play by the late Michael Wall, first shown in Manchester, is now in London. The first act creates a tense atmosphere as two married couples talk on a sunny lawn. In the second half, the setting changes, and the play becomes a deep and emotional look at the impact of illness. Wall was a promising talent lost too soon at age 44.  
*Royal Court Theatre, London SW1 (0207 730 1745)*

C. **Amphibians**  
Billy Roche, an Irish playwright, brings another play to the English stage. Set in Wexford, it explores the decline of the fishing industry with strong characters, deep emotions, and unexpected humor. The play can feel a bit unfocused but ends with a powerful climax.  
*Barbican 3 Pit Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*

D. **Murder by Misadventure**  
A classic thriller about 'the perfect murder'. Gerald Harper and William Gaunt play writers who plan to kill each other. Although the story is familiar, the plot twists are cleverly done.  
*Whitehall Theatre, London SW1 (0207 867 1119)*

E. **The Alchemist**  
Young director Sam Mendes brings out the best in Jonson's comedy about 17th-century con artists. First shown in Stratford, it works well on the Barbican's main stage, with great performances by Jonathan Hyde, David Bradley, and Joanne Pearce as the tricky trio.  
*Barbican Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*

F. **The Madras House**  
Peter James' production of Harley Granville Barker's comedy about fashion and women's roles in Edwardian society moves to London after success in Edinburgh. The production is stylish, the acting excellent, and the play is an overlooked classic.  
*Lyric Theatre, Hammersmith, London W6 (0208 741 2311)*

G. **Dreams from a Summer House**  
This new musical by Alan Ayckbourn is a charming version of the Beauty and the Beast story set in London suburbia. With a beautiful score by John Pattison, it celebrates romantic love and is a delightful show. London producers should take note.  
*Stephen Joseph Theatre, Scarborough (01 723 370541)*

H. **The Merry Wives of Windsor**  
David Thacker's production of Shakespeare's comedy is almost disappointing, but it is saved by excellent comic performances from Ron Cook as Dr. Caius and Anton Lesser as the jealous husband, Ford. Most of the other actors seem uncomfortable.  
*Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*

I. **The Voysey Inheritance**  
Another major revival of Granville Barker's work, now touring. This play about a seemingly honest lawyer who leaves a corrupt financial legacy to his son is excellent.  
*Apollo Theatre, Oxford (01865 244544)*

**Hide and Seek by Yvonne Coppard**  
Emma and her friends are playing a holiday game by watching a suspicious bookshop. She is surprised to see her Uncle Jim as one of the few customers. He tricks her into a world of lies and crime, using her love for him and trying to separate her from her friends. Coppard creates strong characters in Emma's friends. When Emma's life is in danger, the story becomes intense, especially when she is trapped in the basement of an old house. This book explores family life, childhood friendships, and warns that adults are not always the protectors they should be. It's a powerful and believable story.

**Backtrack by Peter Hunt**  
Two teenagers, Jack and Rill, team up when they discover that their relatives were involved in a mysterious train accident in 1915, where eight people died. The story uses different viewpoints and documents like maps and first-hand accounts to help the reader and the characters understand what happened. It's a smart and complex novel that requires careful reading.

**Pigeon Summer by Ann Turnbull**  
Mary Dyer doesn't fit well into her family or the male-dominated society. She loves her father's racing pigeons, and when he leaves to find work, she takes care of them and wins prizes, despite conflicts with her stressed mother. Set in 1930, this story shows that there are different kinds of intelligence. Thoughtful readers will enjoy this book.

**Yaxley's Cat by Robert Westall**  
Robert Westall tells a chilling story of rural prejudice through the eyes of a mature woman, Rose. She rents Sepp Yaxley's cottage with her two children to escape her materialistic life. A fierce cat and strange items in the house reveal why Yaxley disappeared. The locals become hostile, putting their lives at risk. By the end, the danger is controlled, but Rose is troubled by her teenage son's actions. It's a gripping story.

**Someone's Mother is Missing by Harry Mazer**  
Sam, who is from the poorer side of the family, is impressed by his cool and sophisticated cousin, Lisa, from the richer side. When Lisa's world falls apart, Sam helps her find balance, and they both learn the value of family. The story is a bit slow in parts but has gentle humor and shows the growing closeness between the two teenagers. It's interesting for both boys and girls.

**Stanley's Aquarium by Barry Faville**  
Barry Faville writes with confidence and humor, bringing his New Zealand setting to life. Robbie works as a gardener for elderly Stanley and finds him interesting at first, but later unpleasant. When she discovers what he keeps in his aquarium and his plans, the story becomes a thriller while still exploring character and relationships. It's unusual and engaging.

**Dodger by Libby Gleeson**  
This is a sad story about Mick's troubled personal life and difficult school experiences. The story is told through flashbacks, a teacher's letters, Mick's notes, and a sympathetic narrative. Mick improves his self-worth through a role in a school play and with the help of a caring first-year teacher. It's highly recommended, though it's a tough read, especially at the end.

**Science Defying Gravity**

Journalist Tom Mumford joins students testing their ideas in weightlessness. From the outside, it looked like a regular airplane. The pilot told the young passengers it was a Boeing KC-135 refueling tanker, built in 1964, similar to a Boeing 707 passenger plane. But inside, it was different. The 13 students from Europe and America were about to have an unforgettable flight. The inside was a long white tunnel with few windows, lit by lights along the padded walls. Most seats were removed, except a few at the back, where the nervous students sat. For a year, they competed with other students to join this flight, offered by the European Space Agency. They had to propose creative experiments to be done in weightless conditions. The best ideas won a spot on this unique flight, which was like an extraordinary roller-coaster ride.

For the next two hours, the Boeing would fly like a giant bird, going up and then diving down. The goal was to create a weightless state at the top of each curve. At 3,000 meters, the pilot cut the engines, and the plane continued to rise before gravity pulled it back down. In those few silent seconds between going up and falling, everything inside became weightless. The students would feel closer to the moon than the Earth.

The plane took off smoothly, but soon it was clear this was no regular flight. The pilot made the Boeing climb at a 45-degree angle for about 20 seconds. The engines roared, blood rushed from our heads, and we were thrown across the cabin floor. Then the engines stopped, and we were weightless almost immediately. For 20 seconds, we floated in silence. The floor felt like a trampoline, and one step sent us flying towards the ceiling. We floated aimlessly; directions like left, right, up, or down no longer made sense. Only gravity helps us understand where we are.

After ten seconds of freefall, the pilot pulled the plane out of its dive. Gravity returned, but not as quickly as it disappeared, causing some students to land with a bump. After the first curve, some students felt sick thinking about the 29 more to come. Thirty curves gave ten minutes of 'space time' for experiments. Dutch students studied their robotic cat, Leonardo, to see how cats always land on their feet. They released the device, and one student managed to turn it belly-down using a remote control. However, another student accidentally landed on it during a rough return to gravity.

Next to the robotic cat, a German team from the University of Aachen studied how metal joins are affected by no gravity, thinking about future space stations. Another team from Utah State University looked at making solar sails from thin liquid films hardened by sunlight. They tried to create these films in microgravity, believing that satellites could use solar sails to harness the sun's radiation like a yacht uses the wind.

After two hours of swinging between heaven and Earth, breakfast felt unstable, but the main feeling was excitement, not sickness. This feeling would last a long time. "It was an unforgettable experience," said one student. "I already wanted to become an astronaut, but now I want to even more."

**With the Trees, I Planted My Stake in New Zealand**

**Jonathon Porritt Talks to Danny Danziger**

Jonathon Porritt is the author of *Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology*.

I had a unique time in my life when I didn't experience any summers. I traveled to New Zealand every summer from here, which is winter in New Zealand, so I had nine winters in a row. I enjoyed it because I like winter. My parents had an idea to buy a small piece of land for my brother, sister, and me to take care of. My mother said, "If you plant trees on it, you can have it." This way, we would always have a connection to New Zealand, which was nice since my father grew up there. They found a plot about 20 miles north of Auckland in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land wasn't very good, but it was suitable for planting trees.

I have always been interested in land. I spent a year in Australia working on sheep farms and doing different farming jobs, so the idea of planting trees sounded great to me. I was excited, and the rest of the family became enthusiastic too. We started planting in 1968, and by the end of 1972, we had planted the entire 70 acres.

In 1968, it was a very rainy winter in New Zealand. It rained almost every day while we were planting, and I was often wet and cold. Every morning, I had to prepare for planting again. I would get out of the Land Rover, feeling warm and dry, but the rain would start, and my clothes were still damp from the day before. My boots were wet, and my hands struggled with slippery laces. During this time, I had many thoughts and reflections about life.

In the first year, I worked with an experienced tree-planter, which was helpful since I had never planted trees seriously before. We used a planting bag filled with as many trees as possible. It was heavy at first, but it got easier as it became lighter. The hardest part was getting the lines straight. We decided on the spacing for the trees and used three poles to line them up. Once in line, we planted all the way down and then turned around to come back.

I enjoy hard physical work, and it made me fit. After a while, planting became automatic. I developed a rhythm and used the fewest spade strokes needed to dig a hole. This rhythm is common in many farming jobs, where you train your body to do standard moves, making the work easier. You take the tree out of the bag, dig a hole, plant it, stamp it in, and move on.

Mentally, it was interesting. My mind wandered, and I had many thoughts about the natural world and our place in it. These ideas have influenced my life since then. I've returned to New Zealand four times to see the trees grow, which is satisfying. I feel a connection to what happens to them. I worry when I read about storms or droughts in New Zealand, but the trees are now 20 years old and doing well.

In 1984, I took a break from teaching and went back to New Zealand alone for three months. I wrote my first book, *Seeing Green*, there. I stayed in a simple cabin on the tree farm with just a bed, table, and chair. I wrote in the mornings, pruned trees in the afternoons, and did research in the evenings. I still feel a strong connection to that area. It's the place where I feel most connected to the earth, and it's a powerful bond.

**Bringing Up Badgers**

When one of my helpers handed me a cardboard box, I wondered what was inside. My husband Derek and I have been running an 'open farm' in Somerset for six years, where we care for orphaned animals. The noise from the box was unfamiliar, so I was curious to look inside. I found three small grey badger cubs, each about eight inches long. Their fur was soft like velvet, and they had milky-colored eyes on their tiny black-and-white striped heads. I had never seen badger cubs before. Most are born between mid-January and mid-March and spend their early life underground. If they become orphaned, they usually die of starvation and are never found. These three cubs were discovered by builders who accidentally dug into their home while laying drain pipes. The mother was found dead with her babies still nursing her. The cubs were healthy but cold and whimpering. After removing their fleas, I took them into the farmhouse kitchen and placed them by the stove for warmth. There were two females, Primrose and Bluebell, and a male, Willow. At first, I fed them with a syringe, but I had to wipe them with a warm cloth to mimic their mother's licking. This helped them go to the bathroom. For the first few days, they were fed every four hours. Within a week, they were drinking from a bottle and moving around, though unsteadily. They seemed content with each other for company and a heated pad as a substitute 'mum'.

Three weeks later, I noticed Willow was lethargic, even though he was eating normally. It was a warning sign I didn't recognize, and the next morning, I found him dead. The vet's post-mortem showed Willow died from a lung infection. When bottle-feeding, it's important not to let the animal drink too fast, as liquid can enter the lungs. In Willow's case, this caused an infection that was hard to treat, even with antibiotics. Disheartened by my failure, I continued caring for the others. Then, six days later, a local farmer brought me another male cub, abandoned by its mother. The area had been disturbed too much, and the cub was cold and hungry. We named him Willow II. He was about two weeks younger than the females and difficult to feed. I had to move the bottle's teat around in his mouth to get him to drink. After ten minutes, he would finally latch on as if he hadn't drunk all day. By the end of April, the females were eating creamed rice and then anything. Willow II was different. He gave up the bottle but struggled to eat without making a mess. Eventually, I offered him a sausage, which he slowly ate. After a week of sausages, he was ready for other foods.

At nearly five months old, they were all eating cereals for breakfast, a meat and vegetable meal for lunch, and fruit, nuts, cheese, hard-boiled eggs, and sunflower seeds in the evening. Badgers usually eat 60% earthworms, plus beetles, bugs, baby rabbits, mice, voles, and even plant shoots or roots. My badgers were better off than others that year because the summer was very hot, making it hard to dig for earthworms. By August, the cubs became nocturnal and went for walks only at dusk or late at night. We often walked through the cider orchard, where they played and chased each other's tails. As 'human badgers,' we joined in the fun. I learned to avoid their playful nips, but Derek, who joined us less often, didn't and sometimes got bruised. During these walks, I saw other badgers in our field. They were likely expanding their territory to find food, as badgers are territorial and can kill intruders. We were warned they might enter our badger pen and harm the cubs, so we secured the gate with sheet metal. The local press took pictures of me walking the badgers, and the response was so positive that we started a campaign to build a sett for them on the farm. With advice, we designed a new home for the badgers. Our son Daniel drew up the plans, and we built a sett with tunnels, an enclosure, and a badger gate facing their usual walking direction. It had three chambers, one larger than the others, with a glass side for viewing from a darkened area. As the sett took shape, the badgers explored it before their walks. Eventually, they preferred the sett to walking, enjoying the tunnels and arranging bedding. The building cost more than expected, but a local bus company, Badgerline, sponsored part of it, and local firms donated materials. Everyone wanted the badgers to have a home. One evening, they finally moved in. After watching them for a while, we left them to settle. Half an hour later, I checked on them and saw three badgers asleep in their chambers. These days, I don't walk with them as often, especially since they wake up at midnight. We see Primrose occasionally, as she has joined a neighboring sett, but Bluebell and Willow II still greet us before heading off into the night. This is their territory now, a place they know well and a home they have accepted.

**In Search of True North - and the Man Behind Halley's Comet**

Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, wants to follow in the footsteps of Sir Edmund Halley to study compass variations. Anjana Ahuja reports.

Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. However, one of his important achievements was mapping the 'variations of the compass', now called 'declination'. Declination is the angle between magnetic north and true north. Without knowing this, sailors couldn't accurately use their compasses to find their way across the oceans. Halley, one of the few people paid to do scientific research at the time, set out to map declination in the North and South Atlantic. His first trip to the Cape Verde Islands was cut short due to problems with the crew, but he tried again. This second journey took him to places like Rio de Janeiro and Newfoundland before returning to England. In 1701, Halley published a map showing compass variations in the Western and Southern Oceans. This map was very useful to sailors for over a century until changes in Earth's magnetic field made it outdated.

Dr. Clark, who loves sailing, plans to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's journey by retracing the route of Halley's ship, the Paramore. He needs to raise £70,000 for the trip, and Sir Vivian Fuchs, known for leading the first expedition across Antarctica, is supporting him. Dr. Clark became interested in Halley while working at Halley Station in Antarctica, where he read about Halley's life. Halley was not only a respected scientist but also led expeditions and did research in geophysics. He even helped Sir Isaac Newton with his famous work, Principia Mathematica.

Dr. Clark believes recreating the voyage will give Halley the recognition he deserves. The new expedition, called 'In the Wake of the Paramore', will also have scientific value. Dr. Clark will take the same measurements Halley did, but with more accurate tools. These measurements are important because Earth's magnetic field is always changing. The data will help improve the international geomagnetic reference field, a model of Earth's magnetic field. Dr. Clark explains that measuring the direction of the magnetic field requires knowing true north, which they can find using global positioning satellites. The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments for the expedition. A Danish satellite will also be taking similar measurements, and Dr. Clark hopes his data will fill any gaps in the satellite's coverage of the Atlantic Ocean.

Halley's journey was the first scientific expedition at sea, and he was the first civilian made a naval captain for this purpose. Dr. Clark has the experience needed for this journey, having spent two years in Antarctica and worked in the geomagnetic group at the British Geological Survey. He has also sailed from Rio de Janeiro to England. The expedition will have four stages with different crews. Dr. Clark is committed to the project, saying, "I am prepared to give up my life for eight months to do this, so I suppose some people might think I'm obsessed. But I wouldn't want to sail across the Atlantic again without a good reason. Halley, and his fascinating life, have given me a real sense of purpose."

**POWER DRESSING**

Every summer, the peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their beautiful tails to the female peahens. This behavior puzzled Charles Darwin because, in a world where survival is tough, it seemed strange that birds would evolve such extravagant tails. How do they manage to survive with such a burden?

Zoologist Marion Petrie and her team from the Open University are studying these peacocks to find answers, a century after Darwin's time. Darwin believed that animals evolved through natural selection, meaning the fittest survive and reproduce. However, he thought the peacock's tail was an exception and suggested a different idea called 'sexual selection.' He believed females chose mates based on beauty alone.

Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, disagreed. He thought that if peahens chose the most beautiful males, there must be a reason. Perhaps these males had other qualities that helped them survive, even if humans couldn't see them.

Today, the debate continues because studying peafowl behavior is challenging. At Whipsnade, 200 peacocks live in conditions similar to the wild, providing a unique chance to study them. Petrie and her team are focusing on two main questions: Do peahens really prefer males with the most impressive tails? And do these males have other advantages, as Wallace suggested, or is it just about looks, as Darwin thought?

Observations show that peahens do prefer males with more eye-spots on their tails, which are linked to tail length. These males attract more mates. However, it's still unclear if these males are better in other ways. William Hamilton from Oxford University suggested that showy males might be healthier and free of parasites, but this hasn't been tested in Whipsnade peacocks yet.

This year, Petrie is comparing the offspring of attractive and less attractive males. She wants to see if the offspring of attractive males grow faster and are healthier. If they are, it would support Wallace's idea that female choice is practical.

There's another interesting theory by R.A. Fisher called 'Fisher's Runaway.' He proposed that if a female chooses a male with a slightly better tail, their sons will inherit the tail, and daughters will inherit the preference for long tails. Over generations, this could lead to males with very long tails, supporting Darwin's idea of 'beauty for beauty's sake.'

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**

Tom Cunliffe believes the best boat design should mix old and new ideas. He did this with his own boat, 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London is full of modern yachts with the latest technology. Most of these yachts are based on design changes from 25 years ago. In contrast, my boat is quietly anchored in a tidal creek on the south coast. It was designed last year, but it looks like it could be 100 years old. Some might think I'm a romantic dreamer, but I don't think so. My boat uses the charm of old boat designs, but modern technology made it easier to build.

However, modern technology often protects sailors from the tough realities of life at sea, which is what many seek when they go sailing. I'm not saying sailors should suffer, but I believe boats should have a coal stove for warmth and comfortable beds. But why sail if every sail sets and furls itself automatically? Sometimes, dealing with the sails is part of the adventure. Also, why move the steering from the safe back of the boat to a risky spot in the middle? The sad reason is to create a cabin with more space, like an ocean liner. For me, a boat should be a boat, not a floating house.

When I bought my previous boat, Hirta, for a TV race around Britain, the former owner said it had comfort but no luxury. During my time with Hirta, I learned he was right. Hirta had heavy sails, no pumped water, no electricity, no fridge, no central heating, no winches, and no electronics, especially for navigation. Yet, she was the easiest and kindest boat I've ever sailed. But classic boats need a lot of care. After a back injury, I realized I had to let Hirta go. I couldn't find a suitable new boat, so I decided to build one from scratch.

The Westerman has never let me down. Designer Nigel Irens and his assistant Ed Burnett are skilled with computer design, but Irens first sketched the boat on a napkin. Later, they used a computer to refine the design. They even carved a model, like in the old days. We reviewed the model and made changes on the computer. The final design was perfect. The finished boat has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of six races. She looks timeless, moves beautifully at sea, and her interior, made from reclaimed wood, feels peaceful. This is because she was designed as a sailing boat first, without focusing on furniture. This traditional method works well. The Westerman shows that you don't need to follow trends to be happy and that history can teach us valuable lessons. Made from wood treated with a special glue, she is completely waterproof. She has all the advantages of a fiberglass boat but looks, feels, and sails like a classic wooden boat.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**

Health farms and country house hotels with spa facilities are doing very well. We asked five journalists to visit some of these places.

**A. HENLOW GRANGE**

I was happy to visit Henlow Grange for six days because I was tired and needed to relax. My room in the large 18th-century house was very comfortable, and I felt calm right away. On the first day, I did nothing and slept a lot. From the second day, I joined body conditioning classes and many others like stretch and tone, yoga, and body alignment. The instructors are very skilled. I felt more flexible as the week went on. They offer many treatments, including aromatherapy, seaweed baths, manicures, and pedicures. The one-hour facial made me feel like a new person. The staff in the treatment rooms were very friendly and professional. The atmosphere is full of energy and enthusiasm. Henlow is planning to renovate this year, adding a half-size Olympic swimming pool and a Light Diet Room. You can also ride bicycles around the grounds. If you prefer to relax, you can read a magazine or take a peaceful walk in the garden. During my stay, my mood and appetite improved. I left feeling wonderful and full of energy, which lasted a long time. I definitely want to visit again. This is the perfect break for a stressed working woman. Save Room 5 for me! - Marcella D'Argy Smith

**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**

The calm and relaxing atmosphere of this grand home was clear from the moment I walked up the large staircase to the reception area. The Hall has a beautifully decorated library, a lovely conservatory, and lots of space, so you don't have to talk to anyone if you don't want to. When you arrive, everyone gets a medical check-up, including weight and blood pressure. We were all called patients, which felt strange since I'm healthy. However, I was impressed when a shoulder problem found during the check-up was quickly shared with the fitness instructor, and we worked on it in group workshops and an extra individual session. Each person gets a specific diet to follow. I lost weight without fasting, but I was hungry enough to get a bad headache on the second day. My typical daily menu was grapefruit and honey, hot lemon and boiled water for breakfast; a choice of salads for lunch; and a mix of exotic fruit, yogurt, and hot broth for dinner. If you're not fasting or on a light diet, you eat in the main dining hall, where the food is tasty and nicely presented, so you don't suffer too much! You get a massage or water therapy every other day. All extra treatments are reasonably priced. - Liz Gregory

**C. CAREYS MANOR**

Careys is not a health farm and doesn't claim to be. It's a lovely old manor farm with cozy log fires and a spacious lounge. If you're watching your calories, you'll have to skip the gourmet food. The French chef makes rich sauces and delightful creamy desserts. Luckily, the hotel has a fully-equipped gym and a soft-water pool, so I could work off some of the tempting treats. (You can choose a 'health-conscious' diet if you really want to lose weight.) There is a spa bath, steam room, Swiss shower, sauna, and treatment rooms. A big attraction is the sports injury clinic. I got expert advice on an old, sometimes painful, shoulder injury. The physiotherapist recommended good posture, exercises, and massage. Careys is comfortable and luxurious, relaxed and calm. If you want to explore, there is beautiful countryside around. - Beverly D'Silva

**D. CLIVEDEN**

Cliveden is a grand country home and a five-star hotel that treats guests like royalty. It offers health and beauty treatments, a well-equipped gym, saunas, a swimming pool, tennis, horse riding, and more. There are beautiful woodland walks and gardens on the 376-acre National Trust estate. Waldo's, a highly-rated restaurant, has dishes that are hard to resist. It took me half an hour to read the dinner menu; the choices were amazing. The meal was wonderful, especially the sticky-toffee pudding with banana ice cream. I went to bed a happy woman! The next morning, I spent a few hours in the gym to burn off some calories before my next meal. In the Pavilion, I enjoyed a facial with gentle heat and essential oils, followed by an aromatherapy massage. I thought about the other reports my fellow journalists would write, about fitness assessments, workouts, and beauty treatments to tone and firm the body. Cliveden has all these if you want to use them—before enjoying yourself at Waldo's. - Kay Letch

**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**

The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. It's the best because it's the most delicious I've ever tasted. It's the worst because it's a large piece with 360 calories, which isn't good if you want to lose weight. You've been warned! The second best thing is the amazing aromatherapy massage. I chose the relaxing oils blend, fell asleep twice during the massage, floated back to my room, and had my most refreshing night's sleep in years. The place is modern and purpose-built, efficiently run, with up-to-date facilities and luxurious bedrooms. There are plenty of therapists and beauty rooms, so it's easy to schedule appointments. They offer a variety of treatments, from manicures and pedicures to deep-cleansing facials and body treatments. The guests are a mix of people—from entire football teams to mothers and daughters, best friends, and singles. Ideally, I would take a break here about once a month. - Eve Cameron

**NATURAL TALENTS**

In the seven million years since humans split from chimpanzees, we haven't changed much genetically. We are still more than 98% the same as chimps. On a big evolutionary scale, what makes humans different from animals is a recent change. Our ability to make art and do other things we think are uniquely human must come from a small part of our genes. This is a lot to expect from just a few genes. It's not surprising that studies of animal behavior show that many things we thought were only human are actually shared with animals, just in different degrees. For example, both humans and animals like chimpanzees and sea otters use tools. Chimps use sticks to eat and as weapons, and sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys have simple language with different sounds for 'leopard', 'eagle', and 'snake'. These findings show that there are few absolute differences between us and animals, except for art.

If human art comes from a unique genetic gift, it's strange that our ancestors didn't make art for most of the 7 million years since they split from chimps. The earliest art might have been wood carvings or body painting, but we can't know for sure because those materials don't last. Clear evidence of human art, like cave paintings, statues, necklaces, and musical instruments, only appears with the Cro-Magnons around 35,000 years ago.

If we say our recent creativity sets us apart, how is our art different from similar animal works? Three main differences are often mentioned: human art is not useful, it's made for beauty, and it's learned, not instinctive. Let's look at these claims.

First, as Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." This means human art doesn't help us survive or pass on our genes, unlike most animal behaviors. While human art can communicate thoughts or feelings, it's not the same as passing on genes. Birdsong, for example, helps defend territory or attract a mate, which helps pass on genes. By this measure, human art seems different.

The second claim is that only human art is made for aesthetic pleasure. We can't ask birds if they enjoy their songs, but they mostly sing during breeding season, so they probably don't sing just for pleasure. Again, human art seems unique here.

The third difference is that human art is learned, not instinctive. Each human group has its own art styles that are learned. For example, songs in Tokyo and Paris are different, but people can learn each other's songs. In contrast, some birds are born knowing their species' song. A French baby raised in Japan wouldn't spontaneously sing the French national anthem. Human art changes quickly, unlike animal behaviors. For example, geese honked 2,000 years ago just like they do today, but human art styles change fast. Even a casual museum visitor can tell a 20th-century painting from the Mona Lisa. Experts can often identify when and who painted a work. However, they might mistake the works of two mid-20th-century artists, Congo and Betsy, who were actually chimpanzees. Congo made up to 33 paintings in one day and got upset when his pencil was taken away. Congo and Betsy had a show in 1957 at London's Institute of Contemporary Art, and most of their paintings sold, which many human artists can't claim.

These paintings by chimps blur the lines between human art and animal activities. Like human art, the ape paintings weren't made for practical reasons but for the painter's satisfaction. You might say human art is different because it's meant to communicate, but even some famous human art was made for the artist's personal satisfaction.

Title: A Big Adventure

The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last places on earth that people have not explored. It is also very dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and survived to tell his story. Today, there are not many big adventures or heroes left. In the past, children's stories often featured brave explorers with sunburnt skin and eyes focused on the far horizon as they traveled into the unknown. Nowadays, such people are rare in both fiction and real life. But then I met Charles Blackmore.

Blackmore led a team across the Taklamakan Desert, one of the last unexplored places on earth. Its name means 'once entered you never come out', and locals call it the Desert of Death. He shared the dangers and excitement of this incredible journey from the comfort of his home. His team included four Britons (one was the medical officer), an American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. Surprisingly, the camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were actually long-distance truck drivers. This misunderstanding could have been very dangerous and put the expedition at risk.

This diverse group set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of one of the world's toughest deserts. Charles Blackmore wrote a fascinating account of their journey. At the time, he was about to leave the Army after 14 happy years. He started the expedition for fun, to fill a gap in his life, and to prove something to himself. 'I always thought I'd spend my whole life in the Army. I was offered a promotion, but suddenly I wanted to find out who Charles Blackmore really was, outside of that. It was a big risk. My wife, Tina, was very worried because nobody had ever done that route before; we went into it without knowing what to expect. In the end, it took us 59 days to cross from west to east, and the desert was very kind to us.'

Anyone reading about their crossing might wonder why he used the word 'kind'. The team faced many hardships: dysentery, extreme temperatures, severe thirst and dehydration, and losing part of their precious water supply. 'But', Blackmore explains, 'when we were at our limits and the camels had gone without water for seven days, we found some. We didn't experience the Taklamakan's famous sandstorms. And we never faced the freezing desert cold that could have stopped us completely. That's not to say we didn't face challenges. The fine sand got into everything, especially blisters and wounds. The high dunes were hard to climb for us and the heavily loaded camels, which often fell over onto us.'

'What kept me going was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. Our budget and time didn't allow for one. No aircraft flew over us. Once we entered the sandhills, we were completely on our own. I knew I had the mental strength for the trip, but I was very worried about my physical ability. I remember the first day -- we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot you couldn't breathe. I thought, "We have to do it now!" At that moment, I was very scared.'

If it was like that at the beginning, how did they feel towards the end? 'When you've walked 1,000 kilometers, you're not going to give up. You've gone through so much; you've come so far. We were very thin but strong and muscular despite being exhausted. My body was in great shape, and my legs were like machines. I could walk over anything.'

In the middle of the book, Blackmore describes lying in the desert, looking up at a full moon, and thinking of his family. How aware was he of the difficulty it must have been for them? 'Inside me, there's someone trying to find peace with himself. When I doubt myself now, I think back to the desert and remember that we managed to do that. As a personal achievement, I feel prouder of that expedition than anything else I've done. But in terms of a lifetime's achievement, I think of my family and the happiness we share -- compared to that, the desert doesn't measure up.'

Has Charles Blackmore found peace? 'I long for the challenge -- for the open spaces -- the purpose of it all. We were lifted by the sense of purpose. I find it hard now to be part of the sameness of modern life.'

Life was becoming too hectic for Susan Harr, so she decided to unplug her gadgets and enjoy doing things by hand again. Everyone loves technology because it gives us amazing gadgets that make life easier and give us more free time. However, we've been subtly convinced that technology is essential, and that's okay. But is it really? Using our hands doesn't harm the environment, unlike machines. A recent problem with my word processor, which cost a lot to fix, made me think that gadgets might not be worth the trouble or expense. Are we as dependent on technology as we think? Gradually, I've been letting household gadgets go as they break down. This makes me question what "extra time" technology really gives us. Is it just more time to buy more gadgets? If so, the marketers have tricked us. When my machine started making strange noises, even when unplugged, I left it in the backyard. Now, I'm not stuck to a noisy machine, and I can take my time sewing by hand. I was always a bit scared of electric machines that move quickly towards your fingers. Plus, I can easily take my sewing with me anywhere. Of course, there are some gadgets I wouldn't want to live without. A year without a washing machine showed me how useful it is. But losing some gadgets has been surprisingly nice. We were watching too much TV, so I returned the rented color TV and went back to a small black-and-white one. It's hard on the eyes but makes us focus on what's worth watching. Now, we spend more time walking the dog, reading, talking, or doing other hobbies. One of my hobbies is sewing, and I stopped using my old sewing machine. It's now a plant stand, and I can't afford a new one, so I sew by hand. We've come to believe we can't live without technology, and even if we resist the idea, we don't want to give it up. We feel sorry for past generations who had to work hard without machines. Computers now do amazing calculations and entertain us. But sewing by hand is not boring; it's relaxing. I can sew and listen to the radio or talk with family and friends. If it's a simple task, I can watch TV and feel less guilty about sitting in front of it. It's nice to sit by the fire and sew with a cup of tea. I used to think sewing by hand was hard and tiring, but it's actually soothing and satisfying to see my work improve. Things get done quickly, and life slows down to my own pace. I'm also free from the rush of modern life, where we hurry from one task to another. I've even started enjoying washing dishes by hand, dreaming while I do it. Now, I look around the house and wonder if we really need the freezer, microwave, or electric lawnmower. We could save a lot of money by not using electric lights!

Charles Hurst is a cabinet-maker who creates beautifully crafted furniture. When I visit his workshop in East London, he seems to be in a hurry. He greets me quickly and says, "Well, fire away then!" It's not clear if he's naturally brusque or just shy. His workshop is busy, filled with half-made furniture and colorful planks of wood. Hurst has been making furniture for ten years and has a great reputation. He always has orders for months ahead, even though he doesn't advertise. People know that if they want a good cupboard, table, bookcase, or kitchen unit, Hurst is the person to go to.

Finding a furniture-maker is not hard, but finding one like Hurst, who focuses on clean, simple designs, is rare. Hurst is disappointed by some modern furniture and criticizes mass-produced, low-quality pieces. His quest for perfection and his talent are keys to his success. He is confident in his skills, saying, "I have a huge natural ability." He learned his craft by asking the right questions and learning on his own.

Most of Hurst's work comes from private clients, and some return for more pieces. He finds it satisfying to furnish a whole house. However, he admits that not all client relationships are smooth. He prefers clients who know what they want. Hurst also praises others when deserved, saying there are better craftsmen than him. He criticizes those who take too long to make one piece and those who try to make fashion statements with furniture. For Hurst, furniture should be practical and useful.

Despite his confidence, Hurst is humble about his work. As I leave, he says, "After all, I am only making furniture."

Text: 'Three theories about sleep People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. This suggests that sleep is very important. However, scientists still do not fully agree on why we need to sleep so much. There are three main theories. The most popular theory says that sleep is mainly for our body's health. It suggests that while we sleep, our body repairs any damage from the day and restores itself to full strength. Another theory focuses on the learning benefits of sleep. It suggests that sleep helps us process the information we learn during the day, and without sleep, we would not be able to learn properly. The third theory is about energy. It says that we need sleep to recharge our energy, like recharging a battery, so we have enough energy for the next day.'

**ECCENTRICS**

An eccentric is someone whose behavior is unusual and who does not follow the usual rules of society. This makes us ask, "What is normal?" Most people have their own little habits or interests. It could be a love for entering newspaper contests, collecting beer mats, or writing letters to newspapers about many topics. Eccentricity is about showing our uniqueness. Inside us, there is a struggle between wanting to be unique and wanting to fit in. It's like having two trains on the same track pushing against each other. One train is called individualism, and the other is conformity. For most people, conformity is stronger. We want to be accepted, loved, and feel like we belong more than we want to stand out and be different.

People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often gather together. They form clubs, have meetings, and organize events to share their interests or problems. They look for others who understand them, as their family and friends might see their interests as strange. Being part of a group, even a small one, is comforting.

We all feel a tension between wanting to be unique and wanting to fit in. Even when we follow the crowd, we don't like to admit it. We want to show our individuality, like when someone at a bar says, "I say what I think," or when a new acquaintance says, "You must take me as you find me."

At any time, we can choose to be more individualistic and show our personality. Many successful people have done this. For example, Bob Dylan, the American singer, said, "When you feel strongly about what you are doing and pursue it without giving up, you will surprise many people." But this self-conscious individuality is not eccentricity, at least not at first. When a pop singer wears strange clothes for attention or a socialite makes shocking comments to be noticed, that is not eccentricity. However, if they continue these actions until they become a natural part of who they are, then they might be considered eccentric.

The key to eccentricity is being natural. Eccentrics do not try to be odd; they just are. True eccentrics are not concerned with what others think. They do what they do because of who they are. This makes them different from enthusiasts, practical jokers, criminals, exhibitionists, and recluses. These people are aware of the world around them and react to it. Some want to make an impression on society, and some want to escape from it, but they are all aware of it. Eccentrics, however, continue on their own path without concern for society.

**Natural Books**

We asked four well-known naturalists to share the wildlife book that influenced them the most.

**A Geoffrey Lean**

Choosing the author was easy for me. As an environmental journalist, I've been lucky to meet some of the great thinkers in this field. None impressed me more than Barbara Ward, a small but powerful woman. She was deeply involved in environmental issues in post-war Europe and created her own strong ideas from her experiences. As a young journalist, she helped me understand these complex topics. Choosing her book was harder. It could have been "Only One Earth" or "Progress for a Small Planet." But "The Home of Man," despite its old-fashioned title even in 1976, is her most important work to me. It talks about the rapid growth of cities and the big themes she cared about, like what we now call 'sustainable development.' I've read many books since, but none have matched it.

**B Linda Bennett**

When I read "Signals for Survival" by Niko Tinbergen, I can almost hear the calls of herring gulls and remember the smell of their colony. This book explains the amazing world of animal communication with words and pictures. After reading it, watching a gull colony changes from chaos to a well-organized social system. You can see which birds are partners and recognize families later in the season. Niko Tinbergen was a famous behaviorist who wanted to share his findings with everyone. His work with wildlife artist Eric Ennion in this book was brilliant. Ennion's paintings, based on years of watching birds, show how one gull is aggressive and another is peaceful with just a few lines and colors. This is true art from a field naturalist.

**C Lee Durrell**

"My Family and Other Animals" by Gerald Durrell is the book that influenced me the most. It not only led me to a wonderful husband and a career in conservation but also confirmed my love for nature. I was researching animal sounds in Madagascar when I first read it. I was facing many challenges, but reading this book at the end of the day made everything better. It beautifully combines animals, people, joy, and beauty, showing a world worth saving. Some say humans are the worst because of the harm we've done, but I remember Gerald as a boy in the book, seeing the world as a family. This idea of being connected is something we all need to understand.

**D Bruce Pearson**

I found "The Shell Bird Book" by James Fisher in my school library soon after it was published in 1966. I was immediately drawn to the 48 color plates of birds by Eric Ennion. I already had other bird books and had spent holidays learning to identify birds, which led me to start sketching them. But this book offered much more. Besides Ennion's beautiful paintings, it had chapters on bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and even birds in music, literature, and art. This wide range of information and exciting images made me appreciate birds and nature more broadly. It showed me that my emotional and creative response to nature was just as valid as a scientific one. Since I was better at art than math or physics, this book opened a new path for me.

**DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS?**

We asked five top British publishers if book reviews help sell books. Here’s what they said:

**Publisher A**  
Reviews are very important for publishers. They are the first thing we look at in newspapers. The Book Marketing Council found that most people buy books because of reviews, more than ads, word of mouth, or bookshop displays. Authors and publishers both dislike getting no reviews, but publishers are less upset by bad reviews. They think any attention, whether good or bad, can help sell books because readers want to decide for themselves. Publishers enjoy reviews that match their own opinion of the book since they are often the first to read it.

**Publisher B**  
Publishers and the press both care about book reviews, but they have different needs. Newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books reviewed positively. Book reviews are better now than 40 years ago, but paperbacks are still often ignored. Publishers need reviews because they help make a book and its author known. A good review by a trusted person can boost sales, especially if there are several reviews. Fame helps get books into readers' hands.

**Publisher C**  
Reviews are essential for literary publishing. We rely on them because our books are not by famous authors and we don’t advertise much. Good reviews are more valuable than ads because they are seen as honest opinions. Reviews can help sell books, but they need to be combined with other things like word-of-mouth, support from bookshops, and smart marketing.

**Publisher D**  
In Britain, the link between publishing and reviews is unclear. In the U.S., a review in the New York Times can greatly affect a book’s success. In Britain, bookshops don’t always pay attention to reviews. Sometimes, it takes many years of good reviews for a writer to become popular. Some poorly reviewed books or those not reviewed at all sell very well. Non-fiction reviews often focus more on the reviewer’s knowledge than the book itself.

**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers want long, positive reviews. But do they sell books? I once published a biography that got great reviews, but it didn’t sell because people felt they didn’t need to buy it after reading the reviews. The reviewer’s name used to matter more, but now it’s the surprise choice of reviewer or the quality of the review that can persuade people to buy a book.

The craft of making weathervanes is very old, starting in ancient Egypt. Today, Graham Smith keeps this tradition alive in his workshop. He is one of the few people in the country who make weathervanes by hand. Graham creates unique designs based on what his customers want. "This way, I can make a special item just for them," he says. "Many of my customers are women buying gifts for their husbands. They want something special that shows the man's job or hobbies." 

Traditionally, weathervanes often have a cockerel design, but Graham's first weathervane was a witch on a broomstick, which he made as a surprise for his wife. His friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them too. "I realized there are endless ideas for weathervanes," he says. Graham decided to focus on making weathervanes as a business. He had trained as a precision engineer and worked in that field for 15 years. Then, he and his wife, Liz, decided to switch roles. She went to work as an architectural assistant, and he stayed home to take care of their children and grow the business. That was five years ago, and he is happy with his choice. "My old job wasn't creative, but this is exciting and artistic," he says. "I really enjoy designing."

Graham has now created over 100 original designs. He pays close attention to detail and always gets the customer's approval before cutting the design by hand. He also keeps many traditional designs in stock because they are popular too. "People like handmade things," Graham says. "They like having something a bit different." Graham does not plan to expand his business because he wants to keep it as a small, rural craft. "I have found my place in the market. People love the uniqueness, and I enjoy turning a simple shape into something almost lifelike," he says. "For centuries, weathervanes have helped communities by showing changes in the wind, which affect the weather," he explains. "Now, with more people moving to the countryside, they want to add a special touch to their homes. This has helped crafts like mine."

Graham is getting busier, sending flat-packed weathervanes to clients around the world. Buyers from America and Denmark are especially interested. "The price," he explains, "depends on how detailed the design is." His latest request was for a curly-coated dog. Whatever the occasion, Graham can create a unique gift.

**Beginner Takes All**

Before it was even published, "The Horse Whisperer" was the most talked-about book of the year. It is the first novel by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans, and it has made him a lot of money. Here, he talks about what inspired him and his success.

At the start of the year, things were not going well for Nicholas Evans, who was a screenwriter, producer, and wanted to be a director. His year started badly when a film project called "Life and Limb," which he had been working on for months, suddenly failed. He was very worried because he hadn't earned any money for two years, and this film was his only hope to keep his bank manager happy. A sensible person in Evans' situation might have looked for a job. He could have returned to working in television or started a TV project he had paused. Instead, he made a risky decision. He bought a ticket to America and spent three months researching his first novel.

Even though he was acting on a whim, the idea for the story had been with him for a while. It started when he met a farrier (a person who shoes horses) on Dartmoor while visiting a friend. The farrier told him about a calm horse that suddenly became wild. The owners were desperate until they found a gypsy who calmed the horse just by talking to it. Such people were called "horse whisperers." This story fascinated Evans. He started researching the topic to write a screenplay, as he was a filmmaker. But after "Life and Limb" failed, he decided to write it as a book.

In the spring, he traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses and the people who work with them. "It was a strange time," he says now. "I was watching people, but I was mostly alone and felt like my life was falling apart. I had tried for ten years to succeed as a filmmaker, and now I was in debt, worried about feeding my children, and wondering if it was all a mistake."

By the end of August, he was back home and had written half of the book. "The bank manager was really pressuring us, and I needed to know if it was worth continuing. I showed it to a friend who was a literary agent; he read it and said it was 'fine.'" When asked, the agent thought Evans might get $30,000 as an advance for the book. "I knew how much I needed to pay off some of the debt and keep us going, and it was more than that. I had spent seven months on 'The Horse Whisperer,' and there were at least two more months to go. $30,000 was a tough amount. I was also advised to write a 12-page summary of the rest of the book."

In October, along with the first two hundred pages of the novel, this summary was sent to seven UK publishers just before they left for the famous Frankfurt Book Fair. Within days, his agent called to say he had turned down the first offer of $75,000. "I said, 'You what?' And he said, 'It's OK, I just feel something is happening.'"

What happened next became famous in publishing. Within a week, after intense bidding, the novel was sold to Transworld Publications in the UK for $550,000 and to Delacorte in the US for $3.15 million, both record-breaking amounts for a first novel. "We couldn't believe it; we were shocked. We never sent the manuscript to New York, and we still don't know how it got there," Evans says. They also didn't send it to Hollywood, but soon major studios were competing for it.
