Years ago, these children had visited the factory from their rural school, 50 kilometers away, so Marie's father could show them how he made gloves. He showed them Marie's favorite spot, the laying-off table, where workers shaped and pressed each glove by pulling it over steam-heated brass hands. These hands were very hot, shiny, and stood straight up from the table, looking thin and flat. As a child, Marie was fascinated by them and called them the 'pancake hands'.

Rita asked, 'How many pieces come in a shipment?' Seymour replied, 'Between twenty and twenty-five thousand.' She kept taking notes and asked, 'Do they come directly to your shipping department?' Seymour liked that she was interested in every detail. He explained, 'They come to the tannery. The tannery is a contractor. We buy the material, and they make it into the right kind of leather for us to work with. My grandfather and father worked in the tannery here in town. I did too, for six months, when I started in the business. Have you ever been inside a tannery?' Rita said, 'Not yet.' Seymour offered, 'Well, you need to visit a tannery if you're going to write about leather. I can arrange that for you if you'd like. They're old-fashioned places. Technology has improved things, but what you'll see isn't much different from hundreds of years ago. It's tough work. It's said to be the oldest industry with remains found anywhere. Six-thousand-year-old tanning relics were found in Turkey, I believe. The first clothing was just skins tanned by smoking them. I told you it was an interesting subject once you get into it. My father is the leather expert; he's the one you should talk to. Start him talking about gloves, and he'll go on for two days. That's typical: people in the glove trade love everything about it. Have you ever seen anything being made, Miss Cohen?' Rita replied, 'I can't say I have.' Seymour asked, 'Never seen anything made?' Rita said, 'I saw my mother make a cake when I was a child.' He laughed. She made him laugh. She was innocent but eager to learn. His daughter was at least 30 cm taller than Rita Cohen, fair where Rita was dark, but otherwise, Rita reminded him of Marie. Marie had a good-natured intelligence that filled the house when she came home from school, full of what she'd learned. She remembered everything, neatly written in her notebook and memorized overnight. Seymour said, 'I'll tell you what we're going to do. We're going to show you the whole process. Come on. We're going to make you a pair of gloves, and you're going to watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?'

**Is it a tough job?** Chris Arnot talks to four people with dream jobs to see if they are as great as they seem.

**A. Raquel Graham**  
Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She can't meet me tomorrow because her boss wants her in Los Angeles instead. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she has to travel around the world at a moment's notice. Raquel loves her job and gets along well with her boss. However, she has one small problem - she doesn't like flying. "On a nine-hour flight to California, I usually take sleeping pills to calm down," she says. Her worst experience was flying on Concorde. "It felt so closed in with those tiny windows." When she's not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She has to do some boring paperwork, like organizing the diary, attending meetings with lawyers and accountants, planning schedules, and making more travel arrangements. She didn't apply for the job. She met the manager of a pop group by chance, which led to a job offer. She took a secretarial course in the evenings at the same time. Five years later, she was in the right place at the right time when her boss needed a personal assistant.

**B. David Brown**  
David Brown has been both an accountant and a golf caddy, which is someone who carries a golfer's bags. Overall, he preferred being a caddy because he loves golf. However, there are some downsides. Caddies get a small fixed fee plus a percentage of the golfer's winnings. The average earnings are between £25,000 and £35,000, and much of that goes on travel and hotels. He was 31 when he first worked as a caddy for the golfer Greg Norman. "You're not just carrying bags. You're giving advice, using your knowledge against the weather, and trying to understand the golf course." His skills in accountancy were noticed by European Tour Productions, who made him a statistical data administrator. He collects and analyzes statistics from the caddies' scorecards for each day's play. These results are wanted by TV commentators, golf magazines, and the golfers themselves.

**C. Martin Fern**  
Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' section of a daily newspaper. One of his easier tasks is to try food at the best restaurants. What does he think about restaurants that charge very high prices? "For those who can afford it, it's their choice," he says. "I'd rather spend £120 on a meal I'll remember forever than buy a microwave." His talent as a cook led to an offer to write a food column from a friend who edited a Saturday Review. For Martin, who was then a creative director at an advertising agency, it was a useful extra income. He was 42 when another newspaper offered him a full-time job. "It meant a 50% cut in guaranteed income," he says. "But it was a chance to turn my passion into a profession." He still does all the cooking at home and tries to keep his weight under control by cycling a couple of miles to the nearest tube station.

**D. Dick Prince**  
"I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago," says Dick Prince, one of Britain's most popular children's writers. "Before that, I always loved words and enjoyed using them, but I mostly wrote poetry. Then I had an idea for a story. I had been a farmer and knew the problem of chickens being killed by a fox. So I wrote a story called 'The Fox Busters,' which was my first published children's story." Where do his ideas come from? "Well, it's not easy, I have to work at them," he says. "That's what I usually do in the mornings. I'm not an early riser, I'm afraid. After lunch, I spend a couple more hours typing out the morning's notes - all of which I do with one finger on an old portable typewriter instead of on a laptop. I get between 50 and 100 letters a week, and that's the part of being a writer that I enjoy the most. I try to answer them all, but now I have some secretarial help."

In the lumberyard by the lake, where trees were made into boards for building, there was an old two-story brick building. Around it were big piles of soft sawdust. These golden piles covered the yard all the way to the blue lake. That afternoon, with nothing else to do, Michael and his friends climbed a ladder to the roof of the old building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down," and without thinking, he jumped off the roof onto the sawdust, laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted. "You're all cowards," he said, trying to get them to follow him. Laughing, he watched them from the roof, looking scared, but one by one, they jumped and felt relieved. In the hot afternoon sun, they lay on the sawdust, telling jokes. Then one friend said, "Let's go up and jump again." They weren't very excited, but they all went up and jumped off again, except for Michael. The others were below, calling, "Come on, Mike. What's wrong?" Michael wanted to join them, but he stayed on the roof, nervous and smiling awkwardly, wondering why it seemed so high this time. At first, they thought he was joking, but then they saw him clenching his fists. He tried counting to ten and then jumping, but it didn't work. He tried taking a deep breath and closing his eyes. After a while, his friends started laughing at him; they were tired of waiting, and it was almost dinnertime. "Come on, you're a coward. Do you think we'll wait all night?" they shouted. When he didn't move, they started to leave, still shouting. "Who started this? What's wrong with you?" he called. But he stayed on the roof, looking sadly at the ground. He was alone for almost an hour as the sun, like a big orange ball, slowly set beyond the lake. His clothes were wet from sweating nervously. Finally, he closed his eyes, slipped off the roof, fell heavily on the sawdust, and lay there for a long time. The yard was quiet; the workers had gone home. As he lay there, he wondered why he couldn't jump earlier. Then he got up slowly and walked home, feeling very ashamed and wanting to avoid everyone. He was so late for dinner that his stepmother said coldly, "You're old enough to come home on time. If you can't, you should stay in tonight." She was a strong woman with fair skin, a little grey in her hair, and a patient smile. She spoke with controlled seriousness, but Michael, feeling gloomy and miserable, barely heard her. He was still thinking about his friends laughing at him.

**Careers Advice**

Are you unhappy with your job but unsure how to change it? Kitty Doherty offers some helpful advice. Many people who want to change jobs are now turning to careers advisers. These advisers ask you to write a short history of yourself and take some tests called 'psychometrics'. After the tests, they give you a summary of the results and suggest different careers, along with any retraining you might need.

I decided to try Career Analysts, a big company that offers career advice. Taking the careers test felt like being back in my science exams. I was with about ten other people, answering questions quickly. I had to remember that it wasn't about passing or failing. The tests included finding mistakes in lists of names and numbers and matching similar shapes. After the tests, I had a long talk with an adviser. Using the test results and our conversation, he wrote a report with his observations and recommendations. I agreed with most of his conclusions, although I was a bit upset to learn I didn't do well in the scientific, technical, and practical tests. It's probably good that I never became a nurse. However, it was comforting to hear that I made the right choice in becoming a journalist.

Changing your career doesn't always mean a big change. Last March, Donna Laney, 25, lost her job as a marketing manager at a large insurance company after five years. Her friends suggested she visit Career Analysts for help. 'Losing my job was a great chance to step back and review my career,' says Donna. Some results surprised her. 'I didn't know I had a talent for design. But I had to consider the cost of retraining in design against my financial needs,' she says. Other ideas included taking a year off to work in the Far East. 'I decided to use my existing skills and move into something better suited for me than insurance. Now, I work as a Public Relations officer. I might have reached this point without Career Analysts, but they helped me see clearly what I wanted to do. I've recommended them to several friends, who are all happy with the service.'

Some people feel they wouldn't have reached their goals without help. A visit to Career Counselling Services led 26-year-old Juliet Greene to make big life changes. 'After working for a major bank for six years, I found my job boring and needed a new challenge. I didn't know what I wanted to do, so I went to Career Counselling Services with an open mind. The tests showed I was interested in sciences,' she says. 'I had four sessions with an adviser. The third session was recorded, which was helpful because you forget many things you say. After the fourth meeting, I decided to study geology and plan to start a degree course in it later this year. The advice from Career Counselling Services was worth the fee. I'm much happier now and more positive.'

However, careers advice doesn't work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, a 24-year-old sales representative, says: 'I reached a point in my career where I didn't know what to do next. I thought a careers adviser might suggest something new. Although I got many new ideas, I rejected them because they required a big salary cut or a lot of retraining. I didn't learn anything new about myself,' she says. 'You have to give the adviser a lot of personal information, and I felt that if I had told a friend the same things, they would have given me similar advice.'

Title: 'Enjoying Your Visit to the Dentist?'

If you visit W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in Glasgow, you'll notice bright paintings on the walls and a stylish blue couch where patients sit during their check-ups. Jerome explains that half of the people only visit the dentist when they are in pain because they are scared. To change this, he has created a friendly environment to help people feel less afraid. He doesn't wear a white coat because he believes it reminds people of pain. Jerome thinks dental visits should be relaxing, interesting, and even enjoyable.

This idea might surprise many people who usually think of dental visits as painful or very formal. Jerome believes that if patients are relaxed and entertained, they will forget their past bad experiences. One of his new methods is using virtual-reality headsets. His practice was the first in Britain to use them, and they are very popular. During the first check-up, patients sit on the blue couch and watch a film about underwater wildlife while Jerome examines their teeth. Then, the headset shows a camera view inside their mouth, which most patients find interesting.

Another important feature of Jerome's office is the pleasant smell, like a perfume shop, instead of the usual dental smell. Today, it smells like oranges. Jerome says he wants people to use all their senses to realize that his office is different from a typical dentist's. He believes smell is important because the usual dental smell can make people nervous.

Although Jerome is known as a fashionable dentist, he takes his work seriously. Relaxation is important, but the quality of treatment is the most important. For example, he uses a special tool that sprays warm water to clean teeth instead of scraping them. It might feel strange at first, but it doesn't hurt if you are relaxed.

Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to learn about new dental techniques. He discovered that making things easier for patients also makes it easier for dentists. He believes his patient-focused approach is the beginning of a change towards less formal dentistry in Britain.

As a patient arrives, Jerome greets him, offers tea (herbal or regular), asks what video he would like to watch, and gently leads him to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this special treatment, and it's easy to see why. Jerome's office feels more like a fancy beauty salon than a regular dental practice.

Title: The Rise of Chocolate

Chocolate, which started in South America, is now a huge global business. In the UK, people spend over £230 million on chocolate during Easter. Eight percent of all chocolate is bought at this time, with only Christmas seeing more chocolate consumption. 

Chocolate production on a large scale began in the last century, but the cacao plant was first grown by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan civilizations in Central America over 3,000 years ago. The cacao tree is a tropical plant found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and Southeast Asia. Its fruit is the size of a melon and contains 20-40 seeds. When dried, these seeds become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, they are often called cocoa beans due to a spelling mistake from the 17th century.

The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money and to make a drink called xocoatl, meaning 'bitter water' in their language, Nahuatl. This drink was flavored with spices and used in ceremonies and to welcome guests. The Spanish liked it better with cinnamon and sugar, but it took another century for the recipe to spread across Europe. In the late 17th century, chocolate houses opened in Europe's capital cities, where people gathered to drink chocolate.

Until the last century, chocolate drinks were made from solid blocks of chocolate melted in hot water. In 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands invented chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from the beans. The chocolate bar as we know it started in 1847 when Fry and Sons, a company in Bristol, mixed cocoa butter with pure chocolate liquor and sugar to make a solid block you could eat. Later, a Swiss company added milk solids, creating milk chocolate.

At the start of the 20th century, French companies dominated the British chocolate market. In 1879, the English company Cadbury named their factory Bournville, hoping to add some French style. But Cadbury's Dairy Milk bar, first called Dairymaid in 1905, became popular with clever advertising linking it to the healthy milk from the English countryside. This made it a strong competitor to the French brands.

Today, chocolate consumption in Britain is about four bars each week. This has led manufacturers to find new ways to attract customers, like turning chocolate bars into ice creams, soft drinks, or desserts. Meanwhile, cacao farmers are still affected by a drop in cocoa bean prices from the late 1980s. Many small-scale farmers went out of business. So, next time you enjoy a chocolate bar, think about the farmers who grow the cacao.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**

Peter Cooke, at 83 years old, has become very skilled in his art. He still wants to try new things like making paper and working with feathers. But for now, he focuses on creating delicate and unique objects from shells, a skill he has perfected over the last ten years. 

As he shows me around his apartment, he says, "Tell me if I am boring you." However, Peter is not boring at all. He is enthusiastic, charming, and his work is beautiful. He points to some shell-covered ornaments above his fireplace and says, "I won't mind if people don't buy them because I love them. I never planned to sell my work. About five years ago, some friends visited and said, 'You should have an exhibition. People need to see these. We'll talk to an art gallery owner.'"

This led to an exhibition in London, where 70% of his pieces were sold. His second exhibition opened yesterday. The pieces are expensive, with some ornaments costing around £2,000. There are 86 pieces in the exhibition, with prices starting at £225 for a shell-flower in a crystal vase. Peter says he doesn't set the prices and is open about them. He believes no one else in the world makes work like his. The gallery owner told him, "One day you'll stop, and everyone will want your pieces because there won't be any more."

Peter wishes he had started this art earlier in life. He feels he could have created even more amazing things. Although he still has ideas, he finds himself more physically limited now than when he began. Despite this, his work is far from the typical shell crafts found in seaside shops. He describes himself as having a "miniature mind," which has led to creating boxes covered in tiny shells, small pictures made from shells, and baskets of realistic flowers.

Peter has developed his own method and uses materials he finds. He uses cardboard from laundered shirts for flower bases, a special glue from a sail-maker, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. He says, "I have an idea of what I want to do, and it just does itself," but the detail, color, and symmetry in his work show it is not accidental.

His search for beautiful, especially tiny, shells has taken him beyond the Norfolk shore to places like France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He insists he only collects dead shells and defends himself against accusations of harming beaches. "When I collect shells, I hear people crushing them with their feet faster than I can collect them; and the sea breaks up the rest. I would never collect shells with living creatures in them or dive for them, but once they are empty, why shouldn't I collect them?" His argument is convincing, especially when considering the beauty of his work compared to the natural shells.

**The Schoolgirl Model**

When 15-year-old Kira Langer isn't traveling to amazing places and appearing on magazine covers, she's probably studying for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw learns more about her.

"I'm sorry, Kira will be a little late," the receptionist at the agency told me. "Oh, fine," I said, "no problem." I was trying to ignore all the negative things I had read about models, like being difficult, vain, and unintelligent. And now she was going to be late. How late? An hour? Three hours? Maybe she wouldn't come at all. What if she decided going to the hairdresser was more fun than talking to me? If she was late, she might be in a bad mood and refuse to answer my questions.

But when Kira, the winner of the Looks magazine supermodel competition, walked in, she was smiling, relaxed, and apologetic, and she was with her mother. Kira wasn't wearing expensive designer clothes, just a simple black dress and trainers. She didn't seem selfish at all; she was just a very friendly, very tall, very pretty girl. All models under 16 must have an adult with them when they work, she explained. Her mother looked like a normal mum, very proud of her successful daughter.

Kira seems a bit surprised by her new fame, which makes sense since it was unexpected. Her older sister was the one who decided she should enter the model competition. "She saw the competition and said I should go in for it," Kira remembers. "I said no, but she sent some photos in anyway." When she got the call saying she was a finalist, she was at school. Being chosen for the final gave Kira the confidence to go through with it, and she did great. She won easily, and the Select model agency in London quickly offered her work.

Kira now finds it hard to balance her two separate lives. But her friends and teachers are used to having a star among them. "They're really proud of me," she says. However, some unkind people at her school are rude about her success. "They say I have too high an opinion of myself." This must be hard for Kira, as she is not self-important. But she says, "They think that because I've become a model, I can't stay the same. But the only thing that's changed is I've become more confident—not in a bad way, but I can stand up for myself more."

As a busy model, her social life is affected. The Select agency can call anytime and tell her she has a job the next day. "If my friends are going out, I can't say I'll come because I don't know what I'm doing the next day. I can't really make plans, and if I do, they sometimes get canceled, but my friends are good about it. They don't say, 'Oh, you're always going off modeling now, you never have time for us.'"

Kira has the looks, ability, and support to have a great career ahead of her. Not many people can say that before they even finish their school exams. As I finish the interview with the girl who has it all, I ask what she would like to do if she didn't have the beauty that seems sure to take her to the top of the profession. She pauses and replies, "I'd like to do what you're doing."

Father and Son Start Gold Rush

Terence and Chris Madden have traveled from Canada's cold north to Africa's heat to find valuable metals. Terence, an explorer, and his son Chris, a mineral expert, think their mine on a Welsh mountain might have up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging in the Welsh hills, they believe they are very close to finding a gold vein worth five million dollars. Terence, 68, from Liverpool, said, "As we dig, we find a lot of gold; we just need to dig a few more meters to reach where it is concentrated."

The Maddens have spent their lives searching for gold. Their journey began when Terence read about gold worth millions in the "Dolgellau gold belt," an area near the Welsh town of Dolgellau. They studied 19th-century mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth to choose the best area to explore. After clearing the land and finding small pieces of gold in the rocks, they spent ten years getting permission from landowners, taking earth samples, and removing old cars and rubbish. They dug out 150 tonnes of greenstone rock to make a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft.

Now, they are running out of money. They have used their savings to follow their dream and need to find someone to invest £50,000 to dig a few more meters to reach the gold. Chris Madden says, "Right now, it seems difficult, but we have some people we can contact."

As news about the dig spread last week, the idea of finding gold excited both locals and gold diggers. Dolgellau depends on tourists, and residents are hopeful. Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, said, "It would bring more people here if they are right, but if they find gold, I hope millions won't come and dig up the hillside."

The Welsh gold industry has declined since the late 1880s when many people worked in hundreds of mines. One of the last mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed a month ago. However, individual gold diggers are coming back. George Hall, another prospector, plans to dig a tunnel on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens. Hall, 70, said, "Searching for gold is very emotional. It's adventurous and exciting, like finding hidden treasure. Maybe I'll be lucky this time."

Rachel Mills is a scientist who loves exploring the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She works at Southampton University, where she teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which is the study of chemical processes in the sea. When she's not teaching, she goes on dives in a small steel vehicle, about the size of a car, to explore underwater volcanoes three kilometers deep in the ocean. Inside the vehicle, space is very tight, and she can easily touch the two pilots. They are used to these cramped conditions, where they can't stand or move much, and they have to stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface. If there's an emergency, they can press a panic button to release a small escape vessel that quickly rises to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. However, no one has tested this yet, and it might not be a pleasant experience.

Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. She was on a ship's deck with an instructor who explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would handle being in such a small space. Now, Rachel has completed six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian team to a site five days' sail west of the Canary Islands. There, on the ocean floor, is a large area of underwater volcanoes with chimneys releasing black smoke. The Russian team was setting up scientific equipment to study the effects of a project that would drill a 150-meter hole through a volcano.

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. She spends two-thirds of her time teaching, which she enjoys, but she does it to support her research on "black smokers," another name for underwater volcanoes. These volcanoes release water that looks like black smoke at a speed of one meter per second and a temperature of 350 degrees Celsius.

Rachel recalls being scared once when she was diving with an American team. They were towing equipment on a 50-meter rope when there was a sudden explosion. The shock waves hit their vehicle, and she thought she was going to die. They waited in silence, and when nothing happened, they were incredibly relieved to be alive.

Diving to the deepest parts of the ocean is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she looks out of the porthole and sees the chimneys, she feels a sense of wonder. She is at the bottom of the sea, seeing something no one else has seen before. After studying the black smokers for three years for her PhD, seeing them in person was an amazing experience.

I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and somewhere under all that, suntanned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body couldn't take any more stress. My mind couldn't handle any more foreign schedules, money, or languages. "Never again," I said, as I stepped onto home ground. I said the same thing the next year. And the year after that. All I had to do was buy one train ticket, and because I was under twenty-five, I could spend a whole month traveling anywhere I wanted in Europe. Once you've learned to sleep in a train corridor, regular beds never feel the same. The train's rhythm rocks you into a deep sleep. Carrying all your things in a backpack makes you travel simply and can lead to throwing away socks that are too smelly and getting rid of books when you're done with them. This way of thinking fits the spirit of Inter-Rail, where common sense and reasoning can be ignored, just like the paperback book and the socks. All it takes to feel this free is one of those tickets in your hand. Any system that lets young people travel through countries at a rate of more than one a day must be pretty special. On that first trip, my friends and I didn't realize the possibilities of this train ticket at first. We thought it was just a cheap way to get to and from our chosen campsite in southern France. But the idea of non-stop travel was too tempting because there was always just one more country over the border, always a little further to go. And what did the extra miles cost us? Nothing. We were not completely uninterested in culture. But this was our first holiday without parents, as it was for most other Inter-Railers, and in planning our own schedule, we left out everything except the most easily available sights. This was a chance to escape the guided tour, an opportunity to do something different. I was proud that, in many places, all I bothered to see was the view from the station. We were just there to get by and have a good time doing so. In this, we were no different from most of the other Inter-Railers with whom we shared corridor floors, food and water, money, and music. The excitement of travel comes from the sudden reality of a place that was just a name before. It's as if the city you arrive in never really existed until the train pulls into the station and you see it with your own tired eyes for the first time. Only by actually seeing Europe, by watching the changing landscapes and noticing the differences in attitudes and lifestyles, can you really have an accurate picture of the continent in your mind. Everyone knows what's there, but it means nothing until you see it yourself. This is why other people's holiday photos are so boring. While the train trip won't let you discover anything new in the world sense, it is a valuable personal experience. Europe is a big place, and Inter-Rail gives people the best chance to realize this, though in our case, it didn't happen immediately.

There is nothing more frustrating than arriving at an airport in another country and finding out that your baggage has been left behind. At best, you will have to wear the same clothes for hours or days until the airline returns your luggage. At worst, you might be in a different climate, far from home, and have to wear clothes that are not suitable. Airlines don't often say how many bags they lose, but regular travelers know that losing luggage happens sometimes. Even the best airlines make mistakes, and no airline can promise that your checked luggage will always be on the same flight, especially if you have to change planes. 

Here's how the system works: Airlines ask passengers to check in early to give enough time for baggage to go through the airport and be loaded onto the plane. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are the shortest times needed to transfer between flights, and these are also set to allow for baggage transfers. Usually, the system works well. But extra security checks and air traffic problems can delay flights, which can cause the baggage system to fail. Human error or accidents, like a torn-off destination label, can also cause problems. These issues can be worse at large transfer airports, called 'hubs', because they handle many bags. For example, last year, London's Heathrow airport handled over 41 million passengers, with nine million changing planes. British Airways alone had two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, with most moving between Terminal 1 (for Domestic and European flights) and Terminal 4 (for long-distance flights). Even efficient airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich have bad days. The risk of losing baggage is higher at some airports. Even in the United States, Miami airport is known for luggage going missing when passengers connect to flights to Latin America.

To avoid losing your luggage, choose direct flights when you can and check in early. If you must change planes or if it makes your flight cheaper, try to fly with the same airline. Allow more time for connections by taking an earlier flight to the transfer airport, and label your luggage inside and out with your home and holiday addresses. Don't forget to include the flight numbers. If your luggage still goes missing, contact the airline official in the baggage hall and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.

Charlie James is a wildlife photographer who knows a lot about kingfishers. These are beautiful blue-green birds that live near streams and rivers and eat fish. The area where they live has old trees that hang over the water, creating a mix of soft greens, browns, and yellows from the sunlight. The kingfisher moves quickly and directly through this scene, like a flash of light. It disappears in a moment, but the image stays in your mind because of its strong impact.

Charlie fell in love with kingfishers when he was young. He can't quite explain why he is so drawn to them, but they are part of many legends. In Greek mythology, a kingfisher was a moon goddess who became a bird. Another story says the kingfisher flew so high that its top turned blue like the sky, and its bottom was burned by the sun. Scientifically, kingfishers don't have blue pigment in their feathers. Instead, their feathers reflect light in a way that makes them look blue or green, depending on the light.

Many wildlife photographers are fascinated by kingfishers. They are colorful and, although they avoid people, they can be watched from a hidden spot. Charlie's first hiding place was an old blanket he used to cover himself while waiting for a kingfisher. The bird came close, but it took him four years to take a good picture. During this time, he spent as much time as possible by a stream full of kingfishers, even skipping school, which affected his studies. However, his passion for kingfishers was noticed, and at 16, he became an advisor for a nature magazine. He later worked as an assistant editor and then became a freelance wildlife film cameraman.

Charlie dreams of making the perfect kingfisher film, with no words, just beautiful images. He loves the simple approach and enjoys photographing parts of the kingfisher's wings. Even after spending so much time with these birds, they still fascinate him. His photos show some of his feelings, but he knows there is more to his connection with kingfishers than his work can express.

**Conducting an Orchestra: Insights from Five New Conductors**

**A. Anne Manson**  
Anne Manson, 30, had an unexpected start in conducting when she asked to watch Claudio Abbado's rehearsals in Vienna. She ended up replacing an absent assistant and later helped with another opera. "I wasn't nervous," she says. "I've always been comfortable leading an orchestra." Manson, originally from the US, works with a London opera company that focuses on modern music. She is also gaining recognition in Europe, supported by the British Arts Council, and has worked with Abbado on several projects since then.

**B. Andrew Constantine**  
Andrew Constantine, 31, says the hardest part of conducting is convincing people to give you opportunities. He won a big competition in 1991 after failing in two others. "If I had won earlier, I might not have succeeded," he reflects. The competition gave him many chances to perform and work with a famous conductor. However, he worries about being known only for the competition. "If in three years I'm still just the 'competition winner,' I'll be concerned," he says. "But orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra are inviting me back, which is a good sign."

**C. Wasfi Kani**  
Wasfi Kani, who founded Pimlico Opera, enjoys the long rehearsal periods in opera. "The music deserves four weeks of focus," she says. Kani began conducting seriously in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London's business district until Pimlico Opera became fully professional two years ago. Learning from Sian Edwards was a turning point for her. "Seeing someone my size conduct was inspiring," she explains. She appreciates the complexity of opera, including managing singers' personalities.

**D. Roger Vignoles**  
Roger Vignoles, 48, found conducting unexpectedly fascinating. He started as a musician in an opera house and worked with skilled conductors. Last year, he directed Handel's Agrippina from the piano at a festival, a new experience for him. "It was easier than I thought," he says. "I knew the music and what I wanted it to sound like." Vignoles values his musical experience and is open to trying new things to discover what he enjoys.

**E. Wayne Marshall**  
In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed Wayne Marshall, then a young assistant, and recommended him. Marshall, now 32, quickly found himself conducting a musical in London with little preparation. He even had to deal with musicians who were not paying attention. "I was firm with them," he says. "I always gave a clear beat and got the best results I could." Marshall has never formally studied conducting but is confident and knows what he likes. "If people see you're worried, it gets worse," he advises.

**Variations on a Theme**

If you want to take children to a theme park in Britain, there are many options. We asked five families to try out some of the best parks.

**Fun Island - The Burns family**

Last year, we visited a big theme park in the US, so we thought Fun Island might not be as exciting. However, we were pleasantly surprised. The park is great for younger children, so our three-year-old had fun too. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special dodgems ride for very young kids, which was a big hit. For older children, there are more thrilling rides like Splash Out, where you end up in a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were ready to leave, but the children wanted to stay because they were having so much fun. Our only complaint is that the park could have a better atmosphere and scenery. But the staff are very helpful, and the park is clean, well-organized, and safe.

**Wonderland - The McMillan family**

None of us had been to a theme park before, so we didn't know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings. The older children liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a road layout. We spent six hours there and appreciated the places to rest. The landscaping is beautiful, and the staff are friendly. There is something for everyone, including adults.

**Adventure World - The Jeffree family**

After seven hours, we still had more to see. The children loved the Big Top Circus with its exciting trapeze act. We went on the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared and closed their eyes, they said they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you'll get wet, but you don't. Toy Land is great for younger children. The children wanted to try the new ride, Fear Factor, but they were too small, which was a relief for us! The park is well-designed, so even waiting in line isn't too boring. It's very clean, and the staff are excellent. On one ride, I couldn't sit with both girls, so a staff member offered to go with one of them.

**The Great Park - The Langridge family**

We arrived at 1 p.m. and were disappointed that the park closed at 5 p.m. This is a great park for younger children because the rides aren't too scary. I'm usually scared, but I had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts calmly and then becomes very exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over quickly! I didn't go on the Big Leap, but it looked fun for those who are brave. If the children were older, they might have found it a bit boring, but they were the right age and loved it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all family**

The park advertises 'No Limit to the Fun,' and we agree. Europe's tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, is very noticeable, and Ben thought it was the scariest ride. Jennie thought the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was even scarier! There are about a dozen main rides, and the older children went on them several times. Sarah was too small for a few rides but enjoyed the Long Slide. We found the staff's attitudes varied. Some were great with younger children, but not all were welcoming. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We wouldn't have dared to tell the kids we were leaving early.

Running a Business in the Countryside: Five Women Share Their Stories

A. Christine Hogan runs a computer-aided design business with a yearly income of over £200,000 and four full-time employees. She says, "My customers are friends." Christine and her husband moved from London to the countryside when their children were young. She wanted a job she could do from home. Having worked with computers before marriage, her husband suggested starting a computer-aided design business. It required a lot of money, and the beginning was tough. Christine was careful with spending and informed the bank if she might overspend. Working from home saves money, and she can work in the evenings if needed. The business remains small, and local customers usually pick up their work.

B. Maggy Sasanow enjoys being independent and works from home designing greeting cards. She studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum, but there were no such jobs in the countryside where she moved after marriage. So, she started her own business, creating 50 different greeting cards sold to museums. She works in a large room upstairs. The downside of working from home is the constant chores, like mowing the lawn. Her business grows through word of mouth, without advertising. People send work from London because she is cheaper than other artists. Although she misses exchanging ideas with others, she finds more advantages than disadvantages.

C. Delia Turner has faced challenges with her curtain-making business. She started eight years ago when the business was growing, and her income increased from £24,000 to £80,000 in two years. She managed six full-time workers but had to let them go due to the economy's decline, which was hard because jobs are scarce in the area. Now, she makes curtains at home with her husband's help and hires women who work from their homes. Delia is ready to lower prices when needed and explore new opportunities.

D. Tessa Strickland manages the editorial and production side of her children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside three years ago for financial reasons and because she loves the country. Tessa enjoys flexible working hours. Most of her income comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so she takes calls at odd hours. The challenge is maintaining discipline to stop working. She publishes children's books from different cultures, collaborating with authors and artists. Initially, she felt lonely because all her professional experience was in London.

E. Meg Rivers runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop with a yearly income of £250,000, employing six people, some part-time. She started ten years ago at home, interested in health, making fruit cakes with quality ingredients. Friends and relatives began requesting cakes, and soon she was sending them nationwide. Seven years ago, she rented a small building where everything is made by a baker, an assistant, and a professional cake decorator. Meg no longer cooks but manages the business side. Her biggest challenge has been the financial aspect, as they didn't have much money to start with.

Meet the Amazing Watkins Family

The Watkins family is special because the sons are talented musicians and composers, and their father makes musical instruments. This is not something you see every day. John and Hetty Watkins, who are schoolteachers in South Wales, needed a cello for their ten-year-old son, Paul, because he was getting really good at playing. But buying a cello was too expensive. John thought, "Maybe I can make one myself." He found out about the Welsh School of Instrument Making nearby and took evening classes for about three years.

After trying to make violins and violas a few times, John made his first cello. Paul, now 28, says, "It turned out really well. Dad made me another one later, and I used it until a few months ago." John has now retired from teaching to make instruments full-time. He makes up to twelve violins a year and even sold one to the famous American violinist Jaime Laredo, which was a big achievement for him.

Paul and his younger brother, Huw, started playing music when they were very young. Paul first played the piano: "As soon as I was big enough to reach the keys, I started playing," he remembers. But soon, he wanted to play the cello. His parents wanted him to play the violin because they needed another violinist for their music group. Paul tried the violin for six weeks but didn't like it. He was inspired by the cellist in his dad's group and started taking cello lessons from him.

Huw, now 22, is also making a name for himself as a pianist and composer. He says, "My parents were supportive and relaxed. I wouldn't have liked being pushed. Instead of feeling jealous of Paul's success, I saw it as something to aim for."

Paul's cello, made by his dad, helped him win the string final of the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition. At just 20, he became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra, using his father's cello until last year. Now, he plays a Francesco Rugeri cello, which is on loan from the Royal Academy of Music. Paul says, "Dad hasn't said anything about me using a new cello, but he did admit that my new one is quite nice!" The new cello is 304 years old and has a powerful sound that can fill large concert halls.

Paul will soon be on television playing the Rugeri cello in Elgar's Cello Concerto for a new series called Masterworks. He says, "The history of the performance doesn't change how I play. I always play it my way." However, Paul won't be able to watch himself on TV because he will be performing at the Cheltenham Festival that night. Huw will also be busy, as his String Quartet will have its London premiere at the Wigmore Hall the same evening. John and Hetty will have to be very organized to keep up with their sons' busy musical schedules in the coming weeks.

**Looking After the Countryside: The National Trust**

The National Trust is an organization that aims to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, a warden for the Trust. 

According to Gareth, a National Trust Warden needs common sense and good people skills. This is important because wardens work with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and building companies. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his family's farm until he got married. About 80 people applied for the warden job on the Lleyn Peninsula, but Gareth got it because of his local knowledge and farming experience, even though he didn't have formal training. He says it's helpful that he still farms with his parents, so he understands farmers' problems and can relate to them.

Gareth's farming background also helps him with the physical work of the job, like building fences, planting trees, and constructing walls. Since joining the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. He remembers collecting flowers and bird nests as a child and realizes now that farming has changed the countryside. He believes it's not the farmers' fault because they were following government advice.

When Gareth started his job, farmers and conservationists often disagreed. Now, they are talking and understanding each other better. Gareth believes they are close to working together. Conservation is a big part of Gareth's work, along with allowing public access to Trust land, planting trees, and meeting with tenant farmers. He enjoys seeing projects completed, although he spends a lot of time on paperwork.

Gareth loves his job, even though he is always on duty. He especially enjoys talking to the public, although he finds some people's attitudes frustrating. They sometimes act like they own the place, which annoys him. But as Gareth says, it's all about common sense. If you have a lot of common sense and like working outdoors, you might consider becoming a warden like Gareth. However, don't expect a job to open up on the Lleyn Peninsula anytime soon!

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met with England's netball captain. Kendra Slowinski is the captain of England's netball team. When I met her, she was having a typical day like she has had for weeks before next month's World Championships: teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. I asked her, "Don't people look at you strangely?" She replied, "I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice anything else. I might see cars slow down from the corner of my eye, but that's it."

"My whole life now is about being at my best for the Championships," says Kendra. "I'm on a strict schedule to get as fit as possible." These are her fourth World Championships, and they will be the biggest ever, with 27 countries participating. "We'll have support from home, which is very special," she says. "It's important to improve netball's reputation in this country. Because we're playing here, there will be more pressure than usual. A home crowd will have expectations and give more support. People will expect us to start the tournament with a good game."

Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. "As far as I know, we have always beaten them, but it will be exciting to play them. They have a lot of talent." The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. But, as Kendra points out, the World Championships will be tough. "You have to push yourself to play every day; there's no rest between games like in a series. You can still win an international series if you lose the first game. But the Championships are different because there's only one chance, and you have to be ready to make the most of it."

In the fifteen years she has been playing at the top level, the sport has become harder and faster. On the court, players are more aggressive. "You don't do all that training not to come out a winner," says Kendra. "But once the final whistle blows, you become a different person. We're all friendlier after the game."

Netball is also using a more scientific approach to fitness testing. "It's essential that we all think and train like world-class players," says Kendra. "As captain, I think it's important to have a strong mental attitude and lead by example. I see my role as supporting and encouraging the rest of the team."

"From the very beginning, my netball career has always been carefully planned," she says. "So I decided some time ago that this competition would be the end of my playing career." She will likely coach young players in the future, but right now, she is focused on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening candlelight ceremony, she is likely to have a tear in her eye.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**

How should you help a child with exceptional musical talent? It's not always easy to know the best way to support their gift. Some parents might not notice their child's needs until the child becomes frustrated and difficult. While most schools can handle children who are very good at academic subjects, musically talented children need special attention that regular schools might not provide, especially if music is not a main focus there. These children, along with those encouraged by parents or teachers, might benefit from attending a specialist music school.

There are five specialist music schools in Britain, which are quite new. They offer a supportive environment for gifted children aged seven to eighteen to develop their musical skills with the help of professional musicians. At these schools, children spend one-third to half of their day on music activities, such as individual lessons (up to three hours a week on their main and second instruments), playing in orchestras, chamber groups, voice training, conducting, and learning music theory. They also practice for several hours a day in well-equipped private rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their time is spent on a limited academic program focusing on essential subjects like English, math, basic sciences, and languages. However, students can study more subjects if they want.

All five British specialist schools are independent, with small classes and a high number of teachers compared to students. Most children at these schools are boarders, meaning they live at the school full-time. This allows them to spend their important growing years with others who have similar goals and interests.

What are the downsides? One clear issue is the cost; boarding fees are high (between £12,000 and £17,000 a year). However, schools try to help parents of very talented children with scholarships and financial aid. Another concern is that not all parents want to send their children to boarding school, especially at a young age. Many school directors are unsure about admitting children as young as seven into such a demanding environment. They emphasize that their main goal is to develop 'well-rounded and balanced individuals.'

There is a risk that separating musically gifted children from others at an early age can cause stress. Musical talent might fade during teenage years, and the pressure to succeed can lead to a feeling of failure. But specialist schools closely monitor each student's progress and offer help if needed. While many former students feel they gained a lot from the excellent music teaching, some worry about the limited academic program, which is less important than music activities. Many musically talented young people are also very smart and can handle academic challenges, so they might feel frustrated if their academic needs aren't met.

For these reasons, it might be better to wait until the child is old enough to decide for themselves before choosing a specialist education. Those who are also good at academics might do well in a less specialized school with a strong music department or by combining regular school with music training at a junior music college. These colleges offer Saturday morning lessons with great teachers and experience in orchestras and chamber music. However, this option might not be possible for families who don't live near London or other big cities.

Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. Her house is surrounded by a large garden, which gives her many of her painting subjects. The garden is full of her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread seeds everywhere. The garden has a beautiful mix of colors, shapes, and structures, especially in the two long flower borders along the path that goes from east to west. This beauty is partly thanks to the previous owners, who loved gardening and left plants that Susan liked. She also kept their gardener, Danny. Susan says, "It was really his garden." They got along well. At first, Danny didn't agree with some of the plants Susan wanted, but when she explained she wanted to paint them, he understood her vision.

Susan likes to paint detailed pictures of single plants rather than the whole garden. Sometimes she paints a group of plants where they are, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. She doesn't arrange everything at once. Instead, she paints one flower at a time, which can take a few days, and then adds another flower to the painting. Sometimes, it takes her a couple of years to finish a painting. Her busiest time is spring and early summer when the tulips and poppies bloom. "They all bloom together, and you're so busy," she says. She is also fascinated by how flowers change as they decay. For example, tulips change shape when left in water for a day. They open up and look amazing. At first, they might seem boring in a vase, but they change with twists and turns.

Susan has always loved plants. She studied botany in school and collected wildflowers from the countryside. She wasn't interested in gardening back then and didn't like garden flowers because they looked fake to her. She preferred wildflowers because they grew in difficult places like rock cracks or cliff tops. Today, her garden has many plants from faraway places, but they fit in well. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, like a kind aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause serious harm. With two upcoming exhibitions and plenty of subjects to paint, she finds it hard to work in the garden. She now has an extra gardener, but she knows that to stay connected with her art, "you have to get your hands dirty."

Title: Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, is in her second year working as a chalet girl in Val d'Isère, France. Known as Pilch, she works for a company that provides cooking and cleaning services for visitors staying in chalets, which are wooden houses typical of the area. Sarah graduated in French and History of Art from Oxford Brookes University last summer. She says being a chalet girl isn't a long-term career but a fun way to spend a year or two before settling down. "It's a good way to make contacts. I meet successful people every week," she says.

Sarah doesn't live at the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to the chalet, which can host up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing breakfast for the guests, which includes porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After the guests finish breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either prepares afternoon tea for the guests or cleans the rooms, which she says is "the worst part of the job." By 11 a.m., she is ready to go skiing. She skis as much as she can, sometimes until 4:30 p.m.

Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner and takes a shower before starting, but she doesn't nap. "It's fatal if you do," she says. Dinner is a three-course meal served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually on the table by 10 p.m. After dinner, Sarah cleans up and loads the dishwasher. "There's nothing worse than coming into a messy kitchen the next morning," she says. Sometimes she chats with the guests, while other times they prefer to be left alone. "Good guests can make a week brilliant, but some weeks don't go quite so well," she says.

Sarah meets her friends at the chalet where she lives and they go out around 11 p.m. "We usually start off in Bananas, might go to G Jay's, and perhaps Dick's T-Bar at the end of the evening," she says. However, Sarah never stays out too late on Saturday night because Sunday is her busiest day. "A frightful day," she says, "when you certainly don't want to be cooking breakfast feeling exhausted." Work starts earlier on Sunday, with breakfast for guests ready by 7 a.m. Once the guests leave, Sarah starts cleaning quickly. "We just blitz the place - clear the breakfast, strip the beds, get everything ready." If she hasn't done the week's shopping on Saturday, she does it now. Around 3 p.m., after cleaning, Sarah prepares tea for the new guests, who arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they are confused and have many questions. "I'm sure it's the mountain air that does something to them," she says. Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests needing boots or skis by taking them to the ski shop and then gets a lift back to the chalet. Soon, it's time for dinner duty again and maybe a chat with friends, but not always. "Sometimes I'm so tired I just have an early night," she says.

**Changing Lives with a Stranger**

Mandie Currie, a zoo-keeper, spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. "Choosing what to wear was hard because I usually wear a uniform at the zoo. First, I went to a photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is calm and peaceful, but here I was rushing around. Some of the fashion team seemed stressed, but my job isn't usually stressful. At a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I laughed thinking that I would normally be cleaning cages or handling rats. I find magazines interesting, but I love my job at the zoo, so I'll stay there."

Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent a day at London Zoo. "I arrived at the zoo in leather boots and dark blue trousers. They gave me a green polo shirt to work in, which was good because I got very dirty. As I stroked an elephant, I thought Mandie was probably packing clothes. By five o'clock, I smelled bad, but I had a great day. When I retire from fashion, I might work with elephants, maybe in Africa."

Karen Hodson, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, joined the TV gardening show Ground Force. "I was very excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was really nice. I liked being in the fresh air. Sometimes, because of my shifts, I don't see daylight. It was hard work but fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the team. My idea of gardening didn't include hard work or careful planning. I was more enthusiastic than effective, so I won't leave my nursing job."

Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener with Ground Force, worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. "I made beds and gave out tablets. I thought I might faint, but I was surprised that it didn't bother me. The friendship among the nurses is great, and it felt very 'girlie' compared to my usual male environment. I feel my job is less important than nursing. My day at the hospital wasn't exactly pleasant, but it was very satisfying."

Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. "I changed into the uniform, and I felt different—people suddenly respected me. Before the flight, our supervisor talked about safety and what to do if someone had a heart attack, which I knew from my fitness training. When passengers boarded the flight to Paris, I gave out magazines. Everyone stared at me, and I felt self-conscious. On the return flight, we had 80 schoolchildren who wouldn't sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one sensible adult."

Sonia McDermott, an air hostess with Ryanair, spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. "I was worried about this swap because I don't exercise. I was surprised at how much attention you give to one person. In my job, I meet 130 passengers four times a day. I was surprised at lunch to see that some trainers didn't eat very healthily, but they all drink lots of water. I wouldn't swap my job for this. However, it has inspired me to join a gym and try to be healthier."

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Journey Memories**

**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to visit as often as I can. There's a local train from Cannes that travels along the coast and crosses into Italy. It offers amazing views of the sea. No matter the weather or time of year, it's always beautiful. From the other window, you can see some of the best gardens and homes in France. It feels like you're peeking into the lives of the rich and famous. The passengers are always lively, with a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the stunning journey.

**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I've enjoyed many train journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which travels across the desert in northern Sudan. Growing up in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to Kruger National Park because I was considered too young and troublesome. When I moved to England as a teenager, I still hadn't traveled by train. London Waterloo was the first real station I saw, and its large glass dome amazed me.

**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I owe a lot to one train: the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. Someone mentioned that pink is good for the brain, and I've worn the color ever since. What I remember most about the journey is how lovely it was to travel through France and then by boat up the Nile to Luxor. It was the perfect way to relax after the wedding.

**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on a series of articles about a round-the-world trip and had to cross a desert in an African country. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express. The schedule was unreliable—we were just given a day. We heard that the driver would often wait for days if he knew people were still coming. When the train appeared, hundreds of people rushed to get on, even climbing onto the roof for free. At night, the train crossed some of the most beautiful landscapes I've ever seen. It felt like a dream, like traveling across the moon.

**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people form their favorite train memories as children, but not me. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains. It wasn't until I was a teenager that trains became important to me. I made a film featuring a railway in Yorkshire. Most filming was on an old, unused part of the line, maintained by volunteers. That's where my love for steam trains began. When we weren't filming, we rode the train whenever we could. When I returned last year, it felt like time had stood still. Everything was still there, even the gas lights on the station platform!

Are you trying to get your story published? Our expert, Margaret Stubbs, has some advice for you. Many readers ask us, "I've written a story or book. Who should I send it to?" The first thing you need to do is research the market and learn about publishers while improving your writing skills. Selling your writing requires understanding the publishing world. No matter what you write, you need to know the market you are targeting. The best way to do this is by reading as much as you can. Visit your local library, bookshops, and newsagents. Reading widely will help you understand what publishers are looking for at any time. Keep updating your knowledge because new publications appear, editors change jobs, and magazines change direction. Publishers always want new writers, so we must give them what they want. 

If you're not sure what to write, let's say you want to write short love stories. First, find out which magazines publish love stories and get recent copies. Learn what kind of stories they buy and who their readers are. Editors focus on what their readers want. Writers often ask me, "My story was rejected three times. Am I wasting my time?" As a former teacher, I never discourage anyone, but the work might not be ready for publishing. Most new writers send their work too soon, before they are ready. If you've only written one story or article, it's unlikely to be published. Success usually comes after years in publishing or journalism. 

When you send your work for the first time, start writing more stories while waiting for a reply. Write ten or even twenty more. Each one will be better, and you'll start seeing yourself as a writer. Don't throw any stories away—improve them. I also suggest not showing your work to others, especially at the beginning. Remember, every successful writer faced many rejections before succeeding. Do everything you can to advance your writing career. Look for a creative writing course nearby or join a local writers' group to gain ideas and confidence. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if possible.

On the last day of a difficult year, I was at the Baltimore railway station, waiting for the 10.10 train to Philadelphia. The station was busier than I expected. Usually, it felt airy and clean, but now it was crowded. Elderly couples with matching luggage filled the benches, and college students sat on the floor with their bags. 

A well-dressed, grey-haired man was walking around, talking to strangers. He looked wealthy, with tanned skin and nice clothes. He approached a woman sitting alone and asked her something. Then he came to a girl near me with long blond hair. I had thought about talking to her myself. The man asked, "Are you traveling to Philadelphia?" 

She replied, "I'm going north, yes." 

"But to Philadelphia?" he asked again. 

"No, New York," she said, "but I'll be..." 

"Thanks, anyway," he said and moved on. Now, I was curious. I heard him ask an old lady, "Are you traveling to Philadelphia?" She said she was going to Wilmington, and he moved on to another couple. 

I stood up and moved closer, pretending to look at the train platform. I was going to Philadelphia, but he didn't ask me. I guessed he thought I looked unreliable. He glanced at me quickly and then walked away, looking stressed. 

"Please!" he said to a woman reading a book. "Tell me you're going to Philadelphia!" 

She looked up from her book. She seemed about thirty-five, older than me, and like a schoolteacher. "Philadelphia?" she said. "Yes, I am." 

"Could I ask you a favor?" he asked. 

I stopped nearby, pretending to check my watch, even though I didn't have one. I could tell she was cautious. The man noticed too and said, "Nothing too difficult, I promise!" 

They announced my train, and people started moving toward Gate E, pulling their bags. I heard the man explain, "My daughter is flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad, leaving from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning, then went shopping, and when I got home, my wife was upset. My daughter forgot her passport and called from the Philadelphia station, not knowing what to do." 

The woman listened sympathetically. I would have stayed quiet to see what he wanted. 

"So I told her to stay there, and I would find someone here to take her passport," he said. 

I thought it was suspicious. Why didn't he go himself if it was so urgent? 

"Why don't you go yourself?" the woman asked. 

"I can't leave my wife alone for that long. She's in a wheelchair," he replied. 

This seemed like a weak excuse to me. It was too much bad luck for one family. I looked at them. The man was holding a padded envelope, not a regular one, which seemed odd. It was the size of a paperback book and looked stapled shut. I thought to myself, "Be careful, lady."

**Gary and Me**

John Moore, a restaurant owner, talks about his relationship with his son Gary, who is a famous TV chef.

I believe everyone gets a chance in life. My son, Gary, got his chance with cooking, and my chance was to run a restaurant. When I heard about the opportunity, I quickly went to see the place. It was in very bad condition, but it was perfect for what I wanted. Starting this business reminded me of my childhood. I remember my mother going to work in a factory, and I was upset because I was left alone. So, I thought, 'We need time for family life.' My wife focused on taking care of the children and did all my accounts, while I ran the business. We lived above the restaurant back then, and we always made sure to have meals together. This has been very good for our children, Gary and Joe. They are both very confident. From a young age, they would come down and talk to our regular customers. This gave them a great start in life.

Gary was a very active child. When he was about seven, he tried to jump into our corner bath like it was a swimming pool and knocked himself out. As he grew older, he had to work for pocket money. He started with small jobs, and by the age of ten, he was in the kitchen every weekend, so he always had a lot of money at school. He was disciplined. He used to wake up even before me in the morning. In a family business, it's for the family, and it was nice to see him helping out. Gary wasn't very good at school, but he was excellent in the kitchen. By the age of 15, he was as good as any of the men working there, and sometimes he was even in charge. He would make over a hundred meals, and I knew he would go into catering because he had a talent for it. So when he told me, 'Dad, I need to do work experience for my school course,' I sent him to a friend who has a restaurant.

Gary recently started playing the drums and now has his own band. I wonder what will happen to his cooking if the music becomes successful. My advice to Gary is: if you try to do two things at once, you might not succeed in either, so focus on what you know you can do well. He understood when I told him: 'Gary, if you want to achieve something in life, you need to do it by the age of 30. If you haven't done it by then, it might be too late.'

Gary went to catering college at 17, and on his first day, he and the other new students, who are usually beginners, were given a morning's work. But within an hour, Gary had chopped all his vegetables and sliced all his meats. He had prepared everything. That's my son! In the end, he was helping other people. None of us can believe how successful Gary's TV cooking show has become. I'm very proud of him. I've always tried to tell him that if you want something, you have to work very hard for it because no one gives you anything for free. He saw the opportunity he was given and took it with both hands. You know, you talk to your children as they grow up, and if they remember even ten percent of what you've told them, you should be happy. The things Gary says and does make me think he must have listened sometimes.

Finding a good flat in Dublin at an affordable price was very difficult, like finding gold during a gold rush. The best way to find a place was through personal connections: if you knew someone who knew someone leaving a flat, that often helped. But if you were new to Dublin, like Jo, you had no personal contacts and no one to tell you about available places. So, you had to stay in a hostel and search for a flat. For Jo, Dublin was a big unknown. She felt like she was stepping into the unknown when she took the train to work there. She didn't question why she was going; everyone at her school assumed she would leave. Who would stay in a small, boring town? That's what she heard for years. Everyone wanted to leave, see the world, and have a real life. Some of her classmates went to towns like Ennis or Limerick, where they had family to help them settle. But no one from Jo's year was going to Dublin. She was going alone. Jo's mother thought it would be great if she stayed in the hostel permanently because it was run by nuns and safe. Her father hoped the hostel was warm because they were known to be cold. Jo's sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy to stay in a hostel for a whole week. But Jo didn't know they were still thinking and talking about her as she answered an ad for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, 'Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom.' It was close to the post office where she worked and seemed too good to be true. She hoped it would be nice, that they would like her, and that it wouldn't be too expensive. There wasn't a long line for this flat because it was more like 'Third Girl Wanted' than 'Flat to Let.' The mention of 'own television' made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked ordinary. It was a red-brick terraced house with a basement, but the flat was upstairs. A cheerful girl with a college scarf, who had obviously been rejected, was coming down the stairs. 'Desperate place,' she said to Jo. 'They're both awful. Common as dirt.' 'Oh,' said Jo and continued climbing. 'Hello,' said a girl with 'Nessa' on her T-shirt. 'Did you see that snobby girl leaving? I can't stand her type.' 'What did she do?' asked Jo. 'Do? She didn't have to do anything. She just looked around, made a face, giggled, and said, "Is this all there is? Oh dear, oh dear," in a posh accent. We wouldn't have her here, would we, Pauline?' Pauline wore a very colorful shirt, almost as bright as her hair. Pauline was a punk, which amazed Jo. She had seen punks on O'Connell Street but never talked to one. 'I'm Jo, I work at the post office, and I called about the flat.' Nessa said they were about to have tea and offered Jo a mug. One mug had 'Nessa,' another had 'Pauline,' and the third had 'Other' written on it. 'We'll put your name on it if you stay,' Nessa said kindly.

People love dolphins. We enjoy watching them at seaside marinas, in movies, and on TV. However, the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society says dolphins are in serious trouble. Mark Simmonds talks about how dolphins are declining. Dolphins are special to us because they are very intelligent, understand human feelings, and make us dream of freedom in the ocean. TV shows like "Flipper" and "Seaquest" have made us love them even more. But these shows don't show the real problems dolphins face in polluted and overfished seas today. 

For example, the number of North Sea harbour porpoises, a type of dolphin, has dropped by up to 89,000. You might think such popular animals are protected by law and live in special marine areas, but this is not true. Without plans to protect them, dolphins might face one of the biggest wildlife disasters ever.

There are 40 different kinds of dolphins worldwide. In northern Europe, the most common are the striped, common, bottlenose dolphins, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The first two types usually live far out at sea and are seen only in small groups. We don't know much about them. The large grey bottlenoses and harbour porpoises used to be common near European coasts. Bottlenoses are very social and were found on the Channel coast and in British rivers like the Thames. Now, they are only found in places like Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The few that remain show signs of stress.

It's hard to know exactly why dolphin numbers are going down because their habits are complex. Overfishing is a big problem because it reduces fish stocks, which dolphins need to eat. If fish are caught in one area, dolphins may not find food in time. They can also get caught in fishing nets, which they can't see. Modern fishing uses large nets that float or are pulled quickly through the sea. Many dead dolphins have been found on beaches in France and Cornwall, showing marks and cuts from these nets.
