**A New Life**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years in business, working in the City became boring and no one was having fun anymore. I didn't plan to leave for another five or ten years, but then I lost my job unexpectedly. I didn't get a big payout, but it was enough to start the farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a local hotel with one of the top 20 hotel restaurants in the country. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat by mail order. I'm happy not to be stuck in an office, but it's surprising how little has changed: I still work 80 to 90 hours a week and I'm still selling a product."

**The Painter**  
Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising but now earns a living as an artist. "Painting started as a hobby, but I realized it was more exciting than my job. Taking redundancy and becoming an artist seemed logical. The career counselor I spoke to was very helpful. I think I was the first person to tell him, 'I don't want to go back to my old job.' He was surprised because most people in their mid-forties need to work immediately for money. But we married young, and our children didn't need our support. It was a leap into the unknown. We moved to the north of England, where we didn't know anyone. It meant leaving all our friends, but we've been lucky that our friendships have survived the distance—many of them visit us now."

**The Hatmaker**  
After working for five years as a company lawyer, Katherine Goodison started her own business in her London flat, making hats for private clients. "My job as a lawyer was fun and I earned a lot of money, but the hours were terrible. I realized I didn't want to become a senior partner, working even more hours, so I left. Many people said I'd get bored, but that never happened. The secret is to have deadlines. Since it's a fashion-related business, there are always collections, next year's styles, and the season—there's always too much to do, so you need a very organized schedule. I feel happier now and definitely less stressed. I do miss things like social interaction with colleagues. What I love about this job is that I'm totally responsible for the product. If I do a bad job, I'm the one to blame. Of course, you care when working for a company, but when your name is on the promotional material, you care even more."

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I started in financial markets at 22, setting up deals. I liked the adrenaline, but the work was never rewarding. I was almost made redundant in 1989, but I resigned and traveled for a year. During that year, I tried to figure out what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited some of the world's best gyms and talked to the owners about how they started. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took various massage courses. Then I got a part-time job at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I never used to feel in control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my future. That's the best part."

**Onto a Winner**

Two brothers are finding that their childhood game is very good for business. Dave and Norm Lagasse, two brothers in their forties with big beards, are sitting in their simple home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA, and remembering their childhood. In front of them is a wooden board with round plastic pieces. They are playing the old game of pichenotte, which they say is unique. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, a grocer from Quebec, Canada, brought the game to the USA and taught it to his family. Soon, the family was playing the game almost every weekend and holiday, and as Dave says, they were 'having the best time ever'. 

Eventually, the family moved to New Mexico. But they did not forget Grandpa's pichenotte board, which he made from old wooden food crates, and they kept playing regularly. When visitors came by, they were often interested because the game was unknown in southern USA. Three years ago, Dave noticed the old pichenotte board was cracked and worn out, so he decided to make a new one. It turned out beautifully. A relative saw it and wanted one, then a friend wanted another. Curious about how popular the game might be, the brothers took one of Dave's new boards to a sports bar in Santa Fe. 'People there started to watch,' says Dave, 'and say, "No way I'm playing that silly game." Then they'd sit down, and soon you couldn't get them up from the table!'

When people started asking about the game's origins, Dave did some research. He found out that the game probably started in India, where a similar game called 'carroms' exists. It was adapted into a game called 'squails' played in British pubs, and a century ago, British people moving to Canada brought the game with them. Pichenotte is the name of the French-Canadian version that developed in Quebec. Pichenotte, which can be played by two to four people, is a game of skill. Each player gets 12 pieces or 'pucks'. These are 'flicked' across a wheel-like board using the middle or index finger of one hand. Flicking a puck into a small hole is worth 20 points. Three rings around the hole are worth 15, 10, and 5 points. Eight tiny posts are obstacles. The game usually lasts just two minutes.

Seeing how popular the game was at the Santa Fe bar, the Lagasses made more boards and took them to markets and craft fairs. Crowds gathered, money was exchanged, and the game's popularity grew. Championships began to take place, and a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup' was created. As word spread, the boards began to sell quickly. The brothers decided to go into the pichenotte business full-time. They set up a workshop in their garage and started making boards. They have made more than 450 so far. Made of birchwood and mahogany, each board weighs 12kg and is 1cm thick. As Norm explains, 'They're very durable, as they have to stand up to lots of use.' They sell for $595 each on the brothers' website.

There are no professional pichenotte players or TV coverage yet, but the brothers hope their garage will one day hold a luxury car instead of tools and wood. Until then, they are happy to spend their free time playing the game they hope will make them rich.

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**

When you first enter the Model Village, it's hard to believe that a few years ago, this was just a piece of unused land, flat and covered with wild plants. For a long time, people thought it was worthless. But with careful planning and hard work, one man, with the constant support of his wife, turned this land into the beautiful place you see today. Many thousands of tons of soil and clay were moved to change the flat land into the shaped landscape you see now. Bulldozers and digging machines helped, but a lot of hard work was also needed. After shaping the land, about 1,000 tons of topsoil were added to create the lawns, flower beds, and rock gardens.

Hundreds of trees and shrubs were planted in the Model Village. These plants had to be chosen carefully because they needed to survive the salty air near the sea and the strong winter winds. Most plants came from local garden centers, but some were brought from as far away as Canada and New Zealand.

The whole village was the idea of Colin Sims, and he made over 100 models by himself over nine years, starting from when the village first opened in 1972. The models are made from different materials like stone, concrete, specially treated wood, and plastics to handle all kinds of weather. At first, Colin needed help from experts to understand how different materials would last in changing weather, but he soon became an expert himself.

You will notice that all models are made to the same scale, and even the smallest details are carefully done. This was achieved through patience and special building techniques. The Model Village is very popular and is known for its high-quality work and upkeep. The techniques used here have been used in other model villages in England and are even taught in some college courses.

All the model buildings show traditional British architecture and are not based on one specific place. One of the most impressive buildings is the Manor House, a typical 13th-century stone building with a brick tower and stone walls, similar to those found in the West Country. As you walk around, you will also see the Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is the newest addition.

Please stay on the paths during your visit and do not touch the models; a small mistake can mean hours of repair work for us. You can take photos from the paths. Dogs are welcome if they are on a short lead. To make your visit more enjoyable, you will find buttons in front of some working models. Press these to see the models move.

At the end of your visit, we would love to hear your thoughts. We are always planning new models, and your ideas can help us create a more interesting display. We also want to know if any models are not as good as the others. We are always updating and replacing models, so your feedback is important. We hope you enjoy your visit and look forward to seeing you again. Don't forget to tell your friends about us!

Week after week, British tabloid newspapers publish pictures that invade people's privacy and break the rules set by newspaper editors. Sometimes pop stars pose for photographers, but this is not common. Usually, these pictures cause a lot of harm to famous people when their private moments are shown on the front page. However, very few people use the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), an organization created to handle such issues. These pictures rarely serve the public interest. Do private photos of pop stars help solve crimes? How did a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony protect public health and safety? The actress has complained about long-lens photos before, and since she was in a hotel, where privacy is expected, she had a good reason to complain, but she didn't. It is shocking that the PCC did not investigate on its own. They should also look into the recent story about a pop star's love life. Like the actress, the pop star did not make a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take action on these and other unfair attacks? At first, this seems like a good idea. It would lead to many decisions against newspapers. These decisions would be reported by other newspapers and on TV and radio. The public would not support the newspapers, and editors would have to stop publishing such material. Even photographers would be affected, as it would no longer be profitable to hide and take pictures of celebrities. If the PCC decided to act like a 'police officer', which it could, there would be problems. How would it decide to start an investigation? Should it ask the victim to make a complaint? And if the person still refused, should it continue anyway? Also, celebrities and royalty might expect every story about them to be investigated and be upset if it wasn't. The role is too big. How could the PCC realistically monitor all British press: national, regional, and magazines? There is also the embarrassment factor. Even if someone's privacy is invaded, would they want the embarrassment of an investigation? Most people probably just want to move on with their lives. Some might have other reasons for staying quiet. There might be a worse story they have kept from the press, and they fear it could become public if they complain. In other words, even the PCC might seem like an enemy. A British comedian also suffered when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon in the Caribbean. He didn't complain then, nor when he and his family were photographed during a holiday. He feared that the newspaper, News of the World, would publish the pictures again with a new story about his 'anger', saying it was just a joke and that, as a comedian, he should have a sense of humor. This fear is understandable. People believe they will be targeted again if they challenge the tabloids. It is hard to find an easy solution to this serious problem.

There is a lot of advice for college graduates starting their first job. This article is about moving to a second job. We are not talking about those looking for a temporary job while searching for a permanent one, or those leaving a bad job in the first few weeks. We are focusing on those who are ready to take a real step in their career, choosing a job that matches their goals now that they have some experience and skills.

What kind of job should you look for? It depends on your long-term goals. Ask yourself if you want to specialize in a certain area, move up to higher positions, or switch to a different field. Whatever you decide, choose your second job carefully. Plan to stay in it for two to three years. This job will be important when you apply for your next job. It should show that you are serious about your career. Most importantly, it should help you grow and give you more responsibility.

If you feel like traveling, now is a good time to do it. You can do temporary work when you return and then find your second job. Future employers will be glad to see that you have traveled and are not likely to leave again soon.

Juliette Davidson spent her first year after college working for three lawyers. It was a great first job because they were supportive. She learned about office work and improved her computer skills. But there was no chance to advance, so she quit, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year. Now, Juliette works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. In two and a half years, she has grown a lot in her job. Her boss wanted to help her develop from the start. Her job title is the same, but her duties have changed. She went from mostly typing and answering phones to handling most of the correspondence and budgets. She also deals with different questions, from company chairmen to people wanting to start their own business. Brenda involves her in all her work and gives her specific projects and events to organize.

Confident people: What's their secret? Confident people might seem like they were always confident, but most of them have learned this skill because they needed to. Nina Hathway talks to five people about how they became confident.

A. Jenny: When I finished school, I was very shy and thought I would always be that way. When I was 25, I was asked to help at my daughter's school. I didn't think I could do it, but I did well. Someone there suggested I take a university course. I was very nervous on my first day, but my confidence grew over time. Working at the school was a turning point in my life.

B. Michaela: Four years ago, my father got sick, and I had to take over the family business. I was scared and became too aggressive and impatient. I thought that's how confident people acted, but I learned that confidence means believing in yourself. If work gets too hard, I don't feel bad about leaving some tasks for the next day. When faced with something difficult, I remind myself I have nothing to lose. Fear makes you less confident, so I talk to myself to overcome those fears.

C. Lisa: People think I'm confident, but the calmer I look, the more scared I am. In TV, looking confident is very important. Interviewing people taught me that everyone gets nervous in important situations, and we feel better when we talk to someone friendly. My mother once told me, 'Who's looking at you? Everyone's worried about themselves.' I remember this advice. You gain confidence by facing things that scare you. I was very nervous during my driving test, but I passed. After that, I felt I wouldn't be that scared again.

D. Barbara: My confidence comes from enjoying my work, but I've built it over the years. If you keep going and learn from mistakes, you'll be more confident next time. I work hard and am liked at the restaurant, but not everyone likes me. I don't let that bother me. You have to like yourself for who you are. My company offers training courses, which have boosted my self-esteem. They also encourage setting achievable goals. It's helpful to see you're achieving something real, rather than aiming too high and getting nothing.

E. Kim: After college, I worked as a secretary and was too scared to speak up in meetings. Eventually, I found the confidence to share my opinions. When I started in politics, I had never spoken in public and was very nervous. I told myself, 'People do this every day, so you can too.' I also wrote down notes to help me, like a comfort blanket. Everyone feels a bit nervous about public speaking. The secret to confidence is telling yourself, 'Nothing is impossible.'

Paul Forster visits Malaysia for a kite-flying festival and spends a night in the forest. Adnan Ali, a local, smiles as Paul returns his broken kite. Adnan tells Paul to keep it because it's a tradition that if a kite's line breaks, the finder keeps it. Adnan has many more kites, all beautifully decorated and made of tissue paper and bamboo. They sit under the trees near the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, watching Malaysia's biggest kite festival. 

On the beach, there are 10 platforms where helpers hold up kites. Competitors wait for the signal to release their kites. When the whistle blows, the kites fly up like rockets. Over 500 men and boys compete, each with four kite designs judged on decoration, stability, and flying ability. Adnan explains that flying kites is easy, but making them requires skill. He invites Paul to his home to show him how it's done. Paul accepts the invitation and enjoys cold tea and fish crackers at Adnan's house. Adnan asks Paul to return the next day to help rebuild the kite, but Paul has other plans.

Paul explores the southern part of Kelantan, driving towards Kuala Lumpur through mountains and rainforests. He takes a wrong turn and ends up at a river. A boat is there to take people across. Paul sees a sign for 'Jelawang Jungle 3 km' and decides to follow the path. The path is steep and slippery. At the end, he meets Baba, who runs a tented kitchen and bamboo huts. Paul decides to stay the night, despite the insects. The night is dark and full of sounds, with a waterfall nearby. In the morning, he enjoys a view of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rains heavily, and Paul gets soaked. He worries about his car being washed away but finds it safe, covered in mud.

Back in Kota Bahru, the capital of Kelantan, people are friendly and ask Paul many questions. Kelantan is famous for its kites, but Paul remembers it for the kindness of its people.

**What kind of shopper are you?**

Everyone goes shopping, whether they like it or not. But people shop in different ways. Do you know what kind of shopper you are? Abby Edwards asked some people about their shopping habits.

**A. Melanie, 22, dancer**  
I'm a shopping addict—I can't spend enough money! When I have money, I go shopping, and it makes me happy. I find it hard to ignore sale signs. My boyfriend is the same, so we often shop together. We're an addicted couple!

**B. Brenda, 40, office manager**  
I'm a reluctant shopper. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks and knows what he wants. I don't spend much time shopping for clothes. I take my 6-year-old son and 14-year-old daughter to buy clothes, but I don't enjoy it because we all have different tastes. I don't spend money on myself often, so when I do, I feel guilty and don't tell my husband the real price—I always say it cost less! The real price always sounds too high.

**C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager**  
I only shop for essentials. I hate shopping and only go when I really have to. When I do shop, I know exactly what I want and won't settle for anything else. I find shopping tiring and would rather be doing something else.

**D. Anita, 35, TV producer**  
I like to look around sometimes, but I usually know what I want and where to find it. I don't waste time and try to shop quickly. I do have some mistakes hidden in my wardrobe, so maybe I'm a careful shopper who sometimes buys the wrong thing!

**E. Lizzie, 41, secretary**  
I don't enjoy shopping at all. I really dislike shopping for clothes because I can never find what I want or anyone to help me. The shops are too noisy and messy, and I find it a nightmare. Luckily, I rarely have to shop for clothes because most of my clothes are given to me. For food shopping, I go to the local supermarket once a week and finish quickly!

**F. Lisa, 22, actress**  
I'm probably a happy shopper. Sometimes I go out with my friends just to look around, and we often end up buying things. I don't usually have a specific item in mind, but if I see something I like, I'll buy it.

**G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant**  
I'm a careful shopper—I like shopping, but I don't buy much. I usually know what I want and don't go crazy. Sometimes I shop to cheer myself up, but I often feel worse because I've spent too much!

**H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker**  
I love shopping, but only on certain days and never on Saturdays because it's too busy. I'm a careful shopper. I usually know what I want and never buy things immediately. I look in other shops to find a better deal—it takes me a long time!

**I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager**  
I'm an unwilling shopper. Maybe because I work in the city center, the shops don't interest me anymore. When I have to shop, I do it quickly and don't try things on because it's too much trouble. Sometimes the clothes I buy don't fit, but I don't mind. I'd rather make a few mistakes than spend a lot of time shopping!

Text: 'NEW OPPORTUNITIES WITH AN OPEN UNIVERSITY DEGREE

The Open University offers degrees just like any other university. However, you can keep working while you study. It also lets you explore many different interests. If you have never studied before, you will enjoy the new experience of learning more. You will meet many different people and make new friends. Your degree might also help you find new job opportunities.

At the Open University, you don't attend regular lectures. Instead, you study at home using television, radio, and computer programs. You can choose to attend one class a month at an Open University center if you want. Like other universities, there are exams to pass.

If you want more information, just fill out the form below. This could be the beginning of an exciting new chapter in your life.'

**Gallery News**

**Easter Quiz for Children**  
During the Easter holidays, young visitors can join a quiz about "Surprises." You can get the free quiz sheets at the Orange Street entrance. Children will look at 14 surprising paintings and answer questions about them. The quiz is available during normal gallery hours from 25 March to 9 April.

**New Picture**  
The Gallery has a new still life painting by Dutch 18th-century artist Jan van Os. This large painting (89.1 cm x 71 cm) shows flowers and fruit in bright colors on wood. It is one of the first of its kind in the Gallery. The painting is signed and dated 1777 and 1778 because the artist waited for different flowers to bloom in their seasons to paint them. Miss Violet Churchman donated this picture in memory of her sister Ida Nancy. It is now on display in Room 25.

**Special Exhibition**  
The exhibition "Painting in Spain during the late 18th century" started in the Sunley Room on 15 March. The Gallery recently bought works by three Spanish painters from this time: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu. The exhibition also includes Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italians who worked in Spain, Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. The exhibition is open until 31 May.

**Lecture News**  
A series of lectures related to the special exhibition happens every Wednesday. On 5 April, Lizzie Barker will talk about Melendez's work. On 12 April, Sarah Symmons will discuss Luis Paret. On 19 and 26 April, Juliet Wilson will speak about Francisco Bayeu. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists often "tell a story" through their paintings.

**Gallery Restaurant Improvements**  
The Gallery is happy to announce that the restaurant now has better and more services. With new kitchens, the restaurant offers a wide choice of hot and cold dishes at reasonable prices.

**Information for Visitors**  
Free guided tours of the Gallery are available every day at 11.00 am and 3.00 pm (except Sundays). These tours introduce some of the Gallery's greatest paintings and show the full range of the Gallery's collection of important European paintings from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.

Little Chefs

For a group of children aged between ten and fifteen, Saturdays are spent learning how to cook seriously. Their weekly lessons in small classes are so popular that there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay £280 for the course where their children can have fun and learn to make good food. 

Bill, who is ten years old, says, 'I love my mum's cooking and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down with them to eat the food we've made.' Flora, who is twelve, is having trouble with onions. 'I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really liked it. Then my mum suggested I find a hobby instead of doing nothing at weekends. I was happy staying at home, so I wasn't very interested at first. But I'm really glad I decided to come.'

Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, although the kitchen isn't always tidy when they're cooking! As adults, we're always learning more about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking while they are young, they'll have enough skills to make food for themselves when they leave home.'

The Outdoor Centre charges a fee for a car with four people. Each extra person costs 50p. You need to pay the fees at the main office. The centre is not a private club; it is an organisation that provides outdoor sports and recreation for everyone. If you are visiting as a group, please let the centre know before you come.

Windsurfing - One-day course
Beginner windsurfing courses are available on Saturdays and Sundays if the weather is good. Learning to windsurf is very enjoyable. The thrill of sailing across the water for the first time is unforgettable. Beginners can use boards with small sails. The course costs £32.50, which includes all equipment.

One-day adventure course
This is a great chance to try sailing, climbing, surfing, and archery. The course is designed to introduce adults to outdoor activities in a fun and relaxed way. You don’t need to be very fit or have done these activities before. You just need to be interested. The course costs £22.50.

Play Park
The Play Park is for children aged two to ten. It is one of the best in the country. It has sand and water play, slides, a large ball pool, a play castle, and much more. Next year, the centre will open a new Play Palace and Play Ship.

Group day and residential courses
We also offer day and long weekend courses for groups. Schools, colleges, and youth groups visit us regularly. There are three large rooms with twelve beds each, which can be booked in advance for groups of up to 36 people (minimum 12).

Summer adventure holidays (for ages 8-14)
Activities include sailing, climbing, windsurfing, and fun games. Safety is very important at the Outdoor Centre. All staff are trained in First Aid and qualified to teach the activities. We make sure that all children only do activities that are right for their age and abilities. For this programme, children must be able to swim 25 metres and be in good health.

**STAMP COLLECTING - A HOBBY THAT CAN KEEP GROWING**

Millions of people, young and old, enjoy a hobby that is both interesting and fun. Every year, more people start their own stamp collections and find an interest that can last a lifetime. Starting your collection is easy because stamps are everywhere. You can get stamps from holiday postcards, birthday cards, and letters from friends around the world.

Once you start collecting seriously, you might want to join the Stamp Collectors' Club. This club helps collectors get new British stamps. As a member, you can order special sets of new stamps for your collection. You can receive these stamps in three ways: we can send you a complete set on an envelope addressed to you, send them in a colorful information pack with interesting facts, or send you individual stamps to arrange in your own special book.

The Stamp Collectors' Club has about 70,000 members, and you can join too. A two-year membership costs just £5, and there is a discount if a group joins together. This is great value for money. When you join, the Club sends you a Starter Pack at no extra cost. This pack includes 100 stamps to start your collection and a nice box to keep them in. You also get a helpful 4-page guide to collecting, with tips on how to add to your collection and addresses of shops that sell stamps.

Every two months, you'll receive the club magazine, which is full of competitions and quizzes. It also gives you the chance to exchange stamps with members around the world. Why not start an adventure that will give you years of pleasure? You can spend many happy hours looking at the amazing variety of stamps in your collection or searching for unusual ones. Join the Stamp Collectors' Club today and discover the fun and excitement of stamp collecting. To join, simply fill out the application form and send your membership fee. Your Starter Pack will arrive within 28 days of receiving your application.

Text: 'MONEY What is money? The pound, the dollar, or the franc are like units of measurement, such as a gram or a kilometre. The difference is that you can use money to buy things. For example, a five-pound note can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or a couple of cinema tickets. But the note itself is just a piece of paper that costs very little to make. Thousands of years ago, people didn't have money like we do now. There were no banks or shops. Back then, Mr. Green, the farmer, would trade the corn he grew for Mr. Hive's honey. This was a trade between two people, each having something the other wanted. Over time, most societies created their own 'currencies' so people could trade more easily. These different currencies started to connect, which is why today everyone uses a national currency.'

Text: 'Write a winning story! You could win £1,000 in this year's Fiction Prize and have your story published in Keep Writing magazine. Ten other lucky people will win a cheque for £100. We are looking for people who can write good stories. The judges, including Mary Littlejohn, a novelist, Michael Brown, a TV reporter, and Susan Hitchins, the editor of Keep Writing, want interesting and original stories. Last year, detective stories were very popular, but the winner wrote a love story. You can write about anything you like, but here is some advice to help you: Write about what you know This is important advice for every writer. Last year, most people who wrote for us did this. Love, family, and problems with friends were the main topics. However, you need to make ordinary situations interesting so people want to read them. Make the reader want to keep reading by writing about ordinary things in a new and surprising way. Get your facts right Don't describe a town or explain how something works if you are not sure about it. Only write about things you know are correct. Hold the reader's attention Make the beginning interesting and the ending a surprise. A bad ending is the worst. Develop the story carefully and try to think of something unusual for the end. Think about the characters Make the people in your story seem real by using the right words. Your story must be your own work, between 2,000 and 2,500 words, and typed, double-spaced, on one side of each sheet of paper. Even if you are close to the deadline, we cannot accept stories by fax or email. You must include the application form with your story. Unfortunately, we cannot return your story or discuss our decisions. You should not have had any fiction published in any magazine or book in this country, and the story must not have appeared in print or on radio or TV anywhere in the world. Your £5 fee will go to the Writers' Association. Make your cheque payable to Keep Writing and send it with the application form and your story to us. The closing date is 30 July, and we will inform the winner within one month. If you win, you must agree to have your story published in our magazine.'

Text: 'THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST

Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. For many years, she was the only woman scientist mentioned in history books. Hypatia's father was the director of Alexandria University, and he made sure she got the best education possible. This was rare because most women at that time had few chances to study. After studying in Athens and Rome, Hypatia went back to Alexandria and started teaching mathematics. She quickly became well-known for her knowledge of new ideas. We don't have any copies of her books today, but we know she wrote several important works on mathematics. Hypatia was also interested in technology and invented several scientific tools to help with her work. During that time, many rulers were afraid of science, and people involved in it were in danger. One day in March 415, Hypatia was attacked on the street and killed.'

**NENE VALLEY RAILWAY**

**About the Railway**

The Nene Valley Railway is 12 kilometers long and goes through the beautiful Nene Park. It starts in the east at Peterborough and ends at Wansford, which is next to the main road. There is a 2-kilometer extension that takes passengers through Wansford Tunnel to Yarwell, the current western end of the line.

**Fares:** 
- Adult: £10.00
- Child: £5.00
- Family Fare (up to 2 adults and 3 children): £25.00
- Special prices may apply on public holidays.

**Nene Park**

Nene Park has golf courses and a large Caravan Club site. It's a great place for a family day out. There are many hectares of public parkland with boating lakes, picnic areas, a nature reserve, and a miniature railway.

**Wansford**

Wansford Station has a unique collection of historic trains from Europe. This includes famous trains like the elegant De Glen Compound locomotive from France and the German Class 52 Kriegslok, the largest working steam engine in Britain. You can also see '92 Squadron' and 'Mayflower', which were built in Britain. These engines can be seen all year round, even if the Nene Valley Railway is not running. The buffet, bar, and souvenir shop are only open when the train is running. There is a site entrance fee of £2.00 for adults and £1.00 for children at Wansford.

**A Famous Railway**

Nene Valley Railway is popular with filmmakers because it can look like a railway from any part of Europe. The James Bond movie "Octopussy" was filmed here. Come and see where it was made.

**Services for Schools**

From May to July, the Railway offers special services for school groups. Teachers can set projects for students to do while visiting or in the classroom. An educational pack is available for £1.50 plus postage. At other times, schools can hire the train ('Teddy Bear') with up to 3 carriages on non-service days. Bookings should be made one month in advance. There are special low fares for groups of 60 or more students. Call 01780 784444 for more information.

**Private Hire of Trains**

The Railway is a popular place for family events or company visits. It can be a fun afternoon or evening out. Special programs can include a buffet, bar, entertainment, discos, etc. For more information, contact the General Manager at Wansford Station.

Grass is probably the most successful plant in the world. There are over 9,000 different types of grasses, and they are found everywhere on Earth. They are the only flowering plants that can live in the cold environments of the Arctic and Antarctic. Grasslands support many kinds of animals, from small insects and birds to large animals like cows and lions. All these animals depend on grass in some way. Grass grows back quickly after it is cut or damaged. Unlike other plants, new leaves grow from below the soil, not from the top. This is why large groups of animals can live in one area. After they eat all the grass, new grass starts to grow again, providing a fresh meal.

Kal Kaur Rai, who has always loved fashion, recently won the Young Achiever of the Year award at the Asian Business Awards. Since she was a child, she enjoyed drawing clothes and creating designs. However, she never told her parents, who own a supermarket, that she wanted to make fashion her career. She thought they wanted her to choose a more traditional job, so she studied management at university. After graduating, she moved to London and worked at an advertising agency. She had to go to industry events but couldn't afford the designer clothes she liked, so she started making her own skirts and tops. Her friends loved her clothes and asked her to make some for them too. A small shop in London agreed to sell her designs on a sale-or-return basis, and they sold very well. This success encouraged her to leave her advertising job, take a £20,000 loan, and start her own womenswear brand. Kal's parents were supportive of her career change, which made her happy. Now, her clothes are sold in over 70 stores, and her business earns over £500,000. Her designs are featured in fashion magazines, she creates clothes for pop stars, and she has gained public recognition by winning this award. Kal feels very fortunate and says, "What I do is my hobby - and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this."

SUNNINGDALE HOTEL

The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913 and opened by Princess Louise. It has been a great place for people from all over the world to stay. In the last 80 years, more than 50,000 guests from 174 different countries have visited. The hotel is on a main road leading to the town center. It takes about 20 minutes by bus to get to the center, and buses to many parts of the town stop outside the hotel. Be careful not to take buses with the blue sign "Express" because they do not stop near the hotel. There is an underground station less than 100 meters away.

The main building has 200 comfortable, centrally-heated single rooms, each with hot and cold water basins. Showers, baths, and toilets are at the end of all corridors. The hotel has a shop, sitting rooms, four TV rooms, a table tennis room, a library, and a laundry. There are also eight pianos for guests to use. There is parking available in the hotel drive. Free daily newspapers are provided, and you can buy stamps at the office.

Guests staying for a long time must pay for their stay weekly in advance and give one week's notice before leaving. Both short-term and long-term guests are welcome, but long-term guests get room priority. Meal times are: breakfast from 7 am to 9:30 am, lunch from 1 pm to 2 pm, and dinner from 5:30 pm to 7 pm. During the week, if you are studying or working late, you can request dinner until 11 pm by writing your name on the late list or calling before 7 pm. There are 10 menu choices for breakfast and dinner.

No animals or fires (for cooking or heating) are allowed, and guests should respect others' comfort. If you have tapes or CDs, please keep the noise down, especially between 11 pm and 8 am. If you arrive by train, it is best to take a taxi to the hotel because it is far from the main railway station.

Tom Cruise is one of the most successful actors in movie history. But his life wasn't always easy. When he was a young boy, Tom was shy and had trouble making friends, even though he loved acting in school plays. After finishing high school, Tom moved to New York to find work. He got a job as a porter and also took drama classes. In 1980, film director Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. Ten years later, he became so successful that he was one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood, earning millions of dollars for each movie. Today, Tom still acts in movies and is very popular with his many fans from all over the world.

Title: "Little Cat, Little Cat, Where Have You Been?"

When Bo the cat decided to explore a furniture van, she had a bigger adventure than she expected. The driver found her after he had driven over 500 kilometers. It was the end of a long day, and both the driver and the cat were hungry! He gave her some milk and started asking around. He called his last customers, but none of them had lost a cat. It was getting late, so he took Bo home for the night. The next morning, he took her to an animal hospital.

Meanwhile, Bo's owner was also trying to find her. After looking everywhere, he remembered the furniture van that had delivered something to a neighbor. Luckily, he remembered the name of the company. He called their office, and soon Bo was safely returned to him.

The Ghan Train

Mark Ottaway traveled by train from Darwin in northern Australia to Adelaide in the south. The Ghan train crosses Australia from the warm north coast through endless desert to the colder Southern Ocean. It is often called the 'famous Ghan', but it is known for being late. The idea of a rail link between Darwin and Adelaide started in the 1920s with a line from Adelaide to Alice Springs. However, this line often had serious flooding, making it hard for trains to pass. A new line was finished a few months before my trip. The railway was built for speeds up to 115 kph, but the Ghan is not a high-speed train. There are few stops, and most passengers are on holiday. The Ghan does not offer luxury like the Orient Express, but the food on board is excellent. The railway was originally built to carry goods, not passengers. It was thought that sending goods from Europe to Australia's south via Darwin and the train, instead of by ship around the continent, would save time and money. A transcontinental railway is rare, and the Ghan claims to be the world's first north-south one. As I waited to board the Ghan, I saw that everyone was excited about the journey. Most of my fellow travelers were Australian pensioners who were eager to board. Our first stop was at Katherine, where the Ghan waited for four hours. Some passengers got off to take a boat trip up the gorge. I stayed on the train until Alice Springs, where I went on a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group and a guide. Climbing the rock is not encouraged now, and few people do it. Our group walked around the rock and watched the beautiful sunset. From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week going south, so many passengers stop their journey here. The view from the train after Alice Springs is not very interesting. There is a lot of flat land with only cattle to see. But at dawn on the third day, we reached the foothills near the Southern Ocean. My journey was over, and although the train might not have delivered everything the advertisements promised, it took me to some of the most amazing sights in Australia.

Climbing to the Top of Britain

Every year, thousands of people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. Because it is far north, the weather can be very cold. Climber Keith Hewitt talks about his first time climbing Ben Nevis. It was February, and it was my first big winter climb. We planned to climb the north side of the mountain to Tower Ridge. This climb is 600 meters high and is probably the longest climb in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries', which are like big bowls in the mountain walls halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. You need these spikes because the snow can be so hard it feels like ice. Even though some people in our group were very experienced, we packed all kinds of safety equipment, like lights to get attention, hard hats, and extra clothes. The weather forecast was perfect, with no strong winds, but we still felt nervous when we started. Climbing Ben Nevis in winter is always a challenge. 

The path soon went up, and my legs felt tired. I was the weakest in the group, so I had to rest more often. The others sometimes stopped to let me catch up, but as soon as I reached them, they started again. I promised myself that I would always train properly before a climb in the future. After 200 meters, we reached the start of Tower Ridge, the path that would take us to the top of Ben Nevis. It is only one and a half meters wide, and the mountain drops hundreds of meters on each side. We knew we had to stay calm and focus on every step as we moved slowly along it. After seven hours of climbing, we reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and all the way to the island of Skye, 48 kilometers away. However, we were not so lucky because a mist came down. On Ben Nevis, going back down to camp can be as challenging as going up. You need to read a map well because a wrong turn could lead to slopes that are too dangerous to go down in winter. I was glad we decided to take turns doing that job. That first time, I only felt I enjoyed the experience when I was safe in the tent. But at least I made it to the top.

Anna's New School

This week has been very exciting because we just moved into our new school building! It's an amazing place. The builders used wood for the whole building, just like our old school. But this new school is special because it is one of the first in our country to be very environmentally friendly. It took months to build, so we watched it being built. It was exciting to see the builders clear the land for the school, although it meant losing some nice open space. The noise from the building machines was very loud, and the builders often had to stop because of heavy rain. We started to think the building would never be finished.

Now, we have five classrooms, which are much bigger than the ones in our old school next door, which was very old. We share one room with people from the town when they need it for meetings. There is also a nursery, a nice dining room, and big changing rooms that we are excited to use once our new sports field is ready.

When you enter the school, you will notice there are no heaters! Instead, the heat comes from us - the children, the teachers, and the computers. The building is designed to keep all the heat inside, and it keeps the sound in too. So, when we sing in our classrooms, it feels like we are in a concert hall!

Another interesting thing is that there is a tree on the school roof! The builders put it there because it is a tradition in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for lights and computers comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We visited it with our teacher yesterday, and it spins very fast. It's so big that you can see it from far away! We took some pictures to put on our website.

Even though we are already using the new school building, some parts are still being added. For example, we are putting on a play for parents, but we have to go back to our old school hall to do it. The new hall will be ready next year. We are very happy with our new school, and our teachers say we will learn much faster here!

**International Book Club**

Have you ever thought about joining a book club and buying new books by mail? At the International Book Club, many members already buy books from us this way.

**To join:**

Simply send us your first order from our book list.

**Immediate benefits:**

As a special offer, you can choose any discounted books from our new members' book list, up to a total value of £6 (plus postage and packing). This way, you will save money compared to the publishers' prices. Tick the box on your form to order a free watch. If you reply within seven days, we will send you another free gift, carefully chosen from our book list by our staff. You can also order a DVD from our list at half the recommended retail price.

**When you've joined:**

As a member, you'll save between 30% and 50% off the publisher's price on every book you buy, and they will be delivered straight to your door. You will receive a free club magazine once a month, which will keep you updated with the latest best-sellers. Every year, we offer over 1,000 books to choose from. You can find all our titles for the year on our exclusive members' website.

**Being a member:**

All we ask is that you choose four books during your first year. After that, you can decide how many books you want to buy. In each monthly club magazine, our experienced staff select a Club Choice book—a fiction or reference book they think is especially worth buying, offered at a special price. If you do not want this book, just indicate this in the space provided on the form. We will send the book if we do not receive your response.

So, return your application form today, but hurry—offers like this don't come every day. To apply, simply fill in the enclosed form and return it in the postage-paid envelope provided. Soon, your books will be with you. Please don't send any money now; we will send you the bill with the books. Remember, you have up to two weeks to decide if you want to keep the books you ordered. You can then either return the books or send your payment.

Text: 'No Title A month ago, I never thought that on a Saturday afternoon in November, I would be hanging 30 meters above the ground and enjoying it. Now, as I looked down at the river far below, I understood why people love rock climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The accommodation wasn't great, but we had everything we needed: beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be out of the city and in the fresh air. On Saturday morning, we met the other ten people in our group. Cameron came with two friends, Kevin and Simon, while sisters Carole and Lynn came with Amanda. We all came from different places, and none of us knew the area. We knew we would spend the weekend outdoors, but we weren't sure exactly what we would do. Half of us spent the morning caving, while the others went rock climbing, and then we switched at lunchtime. Matt and I went to the caves first. Climbing out was harder than going in, but after a lot of effort, we finally got out. We were covered in mud but felt happy and excited about what we had done.'

Text: 'Letter to the Newport Evening News On Saturday afternoon, I left my handbag on the bus. Inside it were my cheque book, address book, and my purse, which had about £50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized what I had done, it was too late. I didn't know what to do: I'm 72 years old, I was far from home, and I was very worried. I stood by the side of the road and cried. A young man asked me what was wrong, and I explained what had happened. He gave me some money for my bus fare home. When I told the bus driver what had happened, he said I should keep the fare. I got home safely, and soon after, the telephone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that owned the bus where I left my handbag. He said they had my handbag and offered to drive over to return it. I got my handbag back, amazingly with everything inside untouched. I would like to say how wonderful everyone was who helped me that day, and how much I appreciate their kindness and honesty. Mrs. B. James, Newport'

Sharks

Sharks are some of the scariest animals in the ocean. They are very good at finding food underwater because they can see well and feel movement with special lines on the sides of their bodies. This makes sharks very dangerous for smaller sea animals that they eat.

Sharks are like other fish in some ways, but their bodies are different. For example, most sharks need to swim all the time to breathe and stay alive, so they almost never sleep. Also, if you turn a shark over on its back, it can stop moving completely. This is helpful for scientists who study sharks because it lets them learn more about these interesting animals.

Text: 'Joining the Kirov Ballet I'm Nathalie. Last year, I became one of the youngest foreign students to join the Kirov's ballet school in St Petersburg, Russia. At my first ballet class, I was nervous because I didn't know anyone. Everyone gathered around and asked me questions in Russian. I tried to speak Russian, and then they started talking in English, so we could communicate. Now, six months later, everyone is really nice to me, my Russian has improved a lot, and I understand my teachers. For the first two weeks after I arrived, my mum stayed with me, and when she left, I felt a bit sad. I even called home late at night once to talk to her because I felt a little lonely. Compared to my ballet school in England, the classes in Russia are really hard, and I eat a lot to keep my energy up. That makes me confident I can meet the school's high standards. In the evenings, I watch my favorite films on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before the DVD finishes. Now that I've settled in, I feel really at home here. I like walking around the city and visiting different shops, even in December when I couldn't believe how cold it was. I decided to buy a fur hat because it was minus 10°C, but the Russians said it was mild for that time of year! At least my room was warm and cozy. Right now, we are preparing for a new production, and there's also a competition for young dancers that I'm going to enter. I feel so lucky to be here.'

**THE ICEHOTEL**

For many years, people visited the Arctic in the summer to see the land of the midnight sun. In winter, only a few people lived there, enjoying the snow and ice alone. By the late 1980s, people thought the dark and cold winter could be a good thing. In the winter of 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit opened an art show in a special igloo (a snow building) in Jukkasjarvi, a small town on the frozen Torne River. This building, called Arctic Hall, attracted many visitors. One night, some foreign guests decided to sleep in the Arctic Hall. The next morning, they were very happy with their experience, and the idea of an ice hotel was born. Today, it is famous worldwide.

When winter starts, a team of snow builders, architects, and artists from around the world come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel for that year. As soon as one part is finished, it opens to visitors and overnight guests, while other parts are still being built. The first part is ready in December, and each week a new part opens until January 7th, when the hotel is complete. Since the ICEHOTEL is built outside with natural winter materials, the finishing date can change because of the weather. In spring, when it gets warmer, the hotel melts.

Inside the hotel, the temperature is always between -5°C and -8°C, no matter how cold it is outside. Warm clothes like overalls, hats, and gloves are included in the cost of staying at the hotel. Guests should also bring sweaters, a scarf, and lots of wool socks. It's a good idea to wear shoes that are bigger than usual to fit thick socks. If you plan to visit the hotel, you can buy warm sweaters, wool socks, and more on the ICEHOTEL website. You can order these items when you book your visit, and they will be delivered to your room when you check in.

The hotel is in the village of Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle, but only 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. You can arrange bus transport from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.

Text: 'Shopping for furniture A report by Dave Worthington Homestyle, a new furniture store, had to close soon after it opened at midnight last Thursday. Up to 6,000 people rushed to the store. There were many special deals, like a leather sofa for £45 (only until 3 am) and a bed for £30 (only between 3 am and 8 am). The store's regular hours will be 9 am to 9 pm every day, but Homestyle had said it would stay open for the first 24 hours. However, it had to close within half an hour of opening. A police officer who came to the store said: 'The police knew a big crowd was expected, but people were not patient. The store filled up quickly, and the managers wisely decided to close the doors. The people outside got angry because they thought everything would be sold before they could get in, and they refused to wait quietly until there was room for them inside. Another problem was the long line of cars trying to reach the parking lot. What surprised me was that many people left their cars in the middle of the road and walked the last few meters to the store. This caused the road to be completely blocked.' One customer, Jenny Smith, who got into the store, said: 'I waited for three hours and didn't have time to buy what I wanted. But the staff were very calm and explained what was happening. They had no choice, as it wasn't safe. So I'll come back when they reopen, but I won't wait in line again.'

The Short Story Society helps writers in Britain today. It started in 1899 and is now one of Britain's most active arts groups.

**Society Magazines**  
We create several great magazines, including the popular Short Story Review. This magazine has short stories by some of Britain's best writers and gives new writers a chance to have their work published. Another magazine, Short Story News, includes interviews with writers and lots of information about events, competitions, festivals, and the writing world. You can read some articles from recent issues by following the links on this website.

**National Short Story Competition**  
We organize the National Short Story Competition, the largest of its kind. It is open to anyone aged 18 and over, and you can write about any topic. Stories should be between 1,000 and 1,500 words long. Members of the Society do not pay an entry fee, but non-members pay £5. The competition runs from April to the end of October each year. The ten best stories will be published in the Society's annual book of short stories. The winner will get a publishing contract to create their own collection of short stories.

**Education**  
For almost thirty years, the Society has brought writers into classrooms, giving children and teachers new ideas and helping them feel more confident in their writing. Current projects include the Young Writer of the Year, which started in 1998 and is open to writers aged 11-18. Winners receive book prizes and can attend a five-day course taught by professional writers.

**The Writers' Cafe**  
The Writers' Cafe is the social center of the Society. It is relaxed and stylish, with freshly cooked vegetarian food, excellent coffees, and cold drinks. It is a great place to read the Society's magazines. The Cafe also offers monthly exhibitions, short courses, and readings. It is located in the heart of London and is open from 11:00 am to 10:00 pm Monday to Friday and 11:00 am to 8:00 pm on Saturday. Society members get discounts on selected products and events.

**Becoming a Member**  
We have members all over the world, and anyone aged eighteen or over can join. If you want to join The Short Story Society, click here and fill out a registration form.

Tanya Streeter is a famous free-diver with four world records. Free-diving is a sport where people dive deep into the ocean on one breath. In 2003, Tanya made history by diving 120 meters deep and returning to the surface without help. She had gone deeper the year before but used a balloon to come back up. This time, she held her breath for over three and a half minutes, becoming the first woman to break a man's world record in any sport. Fourteen safety divers watched her dive at different depths. Some people think free-diving is too dangerous because of accidents, but Tanya believes safety and training are most important.

Most free-divers focus on one or two types of events, but Tanya's training routine stays the same. She spends two-thirds of her time training on land at the gym and the rest in the pool and ocean. She uses an exercise bike to improve her heart fitness but avoids running to protect her knees. Instead, she prefers fast walking to stay fit. When she practices diving, she usually travels away from home. She aims to do fourteen dives over four weeks, with a rest day between each dive to avoid getting tired.

When not training, Tanya often appears in public to promote sports products and supports environmental causes by doing research or making films. Growing up on Grand Cayman in the Caribbean, she loved swimming and exploring rock pools. Tanya says her life now is like living her childhood dreams. She is well-known in some countries, so people listen to her about environmental issues. In her thirties, Tanya plans to keep breaking her own records. She started free-diving at twenty-five and doesn't plan to retire soon.

CARTOON FILMS

Cartoon films have very few limits. If you can draw something, you can make it move on the movie screen. With new ideas and advanced computer programs, cartoons are becoming exciting again for people of all ages. By the end of the 1970s, people in the movie industry thought cartoons were only for children. But soon after, a few directors came up with some new ideas. They showed that it was possible to make films that both adults and children could enjoy together. However, not every cartoon film was a success. For example, The Black Cauldron did not do well because it was too scary for children and too childish for adults. Directors learned from this mistake, and film companies started making a lot of money again.

Title: New TV Star Caroline Benson Talks About Her First TV Role

Caroline Benson shares her experience of acting in her first TV role. She says, "I never thought I would spend part of my first year at university filming The Finnegans. I had only acted in school plays before, but I loved the book since I was eleven. My grandmother always said I was like Polly Finnegan, and I dreamed of playing her. 

Before starting university, I took a year off to travel. While I was in Chile, my mother emailed me about plans to make the book into a TV show. I knew I had to try for the role. My mother was surprised but sent my photo to the director and convinced him to meet me. I flew back and got the part. 

The outdoor filming began a week after university started, so I got permission to be away for three weeks. When I returned, I woke up at 6:00 am to catch up on my essays. I didn't tell my university friends about the filming, but they found out and thought it was amazing. It was a fantastic experience, and I feel very lucky. 

After university, I definitely want to pursue acting as a career. I don't come from an acting family, although my grandfather was an opera singer. I've tried for other TV roles but haven't received any offers yet. I don't know how I managed everything because I also had a busy social life. When filming ended, I didn't know what to do with my time. Since then, I've acted in two college plays. Unfortunately, I haven't been home much, and now that my first year at university is over, I'm going to Greece for the summer with friends."

Text: 'No Title When I opened the first 'Body Shop' in 1976, my main goal was to make enough money to support my children. Today, 'The Body Shop' is a company that is growing quickly all over the world. Since we started, I have learned a lot. Many of these lessons are in this book because I believe our company has important ideas about running a successful business while staying true to our values. This is not a typical business book, and it's not just about my life. The main idea is that to succeed in business, you need to be different. Business can be enjoyable, it can be run with care, and it can have a positive impact. In business, just like in life, I need to have fun, feel like part of a family, and be excited by new things. I have always wanted the people who work for 'The Body Shop' to feel the same way. Now, this book shares my ideas with the world. I like to think there are no limits to our 'family' and no limits to what we can achieve. I find that thought exciting, and I hope you do, too.'

Title: A Journey Along the Beautiful Douro River

Jules Verne offers a 'hotel ship' experience on the Douro River in Portugal. The ship, MV Lady Ivy May, can host 160 guests in double cabins. Each cabin has a private shower and toilet, and all cabins face outside. The ship is air-conditioned and includes a sun deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library.

Itinerary:

Day 1: Depart from London Heathrow to Oporto in the early evening. A guide will meet you and take you to the Lady Ivy May, where you will stay overnight.

Day 2: Spend the morning sightseeing in Oporto. Return to the ship and travel to Entre-os-Rios, a four-hour journey up the river.

Day 3: Continue traveling up the river. In the early evening, stop at Peso da Regua, known for port wine. Enjoy local food and drink at dinner.

Day 4: After breakfast, take a bus to the ancient town of Lamego. Visit the cathedral, several churches, and a museum, which was once a palace and now has a great collection of art. Return to the ship and sail to Tua.

Day 5: The Douro River becomes narrow here. Depending on the river's depth, you might continue by a smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. Return to Tua by coach, with many sights to see along the way.

Day 6: In the morning, drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for a stunning view of the Douro Valley. Return to the ship for lunch, then take a scenic train ride through the Douro Valley to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will be waiting.

Day 7: Visit Vila Real before returning to the ship for lunch. Then, travel down the river to Oporto and spend the night on the Lady Ivy May.

Day 8: Arrive in Oporto with time for sightseeing and shopping before flying back to London Heathrow.

HONEY

Honey is a sweet liquid made by bees. It is made of water and sugars. Bees can travel up to 75,000 kilometers and visit over two million flowers to make just half a kilo of honey. The color and taste of honey depend on the type of flower the bees visit. There are more than 300 types of honey. Lighter-colored honey usually has a milder taste than darker honey. In ancient times, honey was the main sweet food because sugar was very rare. Honey was very valuable to the ancient Egyptians, who even used it as money. Today, honey is made and eaten all over the world. Research shows that it can help prevent tiredness and improve athletic performance. But honey is not just food - it can also be used for sore throats and is an ingredient in many skin and hair-care products.

Norwich, the capital of East Anglia in Britain, has been a place to live for over two thousand years. It started as a small village by the River Wensum. By the time of the Norman invasion in 1066, it had become one of the largest towns in England. Norwich has been a popular center for different religions, with two cathedrals and a mosque. The first cathedral was built in 1095 and recently celebrated its 900th anniversary. In 1994, Norwich celebrated the 800th anniversary of receiving a Royal Charter, which allowed it to be called a city and govern itself.

Today, Norwich is quite small compared to cities like London or Manchester, with a population of about 150,000. However, in the 16th century, it was the second-largest city in England. It continued to grow and became wealthy, known for having as many churches as there are weeks in the year and as many pubs as there are days in the year. Now, there are fewer churches and pubs, but in 1964, the University of East Anglia was built in Norwich. With a growing student population and success as a modern commercial center, Norwich offers a wide range of entertainment: theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, busy cafes, excellent restaurants, and arts and leisure centers. The city also has a football team called 'The Canaries', with green and yellow colors, though the reason for the name is unclear.

One of the city's attractions is a modern shopping center called 'The Castle Mall'. For over two years, the people of Norwich lived with a large hole in the middle of their city as builders worked on the main car park. They moved nearly a million tons of earth so that the roof of the Mall could become a city center park with water pools and trees. The local people are happy that the old open market remains next to the new development. Both areas are successful, showing that Norwich has managed to combine the best of the old and the new.

The Albuquerque Balloon Festival

Every autumn, the sky above Albuquerque, a city in the southwestern United States, fills with bright colors. This is because of the Albuquerque Balloon Festival, a nine-day event held every year. The first festival was in 1972 to celebrate the 50th birthday of a local radio station. Back then, about twelve hot-air balloons took off from a parking lot in the middle of Albuquerque. Since then, the festival has grown a lot. This year, at least a thousand balloons from over a third of the countries in the world are expected at the current location outside the city.

What to See

The pilots of the balloons stay in contact with each other by radio and light up their burners at the same time. This is called a 'balloon glow' and is a great chance to take amazing photos. To see these 'glows,' you need to arrive just after nightfall or before 5:30 am when the balloons rise into the dark sky. During the day, you can walk among the balloons and talk to the pilots as they get ready to take off. The balloons come in many sizes and colors, and some are shaped like animals, cartoon characters, or famous products like soft drinks and fast food. Kids will really enjoy it.

In the afternoon, you can take a balloon flight over the desert with one of the many companies offering rides. Another option is to take a cable car from the desert floor to the top of the nearby mountains. This is the longest cable car ride anywhere and offers a great view of the festival. There are many other attractions for visitors of all ages, including balloon races and fireworks on the opening night and the last three nights of the festival.

The Albuquerque Box

This is a local wind pattern that is perfect for balloonists. The Sandia Mountains protect the balloons from strong winds and create gentle wind currents at different heights. This allows skilled pilots to control the direction of their balloons by going up or down.

Practical Advice

Buy your tickets in advance online to avoid long lines at the festival site. Wear several layers of thin clothing because it can be cool at night and in the early morning, but during the day, you will need sunglasses and sunscreen. Bring a flashlight for night events and, of course, your camera. If you are not using a digital camera, you will need high-speed film for evening and night pictures.

The Eden Project

Since it opened, the Eden Project in the south-west of England has become one of the UK's most popular places for tourists to visit. At first glance, the large 'biospheres' on this old industrial site look like something from a science-fiction movie. Each biosphere has a different climate zone, showing visitors how important the relationship between people and plants is. It is surprising to see how many products we use every day come from plants, like wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate. There are over 135,000 different types of plants grown here. Even if the weather is cold outside, computer-controlled electric heaters keep the plants at the right temperature. In the Rainforest Zone, the air is always damp because of a big waterfall. Another zone copies the environment of the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa, and there are plans to build a desert zone soon.

Text: 'No Title Some people have complained about this year's collection, New Writing 3, but I don't understand why. Having 500 pages of original writing for just £6.99 is amazing! Most of the book is fiction, with parts of novels and complete short stories. There are enjoyable pieces by famous writers like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain. Interestingly, the less famous writers seem to write mostly about food. Be careful with Jane Harris's Those Nails - don't read it right after eating. It has some very unpleasant scenes that might upset your stomach! There is also great work from nineteen poets, including R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. You can find parts of novels being written by Jim Crace and Jane Rogers. Lastly, there is a bit of non-fiction, including a very funny article by Alan Rusbridger about some newspapers, and an extraordinary piece about herself by Ursula Owen. This is an exceptional collection, and I can't wait to see what next year's collection will have.'

Text: "The best age to start learning the violin is between three and six," says Margaret Porter, a violinist and music teacher. "This is when you are learning about the world." Margaret, who lives in London, likes to start teaching children at three or four years old, but she sometimes makes exceptions for eager five-year-olds. When she began teaching the violin in 1972, her first class was made up of her children's five-year-old school friends. 

Margaret's students have group lessons. Each group has about twelve students, and each lesson lasts an hour, once every two weeks. In addition, each student has one individual lesson with her every week. Parents also need to attend the classes. It is important that parents show interest in the lessons. From the beginning, students learn to play by ear. They do not try to read music until they have been playing for several years, and for a long time, there is a big difference between their playing and reading of music. Margaret says her method is not meant to create great violinists, and she often suggests that students who do very well should leave and study the violin using more traditional methods.

Moonshine The band Moonshine released their third CD last week. "Here Again" is a follow-up to "The Waves." There have been some changes since the last CD. Tom Wilcott is now playing bass guitar, replacing Simon McVee, who left the band last year. Tom Simpson has joined as the drummer. From the first song, which is a dance tune, it's clear that the band is moving away from slow songs. The second song is also a dance tune and is even louder and heavier. Most of the later songs are in the band's usual slow style. These two dance tracks will surprise many fans, but they could easily become hit singles because they are excellent. Singer Rob Letchford shows his talent by hitting every note perfectly. Fans should be thankful he recorded the songs before he had throat problems. This issue has caused the band to cancel their next tour. (Anyone who bought tickets should not worry because all the concerts will be rescheduled once Rob recovers.) On this CD, Moonshine shows they can make great music in different styles, from the slow ones we know to the ones that make you want to dance. However, I felt that the best songs were at the beginning, and the last few tracks were not as good. Despite this, "Here Again" is sure to be a big hit and bring more success to the band.

San Francisco

San Francisco is on the coast of northern California. The first Europeans to find the area were led by a Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola. He first saw it in 1769. Interestingly, even though San Francisco Bay is a great natural harbor, it was discovered from the land, not the sea. In 1849, thousands of people came to San Francisco hoping to find gold. But it wasn't the gold seekers who became rich. The richest people made money by owning banks and law firms, and they built big houses on a hill called Nob Hill. Today, tourists visit San Francisco to see famous places like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Many also take a short boat trip to Alcatraz Island to see the old prison.

Text: 'SAMUEL PEPYS The most famous diary in English was written by Samuel Pepys. It gives a detailed and interesting description of everyday life in England between 1660 and 1669. Pepys writes about important news stories of the time, like disease, an enemy navy sailing up the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also writes about himself, even about his faults - he often slept during church or looked at the pretty girls. He describes his home life - a quarrel with his wife and how they became friends again, and his worry about her illness. Besides books, he liked music, the theatre, card games, and parties with good food and lots of fun. Pepys was a busy man who had many important jobs - he was a Member of Parliament and President of the Royal Society. He is also remembered for his work for the British Navy.'

The History of Shoes

In the past, people didn't care if shoes were comfortable or stylish. Early shoes were probably made from animal skins that people wrapped around their ankles when it was cold. We still use leather today, but other materials like silk, plastic, or cotton are also popular, depending on what is trendy.

It was only 150 years ago that people started wearing different shoes on each foot. Before that, both shoes were straight and could be worn on either the left or right foot. All shoes used to be made by hand, but now, even though some shoemakers still use traditional skills, most shoes are made by machines in big factories. The invention of sewing machines helped the shoe industry make a lot of cheaper shoes for more people.

When I hurt my back, I had to stop my running career for a while. I wanted to help more women try running, to show them how fun it can be and to help them feel confident to start running. I decided to create a running club for women in my area because I was frustrated with how some race organizers acted. They often complain that not many women join races, but they also don't provide separate changing rooms for women. I put up posters, and 40 women joined the club. They were of different ages and fitness levels. Most of them wanted to lose weight, but I don't think they had really thought about running before. When they did think about it, they imagined it would be hard and painful. They didn't think about running while chatting and smiling in beautiful places, like by a river. At first, they could only run for one minute, but now they can run for thirty minutes. They have also learned from other runners about healthy eating and staying fit. I wanted to support women's running, and I have enjoyed watching their progress almost as much as they have enjoyed it themselves.

**THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD - THE LAST GREAT RACE ON EARTH**

In the 1880s, gold was found in Alaska, the most northern state of the USA. Many people went there hoping to become rich. New towns were quickly built and grew fast. One of these towns was called Iditarod, which means 'far, distant place'. In 1909, Iditarod grew so fast that it briefly became the largest city in Alaska. 

During the summer, boats could bring important supplies to these towns. But in winter, the rivers and ocean froze, making it impossible to reach them. So, in 1910, a winter trail was created for teams of dogs pulling sleds. They carried mail, food, and clothes to the gold miners. This trail was called the Iditarod Trail. It took about three weeks for a team of dogs to travel across Alaska. They stopped at 'roadhouses' where the drivers could rest and eat, and feed their dogs.
