The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when airplanes replaced steam boats and dog teams as the main way to travel. However, the dogs had one last important job in 1925 when a disease called diphtheria hit the city of Nome. The disease could be treated, but the nearest medicine was in Anchorage, on the other side of Alaska. Airplanes were still new, and it was uncertain if they could fly in such cold weather. Also, Carl Eielson, the only pilot skilled enough for the flight, was away. So, it was decided to use dog teams to transport the medicine. 

The journey was over 1,000 kilometers, mostly along the Iditarod Trail. It took twenty teams just six days to complete it. Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian who came to Alaska for gold, traveled the first 400 kilometers. He relied on his dog Togo to guide him through the blinding snow, and Togo proved to be a reliable guide. The last part of the journey was done by Gunnar Kaasen, who had driven dog teams in Alaska for 21 years. His lead dog was Balto. At one point, Balto refused to go further, saving the team from falling into icy water. The diphtheria was stopped, and Balto became a hero.

Today, a dog sled race is held every year from Anchorage to Nome, following the route of that famous 1925 journey. It is called the Iditarod and is known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth'.

Sweden's Ice Hotel

The village of Jukkasjärvi is in Swedish Lapland, where winter temperatures can drop to -40°C. Despite the cold, 6,000 tourists visit every year to see one of Europe's most unique hotels. In this hotel, you can eat, drink, and sleep in rooms made of ice. You can even get married there if you want. The bar is also made of ice, so it's not a good idea to put hot drinks on it! The bedrooms are about -4°C, but guests get special sleeping bags to stay warm. If needed, the hotel can also provide warm outdoor clothes. The hotel is never older than six months because it melts in the summer and is rebuilt each winter. Building the hotel requires 10,000 tonnes of ice and 30,000 tonnes of snow.

Maria Mutola

In 1988, Maria Mutola was the only girl playing football on an all-boys team in a local competition in Mozambique. "We won," she said. "At first, no one thought it was a problem that I was a girl. But then the team we beat complained." A local newspaper wrote about the story, and Jose Craveirinha, who had helped other African athletes, heard about Maria. He went to see her and found her playing football outside the club. He quickly saw that she was very fast. "He talked to me about athletics. I didn't know what he meant. The only sport I knew was football. Then he bought me running shoes and took me to train. It was very hard work, and my legs hurt a lot."

Jose visited her parents and convinced them that Maria could be successful in athletics and that it could help their family out of poverty. They agreed to let him take her to train. In 1991, she finally accepted an offer to train in the United States. She had said no before because she knew she would miss her family. Her life was very different from the girls she met in the US. She says, "They were good athletes, but while I worried about my parents having enough to eat, they worried about dresses and make-up. They knew very little about me and even less about my problems. But I knew I was lucky to be there. The trainers were excellent, and I learned a lot."

Today, Maria still runs, and for most of the year, she lives happily in South Africa with her mother.

The Skywalk

The Grand Canyon in the United States was formed by the Colorado River. People visit the Grand Canyon Park to walk, run, and especially to enjoy the view. The view is amazing, and the Skywalk makes it even better. The Skywalk is 1219 meters above the bottom of the Grand Canyon. It is a platform with glass walls and a glass floor, so you can see the beautiful rocks below. Up to 120 people can stand on it at the same time. It opened in 2007, and since then, thousands of people have visited it. You need to wear special shoe covers to protect the glass from scratches. Walking on the Skywalk makes you feel like a bird flying high in the sky.

THE ROCKIES

The Rocky Mountains stretch almost the entire length of North America. They begin in the northwest but are only a few hundred miles from the center in the more southern parts. Even though the Rockies are smaller than the Alps, they are just as amazing. There are many roads through the Rockies, but the best way to see them is by train. You start your journey in Vancouver, which is one of Canada's most beautiful big cities. This city is special because it is close to both the ocean and the mountains. People living in Vancouver can go skiing just 15 minutes by car from the city center. In the past, thirty passenger trains left Vancouver every day on the cross-continent railway. Now, there are only three trains a week, but the trip is still a great adventure. You can sleep on the train, which is fun, but some of the most beautiful views are at night.

Text: 'ZOOS People started keeping animals in zoos over 3,000 years ago. The rulers of China created a large zoo called the Gardens of Intelligence. In the early zoos, animals were often trained to perform tricks for visitors. This does not happen anymore because now zoos aim to show animals behaving naturally. Today, most cities have a zoo or wildlife park. However, not everyone agrees with the idea of zoos. People who support zoos say they help us learn about nature and allow us to see wild animals up close, which we couldn't do otherwise. On the other hand, some people are against zoos because they think it is wrong to keep animals in cages. They also argue that in poorly managed zoos, animals live in dirty conditions and eat the wrong food.'

JAZZ By Katie Atkins, aged 14

I play the trumpet in my school's jazz band. Last month, we had a jazz competition with bands from local high schools, and our band won! Each band wore different costumes. My band wore black school uniforms, while others wore bright T-shirts. We didn't look like adult professional bands, but we were used to performing in competitions. The quality of playing was amazing, especially since everyone was so young. Players from each band even made up new tunes right there on stage. It was exciting to watch, but even better when my band played!

We have a great jazz band at my school, but not everyone who wants to join can. Only about half get accepted. However, anyone who is eager to play can go to jazz practice before school. We also spend time together after school, listening to jazz and learning about it. There are trips to jazz summer camps across the country. I've been to a couple and learned a lot.

Adults are often surprised that young people are interested in jazz. My music teacher thinks it's because pop music isn't challenging enough for people like me who are serious about music. I find jazz exciting because it's both new and old. You can create your own music, but you also feel part of its history, playing on stage like great jazz performers before you.

My school is really lucky because we have great teachers and parents who support us. Without them, we wouldn't get far with our music!

Text: 'Watering the Desert In Marrakesh, Morocco, it can rain anytime between November and March. However, it doesn't rain often, and when it does, the city's water pipes can't handle the sudden floods, turning streets into rivers. Recently, many winters have been dry, so when it rains, the local people are happy. Marrakesh's parks and gardens don't rely on rain. Instead, they get water from a network of underground channels dug in the 11th century. These channels bring water from the mountains all year. Places that are usually dry but get water this way are called oases. If you travel further south from Marrakesh, you reach Skoura. Here, every piece of land is divided into small squares by water channels and used to grow food. The Atlas mountains, covered in snow during winter, provide a beautiful background.'

Gareth Ellis is 13 years old and the youngest son of Alan, an engineer, and Kath, a nursery teacher. His older brothers work in banking and computers, but Gareth always wanted to be a clown. Three years ago, Alan, Kath, and Gareth joined the circus. "People laugh when we tell them," says Kath. "But it's true. Gareth has wanted to be a clown since we took him to the circus when he was three." When Alan lost his job, he and Kath decided to try to find full-time jobs in a circus. They both got jobs with a famous circus, and Gareth started training to become a clown. He calls himself Bippo. They travel with the circus during the summer and go back home for the winter. Gareth's brothers are old enough to take care of the house while they are away. "I can't say it was easy," says Kath. "There was a lot to think about and organize. We only had a car and a very small caravan to sleep in, and we were leaving our lovely house. The only thing Gareth missed was his long, hot baths." "People ask about my education," says Gareth, "but from the beginning, wherever we go, someone has always come to teach me. I use the same books as everyone back at school, and I have a computer. I've never fallen behind my classmates." And the future? "It was a difficult decision," says Kath, "but there was no other way to teach Gareth about being a clown. I'm happy to say it's working, and we're enjoying it." And Gareth? "I'm going to be the main clown in a circus one day," he says, "maybe Bippo's circus."

Eight-eighteen News

Eight-eighteen News is a news agency for young people aged 8 to 18. We gather news and write reports, stories, and articles. We send these to big and local newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, and websites to be published. You can read or listen to the news stories and articles by our members on the Eight-eighteen website if they are accepted by newspapers and TV or radio stations.

We have three centers around the country where young people can meet other members and join projects. We plan to open more centers across the country. Our news agency started in 1994, and we were first called 'Young News'. Since then, over 2,500 young people have been members.

Sophie, a former member, says: "I first heard about Eight-eighteen when they interviewed me for an article about young people's opinions on hip hop music. I was amazed by the opportunities the young journalists had. Age didn't matter; they were trusted to do the stories on their own. I started going to the Eight-eighteen center in my city, got some training, and was a member until I was 18. Eight-eighteen helped me achieve more than I thought possible. With the skills I learned, I got a job at 19 and am now the youngest employee at a major news website, checking articles before they go online."

Get involved at every level

When you join Eight-eighteen, you'll receive training and attend monthly meetings to decide who will write each news story. Eight-eighteen encourages members to share skills. 'Peer trainers' are experienced members aged 12 and over who train new members in basic journalism skills. As they gain more experience, some members present sessions to young people and adults outside Eight-eighteen, often in youth clubs and summer camps. These young trainers are supported by older staff who go with them on these trips.

Eight-eighteen News holds training sessions for new members three times a year. Our next training for new members will be in February. If you or someone you know is interested in joining, call Director Den Ley at 01622 657874 for more information. The Eight-eighteen program is suitable for children with all levels of reading and writing skills. Membership is free, and there is no test to join.

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights Website**

Welcome to our website. Here is what you need to know before booking a flight.

**About the Flights**

During the short Antarctic summer, we offer sightseeing flights from Sydney, Australia, over Antarctica and back. We use a large passenger plane, a Boeing 747. Flight dates for next year are not set yet, but if you book now, you can change your booking if we need to change the date.

**Frequently Asked Questions**

**How long is the flight?**

The flight lasts about 12 hours. After about four hours, we usually see the first sea ice and icebergs. We spend four hours flying over Antarctica and the rest of the time returning home. During the flight, experts who have lived in Antarctica give talks about the environment and history and answer questions. A camera near the pilot shows you the view from the cockpit on the video screens from take-off to landing.

**Will I get a window seat?**

All passengers receive two boarding passes. Halfway through the flight, you will move to the seat on your second pass. Business and first-class passengers have a window seat for half the flight and a seat next to the window for the other half. Economy passengers have a window or next-to-window seat for half the flight and an aisle seat for the other half. Over Antarctica, we encourage you to walk around the plane to share the views. The pilot flies in long 'figure 8s' so everyone can see the sights well from both sides of the plane.

**What if the weather is bad?**

We have 17 different flight plans. On the morning of the flight, the captain checks the satellite cloud pictures and chooses the route with the best views.

**Will I see penguins and other wildlife?**

Most Antarctic wildlife is at sea level, over 3,000 meters below the plane, so we can't see them clearly. We do not land in Antarctica to protect the environment. To see wildlife, you would need to take a boat tour.

**Can I take photographs?**

Yes, you can take photos. All cameras are welcome. We also offer some fun photo opportunities on board where you can try on Antarctic cold weather clothes.

Little Chefs

For a group of children aged between ten and fifteen, Saturdays are spent learning how to cook seriously. Their weekly lessons in small classes are so popular that there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join the course. Parents pay £280 for the course where their children can have fun and learn to make good food. 

Bill, who is ten years old, says, 'I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down with them to eat the food we've made.' Flora, who is twelve, is having trouble with onions. 'I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really liked it. Then my mum suggested I find a hobby instead of doing nothing at weekends. I was happy staying at home, so I wasn't very interested at first. But I'm really glad I decided to come.'

Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, although the kitchen isn't always tidy when they're cooking! As adults, we're always learning more about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking while they are young, they'll have enough skills to make food for themselves when they leave home.'

Winter Driving

Winter driving is dangerous because it's hard to predict what will happen, and accidents can occur easily. Fog might appear suddenly when you go over a hill. Ice can be hidden under melting snow, ready to make you lose control. The car coming towards you might suddenly slide across the road. 

Rule Number One for driving on icy roads is to drive smoothly. Sudden movements can make your car hard to control. So, when you turn the wheel, use the brakes, or speed up, do it gently and slowly. Imagine you have a full cup of hot coffee on the seat next to you. Drive in a way that you wouldn't spill it.

Rule Number Two is to be aware of what might happen. The more ice there is, the further ahead you should look. Test how long it takes to stop by gently pressing the brakes. Remember, you might be driving faster than you think. In general, allow double your normal stopping distance when the road is wet, three times this distance on snow, and even more on ice. Try to keep control of your car at all times to avoid trouble.

Craigie Aitchison was a painter from Scotland. He moved to London planning to study law but decided to go to art school instead. At art school, he found traditional drawing classes hard, but he continued to paint. In his late twenties, the Italian government gave him money to study art in Italy. There, he became interested in early Italian artists, which influenced some of his work. He loved the greens and browns of the Italian countryside and the clear light there, and he wanted to capture this light in his paintings. To do this, he painted colors in thin layers from light to dark, but he says he never knows exactly how it will turn out. He explains, 'It's a secret - because I don't know myself. I don't start by painting yellow, knowing I'm going to put anything on top.' Like many talented people, Aitchison makes it sound easy. 'Anyone can do the colors - you can buy them. I just notice what colors you put next to each other.' Unlike some artists, he never makes drawings before starting a painting because he thinks he might get bored and not finish the painting. Instead, Aitchison changes his paintings many times before they are done. This is why he prefers models who don't ask to see their pictures while he's painting them. 'If I feel they're worried and want to look at the painting, I can't do it.' Since moving to London, he hasn't felt connected to the Scottish painting scene. He says he doesn't want to follow any tradition and just paints in his own way. However, his work still influences young British painters.

Two years ago, our 14-year-old son, Ben, asked us for a drum set for his birthday. At first, we didn't like the idea because of the noise. Ben said, "It's better than watching TV or playing computer games in my free time, and it will keep me out of trouble." In the end, we agreed. "Okay," we said, "but you must think about the rest of the family and the neighbors when you play."

That was just the start. Because drums are hard to move, the other members of Ben's band began coming to our house with their guitars and other electric equipment. So, for several hours a week, the house shakes with the sound of their instruments and their teenage singing. At least Ben's hobby has been good for our health: whenever the band starts practicing, my husband and I go out for a long walk. 

I must admit that, even though their music sounds a bit strange, they are a friendly and polite group of young men. I can't judge their musical skill—after all, I didn't expect my parents to like the same music I did when I was a teenager—but they do play regularly in local clubs for young people. Our main worry is that they won't spend enough time on their schoolwork because of their music, though this hasn't happened yet. I always tell Ben how important his studies are. But one thing is certain—Ben was right: it has kept him out of trouble, and he is never bored.

Atlantic College

Last week, I visited Atlantic College, a great private school in Wales. This school is special because it gives young people important experiences outside the classroom, as well as the chance to study for their exams. The students are between 16 and 18 years old and come from all over the world. They study in the morning. In the afternoon, they do useful activities like helping on a farm, taking care of people with learning difficulties, or checking rivers for pollution.

One of the best things about Atlantic College is that its students come from many different countries and social backgrounds. Since not many can pay the fees of £20,000 for two years, there are grants available. A quarter of the students are British, and many of them can only attend because they get help from the government.

"I really admire the college for trying to encourage international understanding among young people," said Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands. "You learn to live with people and respect them, even those you don't like. During the summer holidays, my mother couldn't believe how much less I argued with my sister."

In conclusion, Atlantic College provides its students with an excellent education using methods that really seem to work.

Text: 'Being an older student At 32, I have just finished my first year at university. I attend lectures regularly and have learned to read books quickly and write long essays. I decided to go to university after being away from school for fourteen years. As a secretary, I was earning a good amount of money, but I was bored because the job didn't challenge me. I felt stuck and unhappy in my job. I envied the students at the local university because they seemed happy and full of hope. I wanted to be part of that. Now that I am a student, I find it hard to connect with younger classmates. They often think I am a lecturer and ask me questions I can't answer. I also feel different from the lecturers because, even though we are the same age, they know much more than I do. But I am happy to study because I know I need a qualification to get a good job, which is very important to me. Unlike most eighteen-year-olds, I prefer spending weekends with my books rather than going out to parties. There are also benefits like long holidays and discounts at theatres and cinemas. I sometimes worry about what I will do after university, but I hope that going back to school at this age was a good decision.'

Henry Ford was born on a farm in Michigan in 1863, but he didn't like farming. At fifteen, he started working as a mechanic. In 1893, he built his first car. After driving it for 1,500 kilometers, he sold it and made two bigger cars. In 1903, he started the Ford Motor Company. He used strong but light steel to make cheap cars that ordinary people could buy. In 1908, he made the first Ford Model 'T', which cost $825. Soon, he was selling 100 cars a day. By 1927, the Ford Motor Company was worth $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and cheap, but this sometimes meant fewer choices. Henry Ford famously said about the Model T, "You can have any color you like, as long as it's black."

Text: 'Dear Sir, I saw your advertisement for English courses in the newspaper. I would like more information. How much does a course cost? Also, how long is each course and when does the next course start? Yours, Maria Gonzalez Dear Ms. Gonzalez, Thank you for your letter. Our next course starts in three weeks, on Monday, 9 May. This course lasts 6 weeks and costs £150. If you want to start in June, we have another course that lasts 10 weeks and costs £200. I hope this is the information you need. Yours, David May '

Rebecca Stevens was the first woman to climb Mount Everest. Before climbing the highest mountain in the world, she worked as a journalist and lived in a small apartment in south London. In 1993, Rebecca left her job and family to travel to Asia with other climbers. She discovered that life on Everest is tough. "You have to carry everything on your back," she said, "so you can only bring what you really need. You can't wash on the mountain, and I didn't even take a toothbrush. I usually like to be clean, but there is no water, only snow. Water is very heavy, so you only take enough to drink!" When Rebecca reached the top of Mount Everest on May 17, 1993, it was the best moment of her life. She suddenly became famous. Now, she has written a book about the climb, and people often ask her to talk about it. She also has a new job on a science TV show. Rebecca is well-known today and has more money, but she still lives in the small apartment in south London with her pictures and books about mountains.

Dear Mike,

I'm sorry you couldn't come to my party yesterday. Jon told me you had a bad cold and decided to stay in bed. Are you feeling better now? The party was really good; the best I've ever had! Many of my friends were there, and they gave me some nice presents. I'll tell you more about the party when you come to school on Monday.

Love,  
Lorenzo

CANADA GEESE

Canada Geese are large birds with blue and white feathers. When autumn comes, they need to fly south to warmer places. The winters in Canada are so cold that the birds would die if they stayed there. Last spring, Bill Lishman found sixteen young Canada Geese on his farm. They had lost their parents. Bill thought, "These young birds won't know what to do in the autumn." Bill had a small plane, so he decided to teach the birds to follow him. All summer, he took short trips in his plane, and the young geese flew after him. When the cold weather came in autumn, Bill flew to Virginia in the United States, which is 600 miles south of his home in Canada. The geese followed him all the way. Bill left the geese in Virginia and went back home. This spring, Bill was waiting for the birds to return. They didn't come, so Bill flew to Virginia to find them. He searched for two weeks but couldn't find them. When he got back home, Bill found the geese waiting for him. They had found their way home without his help!

Esther's Story

When Esther finished school at sixteen, her aunt Flory gave her £500 for her birthday. Most of Esther's friends chose to go to college, but Esther used the money from her aunt to start her own business. She bought fruit, sugar, and some glass jars to make her own jam. She sold the jam for £1 a jar to her friends and quickly doubled the £500 from her aunt.

At first, Esther's parents didn't want her to spend her time making jam. They thought she should study and hoped she would become a teacher or a doctor one day. But Esther didn't listen to them and continued making jam. After a few months, she started selling it at the local market. Then she began making orange juice, which she sold to a school where one of her friends worked.

After two years, Esther's business grew very large, and her parents were very happy with her success. She made all kinds of food and sold them to shops and supermarkets. She was so busy that she had to hire some people to help her.

Dear Jacqueline,

Would you like to come to the cinema with me after school today? We can watch Pocahontas at the ABC cinema. The film starts at 6 o'clock. Shall we meet outside the cinema?

Love,  
Isabella

---

Dear Isabella,

I'm very sorry, but I can't go to the cinema this evening. My mother has some work, and I need to cook dinner. Why don't you ask Karen to go with you? I hope you enjoy the film. You can tell me about it tomorrow.

Love,  
Jacqueline

Corryvale Farm is in the west of England. Stephen and Jenny Blackler have cows and chickens and sell milk and eggs. But most of their money comes from Jenny's sheep. She has 50 sheep, and each one has enough wool for six sweaters. Every six months, Stephen cuts the wool off the sheep so they don't get too hot. 

Five years ago, Jenny made some sweaters with the wool and tried to sell them at country markets. But it was summer, and the weather was hot, so people didn't want to buy sweaters. She then made some socks. Everyone loved them because they were cheap, strong, and easy to wash. That's how Jenny's business started. 

At first, she made the socks at home, but soon she had thousands of customers, so she had to send the wool to a factory. Now, all the socks are made by machines. There are six colors, five sizes for all ages, and different socks for walkers, sportsmen, and skiers. Jenny is busiest at Christmas because Corryvale socks are a favorite gift. On the walls of Jenny's office, there are many letters from happy customers all over the world.

28 Long Road Brighton 22nd March

Dear Pat,

I arrived here three weeks ago. I'm studying at a language school in Brighton. The students come from many different countries, and I have made a lot of new friends. We have classes for five hours every day. I like our teacher very much. His name is John, and he helps me if I make a mistake. I want to visit London next weekend because I am going back to my country on Monday. Can I see you there? Please write to me soon.

Best wishes,  
Maria

Text: 'BURGLARS LOVE THE AFTERNOON Most house burglaries happen between 2 p.m. and 6 p.m., say the police. Inspector Ian Saunders told our newspaper that house burglaries have increased by more than 30% compared to last year. He also said that 67% of burglaries happen when people leave a door or window open by mistake. He explained that burglaries at night are rare because families are usually at home then. However, winter afternoons are the best time for burglars because it is dark, and they can't be seen easily. Also, many houses are empty because people are often still at work. Inspector Saunders suggested leaving lights on in living rooms and bedrooms when you go on holiday to keep burglars away. He also asked neighbors to watch other houses on the street when people are not at home and to call the police if they see anything unusual. 'We will also tell you how to make your house safe,' Inspector Saunders said. 'This kind of help is free.''

Dear Lynne and Tony,

I'm writing to say thank you for letting me stay at your lovely home for two nights. It was nice to see you again. Here are the photos of your children that you wanted. They turned out well, don't you think? I hope you like them. I really enjoy using my new camera. Next week, I am going to visit my sister in New York. I plan to take many photos there, too. It's been a long time since I last saw my sister. Thanks again.

Love,  
Roy

Text: 'The History of Farming Before people started farming, they went to the forest to find plants or fruit they could eat. This meant that people were always moving to find food. But about 12,000 years ago, in the Middle East, people began to grow their own food. These people were the first farmers. Farming allowed people to stay in one place, and their villages slowly got bigger. Some people in the villages could do other jobs, like making clothes, because the farmers grew food for everyone. Unfortunately, farming was hard when the weather was bad, and then some people did not have enough food to eat. Today, farmers can grow more food, and it travels thousands of kilometers from where it is grown to our homes.'

WORKING FOR AN AIRLINE

Nicola Peet finished school at eighteen, went to college, and then worked at a local airport. After nine months, she started working for Saudi Arabian Airlines and later joined British Airways as a flight attendant. Four years later, she got her current job as a manager. Here is what she said about her job:

"My office is at Heathrow Airport, but I spend 60% of my time flying. I teach flight attendants and help them with any problems. I also attend many meetings. My working hours are usually from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., but sometimes I work from 1 p.m. to 9 p.m. At work, the first thing I do is check flight times on my computer, and then I talk with some of the flight attendants. Sometimes I go on long flights to see how the flight attendants are doing. That's my favorite part of the job, but I also like office work. Traveling can be tiring. When I return from a long trip, all I can do is eat something and then go to bed! I don't earn a lot of money, but I'm happy with British Airways and want to stay there and keep traveling."

Dear Maria,

It's nice to be back home in my country, but I still think about all the friends I made in our English class, especially you. I cried when I left England because my visit was too short. I want to go back to England, but next time I will stay in a different city. I have started English classes again here. I learned a lot in England, but I know I need to study even more. How about you? Are you still looking for a job? I hope you find one soon.

Love,  
Sophie

Text: 'Dear Sir, I lost my bag on a train last week. I was on the 8:30 a.m. train to Cambridge on May 10th. It is a large blue bag, and my name is written on the outside. Have you found this bag? Yours faithfully, Mary Johnson Dear Ms. Johnson, I am happy to tell you that we have your bag here. If you come to this office, I can give it to you. The office is open from 9 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. every day. Yours sincerely, J Wilson'

The Weather

People are interested in the weather for many reasons, and it is important for people in different jobs. For example, the weather is very important for farmers. Many years ago, farmers spent a lot of time looking at the sky, animals, and flowers to try to understand the weather. Now, there are many computer programs that help us learn about the weather, and people can even get weather information on their mobile phones. Today, many people still believe in old ideas about the weather. They say, for example, that if there is a red sky in the evening, it will be sunny the next day. Some people also think that when cows lie down in the fields, it will rain soon.

Frazer and Peter are two 14-year-old boys from a small town in Canada. They have always been friends and classmates. Like their other friends, they enjoy fishing or swimming on weekends. However, for the past few months, they have spent every weekend in Peter's room working on his laptop. This is not because they have a lot of homework. They have created a new computer word game. The idea for the game came from Frazer's little brother, Kevin, who had trouble with reading. Kevin learns words better by seeing pictures and hearing information than by reading. Frazer wanted to help him. Frazer and Peter worked together for over 200 hours to make a computer game, and now it's ready to use. It's a game with speaking and pictures. For example, if you see the word 'hat', there is a drawing of a hat next to it, and you can hear Peter saying 'Hat! Hat!' at the same time. The two boys have won many prizes for their computer game, and it will soon be sold worldwide. Many schools are interested in buying it.

Text: 'HOW DO THE IRISH POP-GROUP 'BOYZONE' LIVE A HEALTHY LIFE? Sleeping well is very important. When I visit my mother's house, I sleep for ten hours. But after a concert, it's hard for me to sleep because my head is full of music. Sport is important too. Before my car accident, I went to the sports centre for two and a half hours a day, five days a week. I can't do that now, so I do about 150 sit-ups a day. I don't drink alcohol or smoke. I try to eat well and drink a lot of water because it's good for health. I should drink about eight glasses a day, but I don't always manage that. People shouldn't work all the time. I love my job, but I also like doing other things. In my free time, I listen to music or watch TV. It's good to relax sometimes. I don't get tired anymore since the doctor told me to eat better. Now I eat lots of vegetables like carrots and spinach every day. But I still eat burgers sometimes!'

Bollywood

'Bollywood' is the name of the film industry in Mumbai, India. It makes almost 1,000 films every year. Since its first film in 1913, Bollywood has made over 29,000 films. This is more than the USA, making it the biggest film industry in the world. Most Indians prefer watching films over any other free-time activity, and ten million of them go to the cinema every day. Bollywood films usually tell romantic love stories, and singing and dancing are important parts of every film. Indian films are also popular outside India. Last year, Bollywood earned over $500 million by selling its films to other countries. Indian actors make more films each year than American actors in Hollywood, but they do not earn as much money. This is why most Bollywood films only cost about $2 million to make, while a Hollywood film is never made for less than $5 million. Most Bollywood actors are young. They work hard but usually only for a few years. Amitabh Bachchan, who some people say is India's greatest actor, is different. He has been the star of more than 140 films during an acting career of almost 40 years.

I am Bill Bryson. I was born in the United States, but I have written several travel books about England. I lived in England with my wife and four children for 20 years. However, for the last three years, we have been living in the United States. Our children are now learning about life in the U.S. I believe they will be happier because they have experienced living in two countries. I like Britain and want to go back, but my daughter, Felicity, will start college here soon, so we will stay for another four years. I recently spent six weeks in England to work on a radio program about the English language and to talk about my new book. Most writers don't enjoy traveling around to promote their books, but I don't mind. I like visiting new places and meeting people. It's very different from my life in the U.S. when I'm writing. In England, people drove me around in big cars, and I stayed in expensive hotels. It was nice because I didn't have to pay any bills. Everyone was kind to me, and it was fun.

Schnauzer Dogs

There are three sizes of Schnauzer dogs. The two smaller sizes came to England over 50 years ago, but the Giant Schnauzer arrived more recently. The name "Giant" fits well because these dogs are 65 to 67.5 cm tall. All Schnauzers have long hair that needs to be cut often. Most smaller Schnauzers are grey, but the Giant Schnauzer is usually black. Schnauzers come from Germany, where farmers use them to help with sheep. They are also used by the police because Schnauzers are very intelligent. A Schnauzer is a nice family dog. It is friendly and very good with young children.

Mary Daniels is a student in England. This year, she had a very interesting summer holiday. She traveled with fifteen other people to the Ruwenzori Mountains in Africa. They went there to help build a road through a forest between two big towns. Mary said, 'It was very difficult because there was no water to drink and no shops where we could buy food.' She also said, 'It was very cold and wet in the mountains. It is one of the wettest places in the world.' Mary stayed in the mountains for six weeks. It was hard work, but she says it was the best thing she has ever done. She hopes to return next year to do more work there.

Dear Keira,

Thank you for your letter. I started at my new school today. A girl named Nicole helped me and showed me where the classrooms are. She is very nice, and I will visit her this weekend. My favorite lesson today was Maths, and I was happy because I knew more than the other girls. I also played hockey for the first time, and I really enjoyed it. Most of the teachers seem friendly, but I'm scared of the head teacher. No one likes him because he shouts a lot. I have to go now because I need to do my homework.

Hester

New Books This Month

The Long Night  
This is David Reilly's first book. David became a writer after teaching English for several years. Maha is a nurse in northern Australia. She works in a small hospital. One day, a baby is very sick, so Maha has to drive all night to take the baby to the nearest big city. They face many problems on the way.

Hard Work  
This exciting story is Joanna Jones's twentieth book. Hard Work is about Sombat, who works with his father, a carpenter, in Thailand. They work long, hard hours making tables and chairs, but they do not have much money. Then one day, a man dressed all in black buys the most beautiful table in the shop.

Hospital or Cinema?  
Marcie Jacome, who studies English in London, wrote this story earlier this year. Tina is a young Brazilian woman who dreams of becoming a doctor. She goes to London to study English and medicine. But one day, she meets a man who asks her to go to the USA with him to become a film star. What will Tina do?

Horse racing has been an important sport for a long time. It started in Central Asia about 4,500 years ago and was popular in ancient Greece and Rome. Modern horse racing began when Arab horses came to Europe in the 12th century. At first, races were long and only had two horses. But in the early 18th century, races became shorter and had more horses competing. Today, horse racing is watched by many people in the USA, second only to baseball. It is also popular in other parts of the world.

Nick Barlow is a British actor who loves his job. He travels around the world to make TV shows. "People are friendly everywhere I go, and when I come home, I remember all the amazing things from each country," he says. Nick has visited many places, but there are still some trips he wants to take. "I'd love to visit South America and return to Australia someday," he adds. 

On each trip, Nick travels with a team. They bring cameras and other equipment needed for filming. Nick doesn't pack much for himself, just a few shirts and trousers, but he always makes sure to bring some books. 

Nick's wife, Helen, is okay with him traveling for work. She has many friends and stays busy. When Nick returns, she enjoys hearing all his travel stories. However, there can be problems. Once, when Nick was in the Malaysian rainforest, he found out that Helen was sick in the hospital. "I felt terrible because I couldn't help, but she didn't want me to come home. I was so happy when I heard she was better," he says.

Parrots

You might have seen these beautiful birds with their bright colors and long tails in the forest or at the zoo. Parrots live in countries like Brazil, Australia, and India. They usually live in large groups. Because they like to eat fruit, they can sometimes cause problems for farmers. There are many types of parrots, but all of them have strong beaks and feet. They use these for climbing and holding food. The largest parrots can live up to 80 years. They are very noisy, but they are smart birds and can be taught to talk easily. Some zoos have parrot shows where you can watch the birds do tricks they have learned.

Text: 'HOWARD BONNIER Bray is a lovely village about fifty kilometers west of London. A young Englishman named Howard Bonnier opened a restaurant called The Palace there about three and a half months ago. Not many people in Britain know Mr. Bonnier's name yet, but he is already quite famous in France. This is because he has written for French magazines about almost all the best restaurants in that country. He is only 29 years old. When Howard was a teenager, he often went to restaurants with his parents. He enjoyed this so much that he decided not to spend money on lots of clothes and CDs; instead, he used his money to visit France and eat in good restaurants. He also bought many French and English cookbooks - he says he has more than two hundred and fifty! So why did he decide to open a restaurant? Simply because he loves cooking. Has it been easy? He says it's expensive to start your own restaurant and it's much harder to cook for fifty people than for your family, but he is sure he made the right choice.'

John Pickering works in a park in a small town in central England. He cuts the grass and waters the flowers. However, last week he was in Tokyo, where millions of Japanese people watched him on TV. This is because John is currently the most popular singer in Japan. A few months ago, John went to Japan to sing in dance clubs in Osaka and Nagoya. A disc jockey heard his songs and played them on the radio. Many young people called the radio station to ask for his songs to be played again. In Japan, John uses the stage name Jon Otis. Despite his success, John plans to keep his job in the park in England because he is unsure how much money he will make from his music. He says, "I must keep my job in the park. I still have to pay my bills!" The other gardeners do not know he is famous in Japan and have never heard him sing. John's wife, Denise, who works in a hospital, says, "This will not change the way we live. I only know John Pickering, not Jon Otis!"

Memo To: All staff  
Subject: Holidays  
From: D Brown  
Date: 22.2.02  

I am organizing the holidays for next year. Please let me know when you would like to take your holiday. If possible, can you give me two options for dates? Please reply by the end of the month. Thank you.  
D Brown  

---

Memo To: D Brown  
Subject: Holidays  
From: J Green  
Date: 23.2.02  

Can I take two weeks' holiday in July? I would like the first two weeks, but if that is not possible, the last two weeks are fine. Also, can I have three extra days off in the first week of December?  
John

Line Dancing

Thousands of people in Britain have a new hobby called line dancing. In almost every town, you can find clubs and classes for this activity. According to Fiona Lever, a teacher, "Line dancing is easy to learn. If you have two feet and can walk, then you can do it!" You don't need a partner because you dance in groups. It's a great way to make new friends. In my classes, there are both young and old people. The boys enjoy it because they can make a lot of noise with their feet during the dances!

When did line dancing start? Most people think it began about fifteen years ago when American country music became popular in Britain.

Text: 'The Rhino There are five types of rhinos in the world today. The Black and White Rhinos live in the open areas of Africa. The other types live in forests in Asia. All rhinos have large, heavy bodies. Their skin is very tough and they have very little hair. A rhino's big body stands on four short legs. Each foot has three toes. They usually walk slowly, but they can run at 50 kilometers per hour. Rhinos are usually quiet and calm animals, and they only eat grass and other plants. A baby rhino weighs 40 kilos when it is born. It stays inside its mother for about fifteen months. An adult rhino weighs over 200 kilos and can live to be 50 years old.'

THE HISTORY OF THE LONDON POLICE

Today, there are policemen everywhere, but in 1700, London had no policemen at all. A few old men used to protect the city streets at night, and they were not paid much. About 300 years ago, London started to grow. The city was very dirty, and many people were poor. There were so many thieves stealing money in the streets that people stayed in their homes as much as possible.

In 1750, Henry Fielding began to pay a group of people to stop thieves. They were like policemen and were called 'Bow Street Runners' because they worked near Bow Street. Fifty years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London had become very big and needed more policemen. So, in 1829, the first Metropolitan (or London) Police Force was started with 3,000 officers. Most of the men worked on foot, but a few rode horses. Until 1920, all the police in London were men. Today, London police are quite well paid, and for the few police officers who still ride horses, the pay is even better than for the others.

Text: 'TO ALL STUDENTS: Would you like to join a camping trip this weekend? We will travel to the forest in the school bus and stay at a campsite from Friday to Sunday. The campsite has hot showers and a small shop, and you can rent bicycles there. The trip costs £25. It gets very cold at night, so you should bring warm clothes and wear strong shoes. If you want to come, please let me know today. Ahmed, Student Secretary'

Text: 'Visit the Edinburgh Festival! Every year, thousands of people visit Edinburgh, the capital city of Scotland, to join the Edinburgh Festival. For three weeks in August and September, the city is full of actors and artists from around the world. They come for the biggest arts festival in Britain. During this time, the streets are full of music and dance from early morning until late at night. You can even watch artists painting on the streets. One of the best parts of the Festival is the 'Fringe', where students perform comedy shows in small halls and cafes. Many tourists come to the Festival to see new films and plays and listen to music by famous musicians. This year, you can watch over five hundred performances with actors from more than forty countries. The tickets for these shows are quite cheap, and it is usually easier to see your favorite star in Edinburgh than in London. So come to Edinburgh next summer, but remember it can be hard to find a room, so why not book your hotel now!'

ICE-FISHING

If you drive north from Toronto for three hours, you will reach Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake turns into ice, and thousands of Canadian fishermen go there every weekend. They build small wooden houses on the ice and paint them in bright colors. Then they sit inside to catch fish that swim under the ice.

Bob Marvisch has been coming here at this time of year for twenty-five years. "You need clothes that are light but warm: two pairs of socks and gloves, several thin sweaters, and a snow suit on top. Catching the fish is easy," he says. "First, you break the ice and make a small round hole in it. Next, you take a fishing line and put some bread on it. Then you put the line through the hole and into the water. You pull the line up when the fish eat the bread. They are between ten and twenty centimeters long. Some people like to eat them, but when I have caught three or four fish, I prefer to have some chocolate or another snack! Today I have caught twenty-five! It's a great sport, and you can meet some nice people here!"

From: Greg  
To: Anna  

Hi Anna,  

I'm not having a good week! Yesterday, my team played a volleyball match, but we lost. The other team was much better than us! Then, my friend Jeff, who lives in Australia, called with bad news. He can't come to stay with us during the holidays because he has a summer job. So, we can't go camping together now. And this morning, my sister woke up late and took my bike to school! She didn't tell me she needed it. I'm really upset with her. I hope you have some good news! Please write back today if you can.  

Greg

Madame Tussaud's

One very famous place for tourists in London is Madame Tussaud's museum. At this museum, people can see wax figures of famous people. Madame Tussaud was born in France in 1761. Her uncle was a doctor who made wax figures of people. He opened a museum for these figures in Paris, and Marie helped him with his work. In 1789, during the French Revolution, Marie was put in prison. While in prison, she had to make wax copies of the heads of famous people who had died, including Queen Marie Antoinette. In 1795, Marie married Francois Tussaud, and in 1802 she moved to London with her wax figures. She opened a museum there, and her figures can still be seen today.

BICYCLES

Bicycles are an affordable and environmentally friendly way to travel. The first bicycle was made about 150 years ago. At first, bicycles were expensive, so only wealthy people could afford them. These early bicycles looked very different from the ones we have today. Later, when bicycles became less expensive, many people started buying them. People began riding bicycles to work and during their free time. Today, people use cars more than bicycles because cars are much faster and you stay dry when it rains. However, some people still prefer to cycle to work. They say there are too many cars in city centers, and it's hard to find parking!

Text: 'The Elephant Show by Daniel Allsop, age 14 Last summer, I went to Thailand for a beach holiday with my family. One day, we visited a park near our hotel. It had beautiful flower gardens, but we were mainly interested in the elephant show. We went to a large area with seats on three sides. Three elephants came in with their trainers and stood in front of big white cards. Each elephant got a paintbrush and started painting on its card. Sometimes, the trainers gave them a new brush with paint and took the old one away. Slowly, following their trainers' instructions, the elephants drew pictures on the cards. I couldn't believe my eyes! One picture showed a river, another a tree, and the third a bunch of flowers. When the trainers held up the paintings, everyone wanted to buy one. We gave the elephants the bananas we brought for our lunch. Twenty years ago, elephants worked in the forest. Now, they don't work there anymore, but the smartest ones live in special centers where visitors can watch them.'

Big Cats

There are many different types of cats. They come in different sizes and do not look or behave the same. Tigers are the largest cats. From head to tail, they can be 3.7 meters long. Most cats don't like water, but tigers often lie in water when it is hot! Lions are the only cats that live in large family groups. Several lions may work together to find food for the group. They usually live in flat, open areas where they can see far and easily follow other animals. All cats need good eyesight because they catch smaller animals for food. They also need to be fast and very strong.

Dear Mrs. Brian,

I'm sorry, but I can't attend your class anymore because I have to go back to my country. My sister is getting married next month, and I want to help her choose a dress. My parents will prepare a big meal for the guests, and there will be a lot of work in the kitchen. I'm sad to leave the English class. You are a great teacher. Please say goodbye to the other students for me. Thank you again.

Best wishes,  
Soraya

Text: '14 Sheffield Road Rotherham 20th May 2002 Dear Mary, I will be in London next Thursday morning. Would you like to have lunch with me? Please write back and tell me when you are free and where I can meet you. Hope to see you then. Yours, Joan 20 Didsbury Drive London NW1 22 May 2002 Dear Joan, Thanks for your letter. I got it this morning. Yes, I'd love to see you. How about meeting outside my office at one o'clock? There's a good Italian restaurant nearby. Do you like Italian food? I need to be back at work by two o'clock, so please don't be late! Yours, Mary '

Dear Lorna,

How are you? I'm happy because I got a new job in the city center last month. I work in a Tourist Information Office, and it is very interesting. I start work every morning at 7:30, so I have to get up very early! I love this job because I meet people from many different countries. I enjoy telling them about our city. Here is a photo of me. I'm wearing my new uniform. Do you like it?

Love,  
Gloria

The ostrich is the biggest bird in the world, and an adult can weigh more than 90 kilos. Most wild ostriches live in southern Africa, but there are not many left. Ostriches have wings like all birds, but they cannot fly. They use their wings to help them turn while running. Ostriches can run very fast, between 65 and 90 kilometers an hour, so it is hard for other animals to catch them. Baby ostriches are the same size as chickens and take about 3 years to grow into adults. Ostriches eat plants and can survive for many days without water.

Victoria Jamieson from Britain started snowboarding when she was 20 years old. Now, at 23, she has won many snowboarding competitions. We talked to her last week at a competition in Switzerland and asked why she began snowboarding. She said, "I've always liked sports, especially skiing, so snowboarding felt like a natural choice. It's easy to learn, and you can become really good in just a few months."

We asked if she practices a lot. She replied, "In winter, I snowboard in the mountains every day from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. I also run and bike. I love doing all of it! I enjoy the competitions and being in the mountains because they are so beautiful. But free-riding, which is snowboarding for fun without competing, is the best thing for me."

We also asked what is important when learning to snowboard. She said, "You can learn quickly, but you need lessons. It's also important to have the right clothes so you don't get wet because, at first, you fall down a lot!"

23 Oak Avenue  
Manchester  

Dear Sir or Madam,

I would like to book a room at your hotel for three nights, from September 15th to 17th. I need a single room with a shower and a telephone. Could you please give me a quiet room on the ground floor?

I will be driving to the hotel. Is there a car park available? I expect to arrive at around 10:30 p.m. Could you tell me what time the restaurant closes in the evening? If possible, I would like to have a meal when I arrive.

Thank you for your assistance.

Yours faithfully,  
Mark Jones

Mount Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Africa. Many people have climbed it, including a seven-year-old boy and an 87-year-old man. There are different paths to reach the top. The Marangu path is five kilometers long and is thought to be the easiest. It takes about five days to climb and is very popular with tourists. However, only half of the people who try to climb Kilimanjaro make it to the top. This is often because the weather can change quickly. At the start, it might be hot and wet, but at the top, there is ice and snow, and the temperature can be below 20 degrees Celsius. Climbers need to bring both sunglasses and warm clothes!

Text: 'Otters Not many people have seen an otter. These animals live near rivers and build their homes from small pieces of wood. They usually come out of their homes at night. Otters are excellent swimmers and can move in the water at more than 10 kilometers an hour. They have thick brown fur that keeps them warm in the water. An otter can close its ears and nose, which allows them to stay underwater for several minutes. Twenty years ago, there were not many otters in Great Britain. The rivers were very polluted, so many fish and insects died, and the otters couldn't find food. But today, there is plenty of food for them because the rivers are clean again.'

Dear Deshini,

I'm happy to have you as my new penfriend. My name is Tom, and I am fifteen years old. I was born in Canada, but now I live in England. Please write and tell me about your life in India. I would love to visit there one day. Do you live in a small village or a big town? What is your school like? Do you have any pictures of your school you could send me? I'm sending you a few photos of my family. I'll send more next time I write. I hope to hear from you soon.

Tom

Text: '17 Green Street Camden London 29th August 2002 Dear John, Thank you for helping me with my English. You are a very good teacher. I enjoyed my time in Cambridge. Now I am staying at my brother's apartment. He is studying to become a doctor. I will stay with him for two weeks and then go back home to Greece. I like London a lot. Yesterday, we went to Regents Park by bus. It was very sunny, and we had a great time. Tonight, I am going to watch a movie with my brother and some of his friends. I'll write to you again from Greece. Best wishes, Kostas'

Text: 'Dear David, I am visiting your country next month with two friends. We don't know where to stay. Are there any cheap hotels in your town? We would like to stay in the center. Can you help us? Carlos Dear Carlos, Hotels in the center are expensive, but I have good news. I talked to my aunt Gloria about you, and she says you can all stay at her house. It has more bedrooms than my house! Is that okay with you? David'

People have always built different types of buildings. We need houses to stay warm and dry. We build stadiums to watch football games and concerts. We use museums to keep beautiful things safe. Many people work together to create a building. The architect decides how the building will look and draws pictures to show their ideas. Engineers make sure the building will be strong and safe. Then, workers carefully construct it. The Sydney Opera House is a famous modern building with a beautiful roof. It looks nice from every side, not just from the top. The Olympic Stadium in Munich also has a famous roof. This interesting building looks like a tent made of glass.

Text: 'Indre, I have a problem and I need your help. Can you come shopping with me tomorrow? My grandmother is turning 80 next month and she is having a party on Saturday. The problem is I don't have anything to wear. I have grown a lot, and now all my trousers are too short! I want to buy some new ones and maybe a pair of boots. I don't have a lot of money to spend, but I think it will be enough. Would you like to meet me in the morning or the afternoon? Let me know. Sarika'

Text: 'The Cerne Giant Sherborne and Dorchester are two towns in the south of England that are close to each other. On the road between them, there are many green hills and fields. On one of these hills, there is a picture of a very large man. This man is called the Cerne Giant because the village next to him is called Cerne. Nobody really knows when the Cerne Giant was made, but people think it was a very long time ago. You can walk from Cerne to get closer to the picture. If you visit on the first of May at sunrise, you will see people from the village dancing around the man on the hill.'

Gail Rollins is one of the best runners in Edinburgh. This summer, she wants to compete in the 10,000 meters and maybe the 5,000 meters at the European Championships. In the past, Gail was famous for finishing second in big races. But she always laughed and smiled, and people in her city love her for that. Everything changed in 2004 when she ran her first half-marathon, a very long road race. She won with the fastest time of the year for any British woman. Gail's manager and husband, Mike Rollins, used to race when he was younger, but he had to stop because he injured his right leg. He can still run a little and sometimes trains with Gail. But it's not fun for Mike when Gail runs faster than him and he can't catch up. Gail trains hard. She does a long run in the morning and fast runs in the afternoon. But she always takes a break from running on Sundays. "I am with her all the time," says Mike. "Sometimes I ask, 'Are you sure you should be eating that?' It's usually cakes, but she can eat almost anything."

Ivan Petrov Ivan was born on a farm in Russia. From age twelve to eighteen, he studied in Poland. His first music teacher couldn't play the piano but taught him and his sister opera songs. His mother started teaching him piano when he was six. At ten, he decided he wanted to write music and soon began his first song.

Oleg Gagarin was the youngest of five children. When he was four, his father, who enjoyed playing the piano, taught him some traditional Russian music. At six, he started piano lessons with a teacher in his city. Oleg quickly began winning prizes for his piano playing. At fourteen, he went to a music college in Austria for two years, then returned to Russia.

Josef Heptmann's father was German and taught music in Poland, where Josef was born. The family moved to Germany when Josef was two, and he started playing the piano a year later. He gave his first concert at six. At ten, he performed fifty-two concerts in two months during a trip to England! Josef always loved music but was also interested in physics and languages. He is very busy now, but he hopes to write his own music one day.

Bill Prince-Smith was a farmer, a teacher, and a dentist before he started writing children's books at 60 years old. Now, thirteen years later, he has written over 80 books. Every day, he goes to his office to write. In the evening, he gives his work to his wife to read. "She tells me when she doesn't like something," says Bill. His ten grandchildren don't live nearby, but they also read his stories and say if they are good or bad. This way, Bill has learned what young children like to read. Bill writes about life in his village and the nearby farms. His fifth book is his favorite: "The Sheepdog" is about a farmer and the dog that helps him. "I have always liked animals," says Bill, "and dogs are so clever; they learn very quickly." Last year, the book was made into a film with real animals and actors. The filmmakers used the latest computer technology to make it look like the animals are speaking. Bill was very happy with the film. "Sometimes filmmakers change books, but they didn't change mine, and I love the film."

Text: 'POSTCARDS Today, people enjoy sending postcards to their friends and family. These postcards usually have pictures of beaches, mountains, or castles on them, and you can write a message on the back. Many people send postcards when they are on holiday because postcards are cheap, and the pictures on them are often better than their own photos. The first postcard was sent at the end of the nineteenth century. It had a picture of a town by the sea. Later, postcards showed pictures of things in the news that week, like an accident or an important person's visit. People liked these because newspapers did not have pictures at that time.'

Text: 'Dinosaurs No one has ever seen a dinosaur because they died out about 60 million years ago, long before humans existed. We don't know exactly why they disappeared. Birds are the closest living relatives to dinosaurs. Dinosaurs looked different from each other. There were more than 5000 types. Some were very small, while others were huge. The biggest dinosaurs were larger than any other land animals ever. For example, the Brontosaurus was twenty meters long and ate plants. The Tyrannosaurus Rex was not as big, but it was stronger. It had sharp teeth for eating meat and could run fast because of its long back legs.'

Text: 'BEARS Bears can be dangerous animals. Adult bears are very strong and can kill a person. They are good at climbing trees and can run very fast. However, they do not see well and, like most animals, they find food by using their noses. There are seven types of bears. The largest is the white polar bear, which can be almost three meters tall. There are two types of black bears: one lives in the forests of North America, and the other lives in Southeast Asia. But not all black bears are actually black; they can be dark brown or reddish brown. Everyone loves the black and white panda bear, which comes from China. Today, not many pandas live in the forest because it is hard for them to find food.'

CROCODILES

Crocodiles live in warm parts of the world, like Africa, South America, and Northern Australia. They usually stay in slow-moving water, but they can move quickly in water and on land. You often see many crocodiles together in big groups. They eat anything they catch, such as fish, birds, and small animals. Sometimes, they even eat large animals or people. There are more than ten different types of crocodiles. All of them have very sharp teeth. They often lose their teeth, but new ones grow back quickly. Crocodiles are usually about 3.5 meters long, but some can be much bigger. Crocodiles can live for a long time. The oldest crocodile in a zoo lived to be 66 years old.

A HISTORY OF AIR TRAVEL

In 1783, two French brothers made the first balloon that could carry people into the air. One hundred and twenty years later, in 1903, the Wright brothers built the first airplane with an engine and flew it in the United States. In 1918, the US Post Office started the first airmail service. Airplanes changed a lot in the next thirty years. In the 1950s, airplanes became much faster because they had jet engines. In 1976, Concorde was built in the UK and France. It is the fastest passenger plane in the world and can fly at 2500 kilometers an hour, making the trip from London to New York only four hours long. Today, millions of people travel by airplane, and it is hard to imagine a world without them.

Text: 'The Globe Theatre Visiting the theatre in London 400 years ago was very different from visiting a modern theatre. The building was round, there was no roof, and people got cold and wet if the weather was bad. The queen loved going to the Globe Theatre, by the River Thames, to see the plays of William Shakespeare. At that time, all the actors were men. Visitors ate, talked to their friends, walked around during the show, and some people even threw things at the actors! Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre is in the same place near the river. You can enjoy a Shakespeare play there or learn about life in the seventeenth century.'

Dear Jeff,

I'm having a great holiday in Australia. When we arrived two weeks ago, the weather was bad and it was cold. Now the weather is better, and we go to the beach every day. This week we are staying in Sydney, but next week we will go to the Great Barrier Reef. The water there is very warm, and I love swimming. The fish are all different colors: red, yellow, purple! Australia is very beautiful. We don't want to come home!

See you at the end of September.

Sue
